  59 #ifdef CONFIG_SCHED_DEBUG
  60 /*
  61  * Debugging: various feature bits
  62  *
  63  * If SCHED_DEBUG is disabled, each compilation unit has its own copy of
  64  * sysctl_sched_features, defined in sched.h, to allow constants propagation
  65  * at compile time and compiler optimization based on features default.
  66  */
  67 #define SCHED_FEAT(name, enabled)       \
  68         (1UL << __SCHED_FEAT_##name) * enabled |
  69 const_debug unsigned int sysctl_sched_features =
  70 #include "features.h"
  71         0;
  72 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(sysctl_sched_features);
  73 #undef SCHED_FEAT
  74 #endif
  75 
  76 /*
  77  * Number of tasks to iterate in a single balance run.
  78  * Limited because this is done with IRQs disabled.
  79  */
  80 const_debug unsigned int sysctl_sched_nr_migrate = 32;
  81 
  82 /*
  83  * period over which we measure -rt task CPU usage in us.
  84  * default: 1s
  85  */
  86 unsigned int sysctl_sched_rt_period = 1000000;
  87 
  88 __read_mostly int scheduler_running;
  89 
  90 /*
  91  * part of the period that we allow rt tasks to run in us.
  92  * default: 0.95s
  93  */
  94 int sysctl_sched_rt_runtime = 950000;
  95 
  96 
  97 /*
  98  * Serialization rules:
  99  *
 100  * Lock order:
 101  *
 102  *   p->pi_lock
 103  *     rq->lock
 104  *       hrtimer_cpu_base->lock (hrtimer_start() for bandwidth controls)
 105  *
 106  *  rq1->lock
 107  *    rq2->lock  where: rq1 < rq2
 108  *
 109  * Regular state:
 110  *
 111  * Normal scheduling state is serialized by rq->lock. __schedule() takes the
 112  * local CPU's rq->lock, it optionally removes the task from the runqueue and
 113  * always looks at the local rq data structures to find the most elegible task
 114  * to run next.
 115  *
 116  * Task enqueue is also under rq->lock, possibly taken from another CPU.
 117  * Wakeups from another LLC domain might use an IPI to transfer the enqueue to
 118  * the local CPU to avoid bouncing the runqueue state around [ see
 119  * ttwu_queue_wakelist() ]
 120  *
 121  * Task wakeup, specifically wakeups that involve migration, are horribly
 122  * complicated to avoid having to take two rq->locks.
 123  *
 124  * Special state:
 125  *
 126  * System-calls and anything external will use task_rq_lock() which acquires
 127  * both p->pi_lock and rq->lock. As a consequence the state they change is
 128  * stable while holding either lock:
 129  *
 130  *  - sched_setaffinity()/
 131  *    set_cpus_allowed_ptr():   p->cpus_ptr, p->nr_cpus_allowed
 132  *  - set_user_nice():          p->se.load, p->*prio
 133  *  - __sched_setscheduler():   p->sched_class, p->policy, p->*prio,
 134  *                              p->se.load, p->rt_priority,
 135  *                              p->dl.dl_{runtime, deadline, period, flags, bw, density}
 136  *  - sched_setnuma():          p->numa_preferred_nid
 137  *  - sched_move_task()/
 138  *    cpu_cgroup_fork():        p->sched_task_group
 139  *  - uclamp_update_active()    p->uclamp*
 140  *
 141  * p->state <- TASK_*:
 142  *
 143  *   is changed locklessly using set_current_state(), __set_current_state() or
 144  *   set_special_state(), see their respective comments, or by
 145  *   try_to_wake_up(). This latter uses p->pi_lock to serialize against
 146  *   concurrent self.
 147  *
 148  * p->on_rq <- { 0, 1 = TASK_ON_RQ_QUEUED, 2 = TASK_ON_RQ_MIGRATING }:
 149  *
 150  *   is set by activate_task() and cleared by deactivate_task(), under
 151  *   rq->lock. Non-zero indicates the task is runnable, the special
 152  *   ON_RQ_MIGRATING state is used for migration without holding both
 153  *   rq->locks. It indicates task_cpu() is not stable, see task_rq_lock().
 154  *
 155  * p->on_cpu <- { 0, 1 }:
 156  *
 157  *   is set by prepare_task() and cleared by finish_task() such that it will be
 158  *   set before p is scheduled-in and cleared after p is scheduled-out, both
 159  *   under rq->lock. Non-zero indicates the task is running on its CPU.
 160  *
 161  *   [ The astute reader will observe that it is possible for two tasks on one
 162  *     CPU to have ->on_cpu = 1 at the same time. ]
 163  *
 164  * task_cpu(p): is changed by set_task_cpu(), the rules are:
 165  *
 166  *  - Don't call set_task_cpu() on a blocked task:
 167  *
 168  *    We don't care what CPU we're not running on, this simplifies hotplug,
 169  *    the CPU assignment of blocked tasks isn't required to be valid.
 170  *
 171  *  - for try_to_wake_up(), called under p->pi_lock:
 172  *
 173  *    This allows try_to_wake_up() to only take one rq->lock, see its comment.
 174  *
 175  *  - for migration called under rq->lock:
 176  *    [ see task_on_rq_migrating() in task_rq_lock() ]
 177  *
 178  *    o move_queued_task()
 179  *    o detach_task()
 180  *
 181  *  - for migration called under double_rq_lock():
 182  *
 183  *    o __migrate_swap_task()
 184  *    o push_rt_task() / pull_rt_task()
 185  *    o push_dl_task() / pull_dl_task()
 186  *    o dl_task_offline_migration()
 187  *
 188  */
 189 
 190 /*
 191  * __task_rq_lock - lock the rq @p resides on.
 192  */
 193 struct rq *__task_rq_lock(struct task_struct *p, struct rq_flags *rf)
 194         __acquires(rq->lock)
 195 {
 196         struct rq *rq;
 197 
 198         lockdep_assert_held(&p->pi_lock);
 199 
 200         for (;;) {
 201                 rq = task_rq(p);
 202                 raw_spin_lock(&rq->lock);
 203                 if (likely(rq == task_rq(p) && !task_on_rq_migrating(p))) {
 204                         rq_pin_lock(rq, rf);
 205                         return rq;
 206                 }
 207                 raw_spin_unlock(&rq->lock);
 208 
 209                 while (unlikely(task_on_rq_migrating(p)))
 210                         cpu_relax();
 211         }
 212 }
 213 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(__task_rq_lock);
 214 
 215 /*
 216  * task_rq_lock - lock p->pi_lock and lock the rq @p resides on.
 217  */
 218 struct rq *task_rq_lock(struct task_struct *p, struct rq_flags *rf)
 219         __acquires(p->pi_lock)
 220         __acquires(rq->lock)
 221 {
 222         struct rq *rq;
 223 
 224         for (;;) {
 225                 raw_spin_lock_irqsave(&p->pi_lock, rf->flags);
 226                 rq = task_rq(p);
 227                 raw_spin_lock(&rq->lock);
 228                 /*
 229                  *      move_queued_task()              task_rq_lock()
 230                  *
 231                  *      ACQUIRE (rq->lock)
 232                  *      [S] ->on_rq = MIGRATING         [L] rq = task_rq()
 233                  *      WMB (__set_task_cpu())          ACQUIRE (rq->lock);
 234                  *      [S] ->cpu = new_cpu             [L] task_rq()
 235                  *                                      [L] ->on_rq
 236                  *      RELEASE (rq->lock)
 237                  *
 238                  * If we observe the old CPU in task_rq_lock(), the acquire of
 239                  * the old rq->lock will fully serialize against the stores.
 240                  *
 241                  * If we observe the new CPU in task_rq_lock(), the address
 242                  * dependency headed by '[L] rq = task_rq()' and the acquire
 243                  * will pair with the WMB to ensure we then also see migrating.
 244                  */
 245                 if (likely(rq == task_rq(p) && !task_on_rq_migrating(p))) {
 246                         rq_pin_lock(rq, rf);
 247                         return rq;
 248                 }
 249                 raw_spin_unlock(&rq->lock);
 250                 raw_spin_unlock_irqrestore(&p->pi_lock, rf->flags);
 251 
 252                 while (unlikely(task_on_rq_migrating(p)))
 253                         cpu_relax();
 254         }
 255 }
 256 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(task_rq_lock);
 257 
 258 /*
 259  * RQ-clock updating methods:
 260  */
 261 
 262 static void update_rq_clock_task(struct rq *rq, s64 delta)
 263 {
 264 /*
 265  * In theory, the compile should just see 0 here, and optimize out the call
 266  * to sched_rt_avg_update. But I don't trust it...
 267  */
 268         s64 __maybe_unused steal = 0, irq_delta = 0;
 269 
 270 #ifdef CONFIG_IRQ_TIME_ACCOUNTING
 271         irq_delta = irq_time_read(cpu_of(rq)) - rq->prev_irq_time;
 272 
 273         /*
 274          * Since irq_time is only updated on {soft,}irq_exit, we might run into
 275          * this case when a previous update_rq_clock() happened inside a
 276          * {soft,}irq region.
 277          *
 278          * When this happens, we stop ->clock_task and only update the
 279          * prev_irq_time stamp to account for the part that fit, so that a next
 280          * update will consume the rest. This ensures ->clock_task is
 281          * monotonic.
 282          *
 283          * It does however cause some slight miss-attribution of {soft,}irq
 284          * time, a more accurate solution would be to update the irq_time using
 285          * the current rq->clock timestamp, except that would require using
 286          * atomic ops.
 287          */
 288         if (irq_delta > delta)
 289                 irq_delta = delta;
 290 
 291         rq->prev_irq_time += irq_delta;
 292         delta -= irq_delta;
 293 #endif
 294 #ifdef CONFIG_PARAVIRT_TIME_ACCOUNTING
 295         if (static_key_false((&paravirt_steal_rq_enabled))) {
 296                 steal = paravirt_steal_clock(cpu_of(rq));
 297                 steal -= rq->prev_steal_time_rq;
 298 
 299                 if (unlikely(steal > delta))
 300                         steal = delta;
 301 
 302                 rq->prev_steal_time_rq += steal;
 303                 delta -= steal;
 304         }
 305 #endif
 306 
 307         rq->clock_task += delta;
 308 
 309 #ifdef CONFIG_HAVE_SCHED_AVG_IRQ
 310         if ((irq_delta + steal) && sched_feat(NONTASK_CAPACITY))
 311                 update_irq_load_avg(rq, irq_delta + steal);
 312 #endif
 313         update_rq_clock_pelt(rq, delta);
 314 }
 315 
 316 void update_rq_clock(struct rq *rq)
 317 {
 318         s64 delta;
 319 
 320         lockdep_assert_held(&rq->lock);
 321 
 322         if (rq->clock_update_flags & RQCF_ACT_SKIP)
 323                 return;
 324 
 325 #ifdef CONFIG_SCHED_DEBUG
 326         if (sched_feat(WARN_DOUBLE_CLOCK))
 327                 SCHED_WARN_ON(rq->clock_update_flags & RQCF_UPDATED);
 328         rq->clock_update_flags |= RQCF_UPDATED;
 329 #endif
 330 
 331         delta = sched_clock_cpu(cpu_of(rq)) - rq->clock;
 332         if (delta < 0)
 333                 return;
 334         rq->clock += delta;
 335         update_rq_clock_task(rq, delta);
 336 }
 337 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(update_rq_clock);
 338 
 339 static inline void
 340 rq_csd_init(struct rq *rq, struct __call_single_data *csd, smp_call_func_t func)
 341 {
 342         csd->flags = 0;
 343         csd->func = func;
 344         csd->info = rq;
 345 }
 346 
 347 #ifdef CONFIG_SCHED_HRTICK
 348 /*
 349  * Use HR-timers to deliver accurate preemption points.
 350  */
 351 
 352 static void hrtick_clear(struct rq *rq)
 353 {
 354         if (hrtimer_active(&rq->hrtick_timer))
 355                 hrtimer_cancel(&rq->hrtick_timer);
 356 }
 357 
 358 /*
 359  * High-resolution timer tick.
 360  * Runs from hardirq context with interrupts disabled.
 361  */
 362 static enum hrtimer_restart hrtick(struct hrtimer *timer)
 363 {
 364         struct rq *rq = container_of(timer, struct rq, hrtick_timer);
 365         struct rq_flags rf;
 366 
 367         WARN_ON_ONCE(cpu_of(rq) != smp_processor_id());
 368 
 369         rq_lock(rq, &rf);
 370         update_rq_clock(rq);
 371         rq->curr->sched_class->task_tick(rq, rq->curr, 1);
 372         rq_unlock(rq, &rf);
 373 
 374         return HRTIMER_NORESTART;
 375 }
 376 
 377 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
 378 
 379 static void __hrtick_restart(struct rq *rq)
 380 {
 381         struct hrtimer *timer = &rq->hrtick_timer;
 382         ktime_t time = rq->hrtick_time;
 383 
 384         hrtimer_start(timer, time, HRTIMER_MODE_ABS_PINNED_HARD);
 385 }
 386 
 387 /*
 388  * called from hardirq (IPI) context
 389  */
 390 static void __hrtick_start(void *arg)
 391 {
 392         struct rq *rq = arg;
 393         struct rq_flags rf;
 394 
 395         rq_lock(rq, &rf);
 396         __hrtick_restart(rq);
 397         rq_unlock(rq, &rf);
 398 }
 399 
 400 /*
 401  * Called to set the hrtick timer state.
 402  *
 403  * called with rq->lock held and irqs disabled
 404  */
 405 void hrtick_start(struct rq *rq, u64 delay)
 406 {
 407         struct hrtimer *timer = &rq->hrtick_timer;
 408         s64 delta;
 409 
 410         /*
 411          * Don't schedule slices shorter than 10000ns, that just
 412          * doesn't make sense and can cause timer DoS.
 413          */
 414         delta = max_t(s64, delay, 10000LL);
 415         rq->hrtick_time = ktime_add_ns(timer->base->get_time(), delta);
 416 
 417         if (rq == this_rq())
 418                 __hrtick_restart(rq);
 419         else
 420                 smp_call_function_single_async(cpu_of(rq), &rq->hrtick_csd);
 421 }
 422 
 423 #else
 424 /*
 425  * Called to set the hrtick timer state.
 426  *
 427  * called with rq->lock held and irqs disabled
 428  */
 429 void hrtick_start(struct rq *rq, u64 delay)
 430 {
 431         /*
 432          * Don't schedule slices shorter than 10000ns, that just
 433          * doesn't make sense. Rely on vruntime for fairness.
 434          */
 435         delay = max_t(u64, delay, 10000LL);
 436         hrtimer_start(&rq->hrtick_timer, ns_to_ktime(delay),
 437                       HRTIMER_MODE_REL_PINNED_HARD);
 438 }
 439 
 440 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
 441 
 442 static void hrtick_rq_init(struct rq *rq)
 443 {
 444 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
 445         rq_csd_init(rq, &rq->hrtick_csd, __hrtick_start);
 446 #endif
 447         hrtimer_init(&rq->hrtick_timer, CLOCK_MONOTONIC, HRTIMER_MODE_REL_HARD);
 448         rq->hrtick_timer.function = hrtick;
 449 }
 450 #else   /* CONFIG_SCHED_HRTICK */
 451 static inline void hrtick_clear(struct rq *rq)
 452 {
 453 }
 454 
 455 static inline void hrtick_rq_init(struct rq *rq)
 456 {
 457 }
 458 #endif  /* CONFIG_SCHED_HRTICK */
 459 
 460 /*
 461  * cmpxchg based fetch_or, macro so it works for different integer types
 462  */
 463 #define fetch_or(ptr, mask)                                             \
 464         ({                                                              \
 465                 typeof(ptr) _ptr = (ptr);                               \
 466                 typeof(mask) _mask = (mask);                            \
 467                 typeof(*_ptr) _old, _val = *_ptr;                       \
 468                                                                         \
 469                 for (;;) {                                              \
 470                         _old = cmpxchg(_ptr, _val, _val | _mask);       \
 471                         if (_old == _val)                               \
 472                                 break;                                  \
 473                         _val = _old;                                    \
 474                 }                                                       \
 475         _old;                                                           \
 476 })
 477 
 478 #if defined(CONFIG_SMP) && defined(TIF_POLLING_NRFLAG)
 479 /*
 480  * Atomically set TIF_NEED_RESCHED and test for TIF_POLLING_NRFLAG,
 481  * this avoids any races wrt polling state changes and thereby avoids
 482  * spurious IPIs.
 483  */
 484 static bool set_nr_and_not_polling(struct task_struct *p)
 485 {
 486         struct thread_info *ti = task_thread_info(p);
 487         return !(fetch_or(&ti->flags, _TIF_NEED_RESCHED) & _TIF_POLLING_NRFLAG);
 488 }
 489 
 490 /*
 491  * Atomically set TIF_NEED_RESCHED if TIF_POLLING_NRFLAG is set.
 492  *
 493  * If this returns true, then the idle task promises to call
 494  * sched_ttwu_pending() and reschedule soon.
 495  */
 496 static bool set_nr_if_polling(struct task_struct *p)
 497 {
 498         struct thread_info *ti = task_thread_info(p);
 499         typeof(ti->flags) old, val = READ_ONCE(ti->flags);
 500 
 501         for (;;) {
 502                 if (!(val & _TIF_POLLING_NRFLAG))
 503                         return false;
 504                 if (val & _TIF_NEED_RESCHED)
 505                         return true;
 506                 old = cmpxchg(&ti->flags, val, val | _TIF_NEED_RESCHED);
 507                 if (old == val)
 508                         break;
 509                 val = old;
 510         }
 511         return true;
 512 }
 513 
 514 #else
 515 static bool set_nr_and_not_polling(struct task_struct *p)
 516 {
 517         set_tsk_need_resched(p);
 518         return true;
 519 }
 520 
 521 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
 522 static bool set_nr_if_polling(struct task_struct *p)
 523 {
 524         return false;
 525 }
 526 #endif
 527 #endif
 528 
 529 static bool __wake_q_add(struct wake_q_head *head, struct task_struct *task)
 530 {
 531         struct wake_q_node *node = &task->wake_q;
 532 
 533         /*
 534          * Atomically grab the task, if ->wake_q is !nil already it means
 535          * its already queued (either by us or someone else) and will get the
 536          * wakeup due to that.
 537          *
 538          * In order to ensure that a pending wakeup will observe our pending
 539          * state, even in the failed case, an explicit smp_mb() must be used.
 540          */
 541         smp_mb__before_atomic();
 542         if (unlikely(cmpxchg_relaxed(&node->next, NULL, WAKE_Q_TAIL)))
 543                 return false;
 544 
 545         /*
 546          * The head is context local, there can be no concurrency.
 547          */
 548         *head->lastp = node;
 549         head->lastp = &node->next;
 550         head->count++;
 551         return true;
 552 }
 553 
 554 /**
 555  * wake_q_add() - queue a wakeup for 'later' waking.
 556  * @head: the wake_q_head to add @task to
 557  * @task: the task to queue for 'later' wakeup
 558  *
 559  * Queue a task for later wakeup, most likely by the wake_up_q() call in the
 560  * same context, _HOWEVER_ this is not guaranteed, the wakeup can come
 561  * instantly.
 562  *
 563  * This function must be used as-if it were wake_up_process(); IOW the task
 564  * must be ready to be woken at this location.
 565  */
 566 void wake_q_add(struct wake_q_head *head, struct task_struct *task)
 567 {
 568         if (__wake_q_add(head, task))
 569                 get_task_struct(task);
 570 }
 571 
 572 /**
 573  * wake_q_add_safe() - safely queue a wakeup for 'later' waking.
 574  * @head: the wake_q_head to add @task to
 575  * @task: the task to queue for 'later' wakeup
 576  *
 577  * Queue a task for later wakeup, most likely by the wake_up_q() call in the
 578  * same context, _HOWEVER_ this is not guaranteed, the wakeup can come
 579  * instantly.
 580  *
 581  * This function must be used as-if it were wake_up_process(); IOW the task
 582  * must be ready to be woken at this location.
 583  *
 584  * This function is essentially a task-safe equivalent to wake_q_add(). Callers
 585  * that already hold reference to @task can call the 'safe' version and trust
 586  * wake_q to do the right thing depending whether or not the @task is already
 587  * queued for wakeup.
 588  */
 589 void wake_q_add_safe(struct wake_q_head *head, struct task_struct *task)
 590 {
 591         if (!__wake_q_add(head, task))
 592                 put_task_struct(task);
 593 }
 594 
 595 void wake_up_q(struct wake_q_head *head)
 596 {
 597         struct wake_q_node *node = head->first;
 598 
 599         while (node != WAKE_Q_TAIL) {
 600                 struct task_struct *task;
 601 
 602                 task = container_of(node, struct task_struct, wake_q);
 603                 BUG_ON(!task);
 604                 /* Task can safely be re-inserted now: */
 605                 node = node->next;
 606                 task->wake_q.next = NULL;
 607                 task->wake_q_count = head->count;
 608 
 609                 /*
 610                  * wake_up_process() executes a full barrier, which pairs with
 611                  * the queueing in wake_q_add() so as not to miss wakeups.
 612                  */
 613                 wake_up_process(task);
 614                 task->wake_q_count = 0;
 615                 put_task_struct(task);
 616         }
 617 }
 618 
 619 /*
 620  * resched_curr - mark rq's current task 'to be rescheduled now'.
 621  *
 622  * On UP this means the setting of the need_resched flag, on SMP it
 623  * might also involve a cross-CPU call to trigger the scheduler on
 624  * the target CPU.
 625  */
 626 void resched_curr(struct rq *rq)
 627 {
 628         struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
 629         int cpu;
 630 
 631         lockdep_assert_held(&rq->lock);
 632 
 633         if (test_tsk_need_resched(curr))
 634                 return;
 635 
 636         cpu = cpu_of(rq);
 637 
 638         if (cpu == smp_processor_id()) {
 639                 set_tsk_need_resched(curr);
 640                 set_preempt_need_resched();
 641                 return;
 642         }
 643 
 644         if (set_nr_and_not_polling(curr))
 645                 smp_send_reschedule(cpu);
 646         else
 647                 trace_sched_wake_idle_without_ipi(cpu);
 648 }
 649 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(resched_curr);
 650 
 651 void resched_cpu(int cpu)
 652 {
 653         struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
 654         unsigned long flags;
 655 
 656         raw_spin_lock_irqsave(&rq->lock, flags);
 657         if (cpu_online(cpu) || cpu == smp_processor_id())
 658                 resched_curr(rq);
 659         raw_spin_unlock_irqrestore(&rq->lock, flags);
 660 }
 661 
 662 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
 663 #ifdef CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON
 664 /*
 665  * In the semi idle case, use the nearest busy CPU for migrating timers
 666  * from an idle CPU.  This is good for power-savings.
 667  *
 668  * We don't do similar optimization for completely idle system, as
 669  * selecting an idle CPU will add more delays to the timers than intended
 670  * (as that CPU's timer base may not be uptodate wrt jiffies etc).
 671  */
 672 int get_nohz_timer_target(void)
 673 {
 674         int i, cpu = smp_processor_id(), default_cpu = -1;
 675         struct sched_domain *sd;
 676 
 677         if (housekeeping_cpu(cpu, HK_FLAG_TIMER) && cpu_active(cpu)) {
 678                 if (!idle_cpu(cpu))
 679                         return cpu;
 680                 default_cpu = cpu;
 681         }
 682 
 683         rcu_read_lock();
 684         for_each_domain(cpu, sd) {
 685                 for_each_cpu_and(i, sched_domain_span(sd),
 686                         housekeeping_cpumask(HK_FLAG_TIMER)) {
 687                         if (cpu == i)
 688                                 continue;
 689 
 690                         if (!idle_cpu(i)) {
 691                                 cpu = i;
 692                                 goto unlock;
 693                         }
 694                 }
 695         }
 696 
 697         if (default_cpu == -1) {
 698                 for_each_cpu_and(i, cpu_active_mask,
 699                                  housekeeping_cpumask(HK_FLAG_TIMER)) {
 700                         if (cpu == i)
 701                                 continue;
 702 
 703                         if (!idle_cpu(i)) {
 704                                 cpu = i;
 705                                 goto unlock;
 706                         }
 707                 }
 708 
 709                 /* no active, not-idle, housekpeeing CPU found. */
 710                 default_cpu = cpumask_any(cpu_active_mask);
 711 
 712                 if (unlikely(default_cpu >= nr_cpu_ids))
 713                         goto unlock;
 714         }
 715 
 716         cpu = default_cpu;
 717 unlock:
 718         rcu_read_unlock();
 719         return cpu;
 720 }
 721 
 722 /*
 723  * When add_timer_on() enqueues a timer into the timer wheel of an
 724  * idle CPU then this timer might expire before the next timer event
 725  * which is scheduled to wake up that CPU. In case of a completely
 726  * idle system the next event might even be infinite time into the
 727  * future. wake_up_idle_cpu() ensures that the CPU is woken up and
 728  * leaves the inner idle loop so the newly added timer is taken into
 729  * account when the CPU goes back to idle and evaluates the timer
 730  * wheel for the next timer event.
 731  */
 732 static void wake_up_idle_cpu(int cpu)
 733 {
 734         struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
 735 
 736         if (cpu == smp_processor_id())
 737                 return;
 738 
 739         if (set_nr_and_not_polling(rq->idle))
 740                 smp_send_reschedule(cpu);
 741         else
 742                 trace_sched_wake_idle_without_ipi(cpu);
 743 }
 744 
 745 static bool wake_up_full_nohz_cpu(int cpu)
 746 {
 747         /*
 748          * We just need the target to call irq_exit() and re-evaluate
 749          * the next tick. The nohz full kick at least implies that.
 750          * If needed we can still optimize that later with an
 751          * empty IRQ.
 752          */
 753         if (cpu_is_offline(cpu))
 754                 return true;  /* Don't try to wake offline CPUs. */
 755         if (tick_nohz_full_cpu(cpu)) {
 756                 if (cpu != smp_processor_id() ||
 757                     tick_nohz_tick_stopped())
 758                         tick_nohz_full_kick_cpu(cpu);
 759                 return true;
 760         }
 761 
 762         return false;
 763 }
 764 
 765 /*
 766  * Wake up the specified CPU.  If the CPU is going offline, it is the
 767  * caller's responsibility to deal with the lost wakeup, for example,
 768  * by hooking into the CPU_DEAD notifier like timers and hrtimers do.
 769  */
 770 void wake_up_nohz_cpu(int cpu)
 771 {
 772         if (!wake_up_full_nohz_cpu(cpu))
 773                 wake_up_idle_cpu(cpu);
 774 }
 775 
 776 static void nohz_csd_func(void *info)
 777 {
 778         struct rq *rq = info;
 779         int cpu = cpu_of(rq);
 780         unsigned int flags;
 781 
 782         /*
 783          * Release the rq::nohz_csd.
 784          */
 785         flags = atomic_fetch_andnot(NOHZ_KICK_MASK, nohz_flags(cpu));
 786         WARN_ON(!(flags & NOHZ_KICK_MASK));
 787 
 788         rq->idle_balance = idle_cpu(cpu);
 789         if (rq->idle_balance && !need_resched()) {
 790                 rq->nohz_idle_balance = flags;
 791                 raise_softirq_irqoff(SCHED_SOFTIRQ);
 792         }
 793 }
 794 
 795 #endif /* CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON */
 796 
 797 #ifdef CONFIG_NO_HZ_FULL
 798 bool sched_can_stop_tick(struct rq *rq)
 799 {
 800         int fifo_nr_running;
 801 
 802         /* Deadline tasks, even if single, need the tick */
 803         if (rq->dl.dl_nr_running)
 804                 return false;
 805 
 806         /*
 807          * If there are more than one RR tasks, we need the tick to effect the
 808          * actual RR behaviour.
 809          */
 810         if (rq->rt.rr_nr_running) {
 811                 if (rq->rt.rr_nr_running == 1)
 812                         return true;
 813                 else
 814                         return false;
 815         }
 816 
 817         /*
 818          * If there's no RR tasks, but FIFO tasks, we can skip the tick, no
 819          * forced preemption between FIFO tasks.
 820          */
 821         fifo_nr_running = rq->rt.rt_nr_running - rq->rt.rr_nr_running;
 822         if (fifo_nr_running)
 823                 return true;
 824 
 825         /*
 826          * If there are no DL,RR/FIFO tasks, there must only be CFS tasks left;
 827          * if there's more than one we need the tick for involuntary
 828          * preemption.
 829          */
 830         if (rq->nr_running > 1)
 831                 return false;
 832 
 833         return true;
 834 }
 835 #endif /* CONFIG_NO_HZ_FULL */
 836 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
 837 
 838 #if defined(CONFIG_RT_GROUP_SCHED) || (defined(CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED) && \
 839                         (defined(CONFIG_SMP) || defined(CONFIG_CFS_BANDWIDTH)))
 840 /*
 841  * Iterate task_group tree rooted at *from, calling @down when first entering a
 842  * node and @up when leaving it for the final time.
 843  *
 844  * Caller must hold rcu_lock or sufficient equivalent.
 845  */
 846 int walk_tg_tree_from(struct task_group *from,
 847                              tg_visitor down, tg_visitor up, void *data)
 848 {
 849         struct task_group *parent, *child;
 850         int ret;
 851 
 852         parent = from;
 853 
 854 down:
 855         ret = (*down)(parent, data);
 856         if (ret)
 857                 goto out;
 858         list_for_each_entry_rcu(child, &parent->children, siblings) {
 859                 parent = child;
 860                 goto down;
 861 
 862 up:
 863                 continue;
 864         }
 865         ret = (*up)(parent, data);
 866         if (ret || parent == from)
 867                 goto out;
 868 
 869         child = parent;
 870         parent = parent->parent;
 871         if (parent)
 872                 goto up;
 873 out:
 874         return ret;
 875 }
 876 
 877 int tg_nop(struct task_group *tg, void *data)
 878 {
 879         return 0;
 880 }
 881 #endif
 882 
 883 static void set_load_weight(struct task_struct *p, bool update_load)
 884 {
 885         int prio = p->static_prio - MAX_RT_PRIO;
 886         struct load_weight *load = &p->se.load;
 887 
 888         /*
 889          * SCHED_IDLE tasks get minimal weight:
 890          */
 891         if (task_has_idle_policy(p)) {
 892                 load->weight = scale_load(WEIGHT_IDLEPRIO);
 893                 load->inv_weight = WMULT_IDLEPRIO;
 894                 return;
 895         }
 896 
 897         /*
 898          * SCHED_OTHER tasks have to update their load when changing their
 899          * weight
 900          */
 901         if (update_load && p->sched_class == &fair_sched_class) {
 902                 reweight_task(p, prio);
 903         } else {
 904                 load->weight = scale_load(sched_prio_to_weight[prio]);
 905                 load->inv_weight = sched_prio_to_wmult[prio];
 906         }
 907 }
 908 
 909 #ifdef CONFIG_UCLAMP_TASK
 910 /*
 911  * Serializes updates of utilization clamp values
 912  *
 913  * The (slow-path) user-space triggers utilization clamp value updates which
 914  * can require updates on (fast-path) scheduler's data structures used to
 915  * support enqueue/dequeue operations.
 916  * While the per-CPU rq lock protects fast-path update operations, user-space
 917  * requests are serialized using a mutex to reduce the risk of conflicting
 918  * updates or API abuses.
 919  */
 920 static DEFINE_MUTEX(uclamp_mutex);
 921 
 922 /* Max allowed minimum utilization */
 923 unsigned int sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min = SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE;
 924 
 925 /* Max allowed maximum utilization */
 926 unsigned int sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_max = SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE;
 927 
 928 /*
 929  * By default RT tasks run at the maximum performance point/capacity of the
 930  * system. Uclamp enforces this by always setting UCLAMP_MIN of RT tasks to
 931  * SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE.
 932  *
 933  * This knob allows admins to change the default behavior when uclamp is being
 934  * used. In battery powered devices, particularly, running at the maximum
 935  * capacity and frequency will increase energy consumption and shorten the
 936  * battery life.
 937  *
 938  * This knob only affects RT tasks that their uclamp_se->user_defined == false.
 939  *
 940  * This knob will not override the system default sched_util_clamp_min defined
 941  * above.
 942  */
 943 unsigned int sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min_rt_default = SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE;
 944 
 945 /* All clamps are required to be less or equal than these values */
 946 static struct uclamp_se uclamp_default[UCLAMP_CNT];
 947 
 948 /*
 949  * This static key is used to reduce the uclamp overhead in the fast path. It
 950  * primarily disables the call to uclamp_rq_{inc, dec}() in
 951  * enqueue/dequeue_task().
 952  *
 953  * This allows users to continue to enable uclamp in their kernel config with
 954  * minimum uclamp overhead in the fast path.
 955  *
 956  * As soon as userspace modifies any of the uclamp knobs, the static key is
 957  * enabled, since we have an actual users that make use of uclamp
 958  * functionality.
 959  *
 960  * The knobs that would enable this static key are:
 961  *
 962  *   * A task modifying its uclamp value with sched_setattr().
 963  *   * An admin modifying the sysctl_sched_uclamp_{min, max} via procfs.
 964  *   * An admin modifying the cgroup cpu.uclamp.{min, max}
 965  */
 966 DEFINE_STATIC_KEY_FALSE(sched_uclamp_used);
 967 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(sched_uclamp_used);
 968 
 969 /* Integer rounded range for each bucket */
 970 #define UCLAMP_BUCKET_DELTA DIV_ROUND_CLOSEST(SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE, UCLAMP_BUCKETS)
 971 
 972 #define for_each_clamp_id(clamp_id) \
 973         for ((clamp_id) = 0; (clamp_id) < UCLAMP_CNT; (clamp_id)++)
 974 
 975 static inline unsigned int uclamp_bucket_id(unsigned int clamp_value)
 976 {
 977         return min_t(unsigned int, clamp_value / UCLAMP_BUCKET_DELTA, UCLAMP_BUCKETS - 1);
 978 }
 979 
 980 static inline unsigned int uclamp_none(enum uclamp_id clamp_id)
 981 {
 982         if (clamp_id == UCLAMP_MIN)
 983                 return 0;
 984         return SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE;
 985 }
 986 
 987 static inline void uclamp_se_set(struct uclamp_se *uc_se,
 988                                  unsigned int value, bool user_defined)
 989 {
 990         uc_se->value = value;
 991         uc_se->bucket_id = uclamp_bucket_id(value);
 992         uc_se->user_defined = user_defined;
 993 }
 994 
 995 static inline unsigned int
 996 uclamp_idle_value(struct rq *rq, enum uclamp_id clamp_id,
 997                   unsigned int clamp_value)
 998 {
 999         /*
1000          * Avoid blocked utilization pushing up the frequency when we go
1001          * idle (which drops the max-clamp) by retaining the last known
1002          * max-clamp.
1003          */
1004         if (clamp_id == UCLAMP_MAX) {
1005                 rq->uclamp_flags |= UCLAMP_FLAG_IDLE;
1006                 return clamp_value;
1007         }
1008 
1009         return uclamp_none(UCLAMP_MIN);
1010 }
1011 
1012 static inline void uclamp_idle_reset(struct rq *rq, enum uclamp_id clamp_id,
1013                                      unsigned int clamp_value)
1014 {
1015         /* Reset max-clamp retention only on idle exit */
1016         if (!(rq->uclamp_flags & UCLAMP_FLAG_IDLE))
1017                 return;
1018 
1019         WRITE_ONCE(rq->uclamp[clamp_id].value, clamp_value);
1020 }
1021 
1022 static inline
1023 unsigned int uclamp_rq_max_value(struct rq *rq, enum uclamp_id clamp_id,
1024                                    unsigned int clamp_value)
1025 {
1026         struct uclamp_bucket *bucket = rq->uclamp[clamp_id].bucket;
1027         int bucket_id = UCLAMP_BUCKETS - 1;
1028 
1029         /*
1030          * Since both min and max clamps are max aggregated, find the
1031          * top most bucket with tasks in.
1032          */
1033         for ( ; bucket_id >= 0; bucket_id--) {
1034                 if (!bucket[bucket_id].tasks)
1035                         continue;
1036                 return bucket[bucket_id].value;
1037         }
1038 
1039         /* No tasks -- default clamp values */
1040         return uclamp_idle_value(rq, clamp_id, clamp_value);
1041 }
1042 
1043 static void __uclamp_update_util_min_rt_default(struct task_struct *p)
1044 {
1045         unsigned int default_util_min;
1046         struct uclamp_se *uc_se;
1047 
1048         lockdep_assert_held(&p->pi_lock);
1049 
1050         uc_se = &p->uclamp_req[UCLAMP_MIN];
1051 
1052         /* Only sync if user didn't override the default */
1053         if (uc_se->user_defined)
1054                 return;
1055 
1056         default_util_min = sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min_rt_default;
1057         uclamp_se_set(uc_se, default_util_min, false);
1058 }
1059 
1060 static void uclamp_update_util_min_rt_default(struct task_struct *p)
1061 {
1062         struct rq_flags rf;
1063         struct rq *rq;
1064 
1065         if (!rt_task(p))
1066                 return;
1067 
1068         /* Protect updates to p->uclamp_* */
1069         rq = task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
1070         __uclamp_update_util_min_rt_default(p);
1071         task_rq_unlock(rq, p, &rf);
1072 }
1073 
1074 static void uclamp_sync_util_min_rt_default(void)
1075 {
1076         struct task_struct *g, *p;
1077 
1078         /*
1079          * copy_process()                       sysctl_uclamp
1080          *                                        uclamp_min_rt = X;
1081          *   write_lock(&tasklist_lock)           read_lock(&tasklist_lock)
1082          *   // link thread                       smp_mb__after_spinlock()
1083          *   write_unlock(&tasklist_lock)         read_unlock(&tasklist_lock);
1084          *   sched_post_fork()                    for_each_process_thread()
1085          *     __uclamp_sync_rt()                   __uclamp_sync_rt()
1086          *
1087          * Ensures that either sched_post_fork() will observe the new
1088          * uclamp_min_rt or for_each_process_thread() will observe the new
1089          * task.
1090          */
1091         read_lock(&tasklist_lock);
1092         smp_mb__after_spinlock();
1093         read_unlock(&tasklist_lock);
1094 
1095         rcu_read_lock();
1096         for_each_process_thread(g, p)
1097                 uclamp_update_util_min_rt_default(p);
1098         rcu_read_unlock();
1099 }
1100 
1101 static inline struct uclamp_se
1102 uclamp_tg_restrict(struct task_struct *p, enum uclamp_id clamp_id)
1103 {
1104         struct uclamp_se uc_req = p->uclamp_req[clamp_id];
1105 #ifdef CONFIG_UCLAMP_TASK_GROUP
1106         struct uclamp_se uc_max;
1107 
1108         /*
1109          * Tasks in autogroups or root task group will be
1110          * restricted by system defaults.
1111          */
1112         if (task_group_is_autogroup(task_group(p)))
1113                 return uc_req;
1114         if (task_group(p) == &root_task_group)
1115                 return uc_req;
1116 
1117         uc_max = task_group(p)->uclamp[clamp_id];
1118         if (uc_req.value > uc_max.value || !uc_req.user_defined)
1119                 return uc_max;
1120 #endif
1121 
1122         return uc_req;
1123 }
1124 
1125 /*
1126  * The effective clamp bucket index of a task depends on, by increasing
1127  * priority:
1128  * - the task specific clamp value, when explicitly requested from userspace
1129  * - the task group effective clamp value, for tasks not either in the root
1130  *   group or in an autogroup
1131  * - the system default clamp value, defined by the sysadmin
1132  */
1133 static inline struct uclamp_se
1134 uclamp_eff_get(struct task_struct *p, enum uclamp_id clamp_id)
1135 {
1136         struct uclamp_se uc_req = uclamp_tg_restrict(p, clamp_id);
1137         struct uclamp_se uc_max = uclamp_default[clamp_id];
1138         struct uclamp_se uc_eff;
1139         int ret = 0;
1140 
1141         trace_android_rvh_uclamp_eff_get(p, clamp_id, &uc_max, &uc_eff, &ret);
1142         if (ret)
1143                 return uc_eff;
1144 
1145         /* System default restrictions always apply */
1146         if (unlikely(uc_req.value > uc_max.value))
1147                 return uc_max;
1148 
1149         return uc_req;
1150 }
1151 
1152 unsigned long uclamp_eff_value(struct task_struct *p, enum uclamp_id clamp_id)
1153 {
1154         struct uclamp_se uc_eff;
1155 
1156         /* Task currently refcounted: use back-annotated (effective) value */
1157         if (p->uclamp[clamp_id].active)
1158                 return (unsigned long)p->uclamp[clamp_id].value;
1159 
1160         uc_eff = uclamp_eff_get(p, clamp_id);
1161 
1162         return (unsigned long)uc_eff.value;
1163 }
1164 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(uclamp_eff_value);
1165 
1166 /*
1167  * When a task is enqueued on a rq, the clamp bucket currently defined by the
1168  * task's uclamp::bucket_id is refcounted on that rq. This also immediately
1169  * updates the rq's clamp value if required.
1170  *
1171  * Tasks can have a task-specific value requested from user-space, track
1172  * within each bucket the maximum value for tasks refcounted in it.
1173  * This "local max aggregation" allows to track the exact "requested" value
1174  * for each bucket when all its RUNNABLE tasks require the same clamp.
1175  */
1176 static inline void uclamp_rq_inc_id(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p,
1177                                     enum uclamp_id clamp_id)
1178 {
1179         struct uclamp_rq *uc_rq = &rq->uclamp[clamp_id];
1180         struct uclamp_se *uc_se = &p->uclamp[clamp_id];
1181         struct uclamp_bucket *bucket;
1182 
1183         lockdep_assert_held(&rq->lock);
1184 
1185         /* Update task effective clamp */
1186         p->uclamp[clamp_id] = uclamp_eff_get(p, clamp_id);
1187 
1188         bucket = &uc_rq->bucket[uc_se->bucket_id];
1189         bucket->tasks++;
1190         uc_se->active = true;
1191 
1192         uclamp_idle_reset(rq, clamp_id, uc_se->value);
1193 
1194         /*
1195          * Local max aggregation: rq buckets always track the max
1196          * "requested" clamp value of its RUNNABLE tasks.
1197          */
1198         if (bucket->tasks == 1 || uc_se->value > bucket->value)
1199                 bucket->value = uc_se->value;
1200 
1201         if (uc_se->value > READ_ONCE(uc_rq->value))
1202                 WRITE_ONCE(uc_rq->value, uc_se->value);
1203 }
1204 
1205 /*
1206  * When a task is dequeued from a rq, the clamp bucket refcounted by the task
1207  * is released. If this is the last task reference counting the rq's max
1208  * active clamp value, then the rq's clamp value is updated.
1209  *
1210  * Both refcounted tasks and rq's cached clamp values are expected to be
1211  * always valid. If it's detected they are not, as defensive programming,
1212  * enforce the expected state and warn.
1213  */
1214 static inline void uclamp_rq_dec_id(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p,
1215                                     enum uclamp_id clamp_id)
1216 {
1217         struct uclamp_rq *uc_rq = &rq->uclamp[clamp_id];
1218         struct uclamp_se *uc_se = &p->uclamp[clamp_id];
1219         struct uclamp_bucket *bucket;
1220         unsigned int bkt_clamp;
1221         unsigned int rq_clamp;
1222 
1223         lockdep_assert_held(&rq->lock);
1224 
1225         /*
1226          * If sched_uclamp_used was enabled after task @p was enqueued,
1227          * we could end up with unbalanced call to uclamp_rq_dec_id().
1228          *
1229          * In this case the uc_se->active flag should be false since no uclamp
1230          * accounting was performed at enqueue time and we can just return
1231          * here.
1232          *
1233          * Need to be careful of the following enqeueue/dequeue ordering
1234          * problem too
1235          *
1236          *      enqueue(taskA)
1237          *      // sched_uclamp_used gets enabled
1238          *      enqueue(taskB)
1239          *      dequeue(taskA)
1240          *      // Must not decrement bukcet->tasks here
1241          *      dequeue(taskB)
1242          *
1243          * where we could end up with stale data in uc_se and
1244          * bucket[uc_se->bucket_id].
1245          *
1246          * The following check here eliminates the possibility of such race.
1247          */
1248         if (unlikely(!uc_se->active))
1249                 return;
1250 
1251         bucket = &uc_rq->bucket[uc_se->bucket_id];
1252 
1253         SCHED_WARN_ON(!bucket->tasks);
1254         if (likely(bucket->tasks))
1255                 bucket->tasks--;
1256 
1257         uc_se->active = false;
1258 
1259         /*
1260          * Keep "local max aggregation" simple and accept to (possibly)
1261          * overboost some RUNNABLE tasks in the same bucket.
1262          * The rq clamp bucket value is reset to its base value whenever
1263          * there are no more RUNNABLE tasks refcounting it.
1264          */
1265         if (likely(bucket->tasks))
1266                 return;
1267 
1268         rq_clamp = READ_ONCE(uc_rq->value);
1269         /*
1270          * Defensive programming: this should never happen. If it happens,
1271          * e.g. due to future modification, warn and fixup the expected value.
1272          */
1273         SCHED_WARN_ON(bucket->value > rq_clamp);
1274         if (bucket->value >= rq_clamp) {
1275                 bkt_clamp = uclamp_rq_max_value(rq, clamp_id, uc_se->value);
1276                 WRITE_ONCE(uc_rq->value, bkt_clamp);
1277         }
1278 }
1279 
1280 static inline void uclamp_rq_inc(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
1281 {
1282         enum uclamp_id clamp_id;
1283 
1284         /*
1285          * Avoid any overhead until uclamp is actually used by the userspace.
1286          *
1287          * The condition is constructed such that a NOP is generated when
1288          * sched_uclamp_used is disabled.
1289          */
1290         if (!static_branch_unlikely(&sched_uclamp_used))
1291                 return;
1292 
1293         if (unlikely(!p->sched_class->uclamp_enabled))
1294                 return;
1295 
1296         for_each_clamp_id(clamp_id)
1297                 uclamp_rq_inc_id(rq, p, clamp_id);
1298 
1299         /* Reset clamp idle holding when there is one RUNNABLE task */
1300         if (rq->uclamp_flags & UCLAMP_FLAG_IDLE)
1301                 rq->uclamp_flags &= ~UCLAMP_FLAG_IDLE;
1302 }
1303 
1304 static inline void uclamp_rq_dec(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
1305 {
1306         enum uclamp_id clamp_id;
1307 
1308         /*
1309          * Avoid any overhead until uclamp is actually used by the userspace.
1310          *
1311          * The condition is constructed such that a NOP is generated when
1312          * sched_uclamp_used is disabled.
1313          */
1314         if (!static_branch_unlikely(&sched_uclamp_used))
1315                 return;
1316 
1317         if (unlikely(!p->sched_class->uclamp_enabled))
1318                 return;
1319 
1320         for_each_clamp_id(clamp_id)
1321                 uclamp_rq_dec_id(rq, p, clamp_id);
1322 }
1323 
1324 static inline void
1325 uclamp_update_active(struct task_struct *p, enum uclamp_id clamp_id)
1326 {
1327         struct rq_flags rf;
1328         struct rq *rq;
1329 
1330         /*
1331          * Lock the task and the rq where the task is (or was) queued.
1332          *
1333          * We might lock the (previous) rq of a !RUNNABLE task, but that's the
1334          * price to pay to safely serialize util_{min,max} updates with
1335          * enqueues, dequeues and migration operations.
1336          * This is the same locking schema used by __set_cpus_allowed_ptr().
1337          */
1338         rq = task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
1339 
1340         /*
1341          * Setting the clamp bucket is serialized by task_rq_lock().
1342          * If the task is not yet RUNNABLE and its task_struct is not
1343          * affecting a valid clamp bucket, the next time it's enqueued,
1344          * it will already see the updated clamp bucket value.
1345          */
1346         if (p->uclamp[clamp_id].active) {
1347                 uclamp_rq_dec_id(rq, p, clamp_id);
1348                 uclamp_rq_inc_id(rq, p, clamp_id);
1349         }
1350 
1351         task_rq_unlock(rq, p, &rf);
1352 }
1353 
1354 #ifdef CONFIG_UCLAMP_TASK_GROUP
1355 static inline void
1356 uclamp_update_active_tasks(struct cgroup_subsys_state *css,
1357                            unsigned int clamps)
1358 {
1359         enum uclamp_id clamp_id;
1360         struct css_task_iter it;
1361         struct task_struct *p;
1362 
1363         css_task_iter_start(css, 0, &it);
1364         while ((p = css_task_iter_next(&it))) {
1365                 for_each_clamp_id(clamp_id) {
1366                         if ((0x1 << clamp_id) & clamps)
1367                                 uclamp_update_active(p, clamp_id);
1368                 }
1369         }
1370         css_task_iter_end(&it);
1371 }
1372 
1373 static void cpu_util_update_eff(struct cgroup_subsys_state *css);
1374 static void uclamp_update_root_tg(void)
1375 {
1376         struct task_group *tg = &root_task_group;
1377 
1378         uclamp_se_set(&tg->uclamp_req[UCLAMP_MIN],
1379                       sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min, false);
1380         uclamp_se_set(&tg->uclamp_req[UCLAMP_MAX],
1381                       sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_max, false);
1382 
1383         rcu_read_lock();
1384         cpu_util_update_eff(&root_task_group.css);
1385         rcu_read_unlock();
1386 }
1387 #else
1388 static void uclamp_update_root_tg(void) { }
1389 #endif
1390 
1391 int sysctl_sched_uclamp_handler(struct ctl_table *table, int write,
1392                                 void *buffer, size_t *lenp, loff_t *ppos)
1393 {
1394         bool update_root_tg = false;
1395         int old_min, old_max, old_min_rt;
1396         int result;
1397 
1398         mutex_lock(&uclamp_mutex);
1399         old_min = sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min;
1400         old_max = sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_max;
1401         old_min_rt = sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min_rt_default;
1402 
1403         result = proc_dointvec(table, write, buffer, lenp, ppos);
1404         if (result)
1405                 goto undo;
1406         if (!write)
1407                 goto done;
1408 
1409         if (sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min > sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_max ||
1410             sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_max > SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE ||
1411             sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min_rt_default > SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE) {
1412 
1413                 result = -EINVAL;
1414                 goto undo;
1415         }
1416 
1417         if (old_min != sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min) {
1418                 uclamp_se_set(&uclamp_default[UCLAMP_MIN],
1419                               sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min, false);
1420                 update_root_tg = true;
1421         }
1422         if (old_max != sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_max) {
1423                 uclamp_se_set(&uclamp_default[UCLAMP_MAX],
1424                               sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_max, false);
1425                 update_root_tg = true;
1426         }
1427 
1428         if (update_root_tg) {
1429                 static_branch_enable(&sched_uclamp_used);
1430                 uclamp_update_root_tg();
1431         }
1432 
1433         if (old_min_rt != sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min_rt_default) {
1434                 static_branch_enable(&sched_uclamp_used);
1435                 uclamp_sync_util_min_rt_default();
1436         }
1437 
1438         /*
1439          * We update all RUNNABLE tasks only when task groups are in use.
1440          * Otherwise, keep it simple and do just a lazy update at each next
1441          * task enqueue time.
1442          */
1443 
1444         goto done;
1445 
1446 undo:
1447         sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min = old_min;
1448         sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_max = old_max;
1449         sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min_rt_default = old_min_rt;
1450 done:
1451         mutex_unlock(&uclamp_mutex);
1452 
1453         return result;
1454 }
1455 
1456 static int uclamp_validate(struct task_struct *p,
1457                            const struct sched_attr *attr)
1458 {
1459         int util_min = p->uclamp_req[UCLAMP_MIN].value;
1460         int util_max = p->uclamp_req[UCLAMP_MAX].value;
1461 
1462         if (attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP_MIN) {
1463                 util_min = attr->sched_util_min;
1464 
1465                 if (util_min + 1 > SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE + 1)
1466                         return -EINVAL;
1467         }
1468 
1469         if (attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP_MAX) {
1470                 util_max = attr->sched_util_max;
1471 
1472                 if (util_max + 1 > SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE + 1)
1473                         return -EINVAL;
1474         }
1475 
1476         if (util_min != -1 && util_max != -1 && util_min > util_max)
1477                 return -EINVAL;
1478 
1479         /*
1480          * We have valid uclamp attributes; make sure uclamp is enabled.
1481          *
1482          * We need to do that here, because enabling static branches is a
1483          * blocking operation which obviously cannot be done while holding
1484          * scheduler locks.
1485          */
1486         static_branch_enable(&sched_uclamp_used);
1487 
1488         return 0;
1489 }
1490 
1491 static bool uclamp_reset(const struct sched_attr *attr,
1492                          enum uclamp_id clamp_id,
1493                          struct uclamp_se *uc_se)
1494 {
1495         /* Reset on sched class change for a non user-defined clamp value. */
1496         if (likely(!(attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP)) &&
1497             !uc_se->user_defined)
1498                 return true;
1499 
1500         /* Reset on sched_util_{min,max} == -1. */
1501         if (clamp_id == UCLAMP_MIN &&
1502             attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP_MIN &&
1503             attr->sched_util_min == -1) {
1504                 return true;
1505         }
1506 
1507         if (clamp_id == UCLAMP_MAX &&
1508             attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP_MAX &&
1509             attr->sched_util_max == -1) {
1510                 return true;
1511         }
1512 
1513         return false;
1514 }
1515 
1516 static void __setscheduler_uclamp(struct task_struct *p,
1517                                   const struct sched_attr *attr)
1518 {
1519         enum uclamp_id clamp_id;
1520 
1521         for_each_clamp_id(clamp_id) {
1522                 struct uclamp_se *uc_se = &p->uclamp_req[clamp_id];
1523                 unsigned int value;
1524 
1525                 if (!uclamp_reset(attr, clamp_id, uc_se))
1526                         continue;
1527 
1528                 /*
1529                  * RT by default have a 100% boost value that could be modified
1530                  * at runtime.
1531                  */
1532                 if (unlikely(rt_task(p) && clamp_id == UCLAMP_MIN))
1533                         value = sysctl_sched_uclamp_util_min_rt_default;
1534                 else
1535                         value = uclamp_none(clamp_id);
1536 
1537                 uclamp_se_set(uc_se, value, false);
1538 
1539         }
1540 
1541         if (likely(!(attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP)))
1542                 return;
1543 
1544         if (attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP_MIN &&
1545             attr->sched_util_min != -1) {
1546                 uclamp_se_set(&p->uclamp_req[UCLAMP_MIN],
1547                               attr->sched_util_min, true);
1548         }
1549 
1550         if (attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP_MAX &&
1551             attr->sched_util_max != -1) {
1552                 uclamp_se_set(&p->uclamp_req[UCLAMP_MAX],
1553                               attr->sched_util_max, true);
1554         }
1555 }
1556 
1557 static void uclamp_fork(struct task_struct *p)
1558 {
1559         enum uclamp_id clamp_id;
1560 
1561         /*
1562          * We don't need to hold task_rq_lock() when updating p->uclamp_* here
1563          * as the task is still at its early fork stages.
1564          */
1565         for_each_clamp_id(clamp_id)
1566                 p->uclamp[clamp_id].active = false;
1567 
1568         if (likely(!p->sched_reset_on_fork))
1569                 return;
1570 
1571         for_each_clamp_id(clamp_id) {
1572                 uclamp_se_set(&p->uclamp_req[clamp_id],
1573                               uclamp_none(clamp_id), false);
1574         }
1575 }
1576 
1577 static void uclamp_post_fork(struct task_struct *p)
1578 {
1579         uclamp_update_util_min_rt_default(p);
1580 }
1581 
1582 static void __init init_uclamp_rq(struct rq *rq)
1583 {
1584         enum uclamp_id clamp_id;
1585         struct uclamp_rq *uc_rq = rq->uclamp;
1586 
1587         for_each_clamp_id(clamp_id) {
1588                 uc_rq[clamp_id] = (struct uclamp_rq) {
1589                         .value = uclamp_none(clamp_id)
1590                 };
1591         }
1592 
1593         rq->uclamp_flags = 0;
1594 }
1595 
1596 static void __init init_uclamp(void)
1597 {
1598         struct uclamp_se uc_max = {};
1599         enum uclamp_id clamp_id;
1600         int cpu;
1601 
1602         for_each_possible_cpu(cpu)
1603                 init_uclamp_rq(cpu_rq(cpu));
1604 
1605         for_each_clamp_id(clamp_id) {
1606                 uclamp_se_set(&init_task.uclamp_req[clamp_id],
1607                               uclamp_none(clamp_id), false);
1608         }
1609 
1610         /* System defaults allow max clamp values for both indexes */
1611         uclamp_se_set(&uc_max, uclamp_none(UCLAMP_MAX), false);
1612         for_each_clamp_id(clamp_id) {
1613                 uclamp_default[clamp_id] = uc_max;
1614 #ifdef CONFIG_UCLAMP_TASK_GROUP
1615                 root_task_group.uclamp_req[clamp_id] = uc_max;
1616                 root_task_group.uclamp[clamp_id] = uc_max;
1617 #endif
1618         }
1619 }
1620 
1621 #else /* CONFIG_UCLAMP_TASK */
1622 static inline void uclamp_rq_inc(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p) { }
1623 static inline void uclamp_rq_dec(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p) { }
1624 static inline int uclamp_validate(struct task_struct *p,
1625                                   const struct sched_attr *attr)
1626 {
1627         return -EOPNOTSUPP;
1628 }
1629 static void __setscheduler_uclamp(struct task_struct *p,
1630                                   const struct sched_attr *attr) { }
1631 static inline void uclamp_fork(struct task_struct *p) { }
1632 static inline void uclamp_post_fork(struct task_struct *p) { }
1633 static inline void init_uclamp(void) { }
1634 #endif /* CONFIG_UCLAMP_TASK */
1635 
1636 static inline void enqueue_task(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int flags)
1637 {
1638         if (!(flags & ENQUEUE_NOCLOCK))
1639                 update_rq_clock(rq);
1640 
1641         if (!(flags & ENQUEUE_RESTORE)) {
1642                 sched_info_queued(rq, p);
1643                 psi_enqueue(p, flags & ENQUEUE_WAKEUP);
1644         }
1645 
1646         uclamp_rq_inc(rq, p);
1647         trace_android_rvh_enqueue_task(rq, p, flags);
1648         p->sched_class->enqueue_task(rq, p, flags);
1649         trace_android_rvh_after_enqueue_task(rq, p);
1650 }
1651 
1652 static inline void dequeue_task(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int flags)
1653 {
1654         if (!(flags & DEQUEUE_NOCLOCK))
1655                 update_rq_clock(rq);
1656 
1657         if (!(flags & DEQUEUE_SAVE)) {
1658                 sched_info_dequeued(rq, p);
1659                 psi_dequeue(p, flags & DEQUEUE_SLEEP);
1660         }
1661 
1662         uclamp_rq_dec(rq, p);
1663         trace_android_rvh_dequeue_task(rq, p, flags);
1664         p->sched_class->dequeue_task(rq, p, flags);
1665         trace_android_rvh_after_dequeue_task(rq, p);
1666 }
1667 
1668 void activate_task(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int flags)
1669 {
1670         enqueue_task(rq, p, flags);
1671 
1672         p->on_rq = TASK_ON_RQ_QUEUED;
1673 }
1674 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(activate_task);
1675 
1676 void deactivate_task(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int flags)
1677 {
1678         p->on_rq = (flags & DEQUEUE_SLEEP) ? 0 : TASK_ON_RQ_MIGRATING;
1679 
1680         dequeue_task(rq, p, flags);
1681 }
1682 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(deactivate_task);
1683 
1684 /*
1685  * __normal_prio - return the priority that is based on the static prio
1686  */
1687 static inline int __normal_prio(struct task_struct *p)
1688 {
1689         return p->static_prio;
1690 }
1691 
1692 /*
1693  * Calculate the expected normal priority: i.e. priority
1694  * without taking RT-inheritance into account. Might be
1695  * boosted by interactivity modifiers. Changes upon fork,
1696  * setprio syscalls, and whenever the interactivity
1697  * estimator recalculates.
1698  */
1699 static inline int normal_prio(struct task_struct *p)
1700 {
1701         int prio;
1702 
1703         if (task_has_dl_policy(p))
1704                 prio = MAX_DL_PRIO-1;
1705         else if (task_has_rt_policy(p))
1706                 prio = MAX_RT_PRIO-1 - p->rt_priority;
1707         else
1708                 prio = __normal_prio(p);
1709         return prio;
1710 }
1711 
1712 /*
1713  * Calculate the current priority, i.e. the priority
1714  * taken into account by the scheduler. This value might
1715  * be boosted by RT tasks, or might be boosted by
1716  * interactivity modifiers. Will be RT if the task got
1717  * RT-boosted. If not then it returns p->normal_prio.
1718  */
1719 static int effective_prio(struct task_struct *p)
1720 {
1721         p->normal_prio = normal_prio(p);
1722         /*
1723          * If we are RT tasks or we were boosted to RT priority,
1724          * keep the priority unchanged. Otherwise, update priority
1725          * to the normal priority:
1726          */
1727         if (!rt_prio(p->prio))
1728                 return p->normal_prio;
1729         return p->prio;
1730 }
1731 
1732 /**
1733  * task_curr - is this task currently executing on a CPU?
1734  * @p: the task in question.
1735  *
1736  * Return: 1 if the task is currently executing. 0 otherwise.
1737  */
1738 inline int task_curr(const struct task_struct *p)
1739 {
1740         return cpu_curr(task_cpu(p)) == p;
1741 }
1742 
1743 /*
1744  * switched_from, switched_to and prio_changed must _NOT_ drop rq->lock,
1745  * use the balance_callback list if you want balancing.
1746  *
1747  * this means any call to check_class_changed() must be followed by a call to
1748  * balance_callback().
1749  */
1750 static inline void check_class_changed(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p,
1751                                        const struct sched_class *prev_class,
1752                                        int oldprio)
1753 {
1754         if (prev_class != p->sched_class) {
1755                 if (prev_class->switched_from)
1756                         prev_class->switched_from(rq, p);
1757 
1758                 p->sched_class->switched_to(rq, p);
1759         } else if (oldprio != p->prio || dl_task(p))
1760                 p->sched_class->prio_changed(rq, p, oldprio);
1761 }
1762 
1763 void check_preempt_curr(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int flags)
1764 {
1765         if (p->sched_class == rq->curr->sched_class)
1766                 rq->curr->sched_class->check_preempt_curr(rq, p, flags);
1767         else if (p->sched_class > rq->curr->sched_class)
1768                 resched_curr(rq);
1769 
1770         /*
1771          * A queue event has occurred, and we're going to schedule.  In
1772          * this case, we can save a useless back to back clock update.
1773          */
1774         if (task_on_rq_queued(rq->curr) && test_tsk_need_resched(rq->curr))
1775                 rq_clock_skip_update(rq);
1776 }
1777 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(check_preempt_curr);
1778 
1779 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
1780 
1781 /*
1782  * Per-CPU kthreads are allowed to run on !active && online CPUs, see
1783  * __set_cpus_allowed_ptr() and select_fallback_rq().
1784  */
1785 static inline bool is_cpu_allowed(struct task_struct *p, int cpu)
1786 {
1787         if (!cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, p->cpus_ptr))
1788                 return false;
1789 
1790         if (is_per_cpu_kthread(p))
1791                 return cpu_online(cpu);
1792 
1793         if (!cpu_active(cpu))
1794                 return false;
1795 
1796         return cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, task_cpu_possible_mask(p));
1797 }
1798 
1799 /*
1800  * This is how migration works:
1801  *
1802  * 1) we invoke migration_cpu_stop() on the target CPU using
1803  *    stop_one_cpu().
1804  * 2) stopper starts to run (implicitly forcing the migrated thread
1805  *    off the CPU)
1806  * 3) it checks whether the migrated task is still in the wrong runqueue.
1807  * 4) if it's in the wrong runqueue then the migration thread removes
1808  *    it and puts it into the right queue.
1809  * 5) stopper completes and stop_one_cpu() returns and the migration
1810  *    is done.
1811  */
1812 
1813 /*
1814  * move_queued_task - move a queued task to new rq.
1815  *
1816  * Returns (locked) new rq. Old rq's lock is released.
1817  */
1818 static struct rq *move_queued_task(struct rq *rq, struct rq_flags *rf,
1819                                    struct task_struct *p, int new_cpu)
1820 {
1821         int detached = 0;
1822 
1823         lockdep_assert_held(&rq->lock);
1824 
1825         /*
1826          * The vendor hook may drop the lock temporarily, so
1827          * pass the rq flags to unpin lock. We expect the
1828          * rq lock to be held after return.
1829          */
1830         trace_android_rvh_migrate_queued_task(rq, rf, p, new_cpu, &detached);
1831         if (detached)
1832                 goto attach;
1833 
1834         deactivate_task(rq, p, DEQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
1835         set_task_cpu(p, new_cpu);
1836 
1837 attach:
1838         rq_unlock(rq, rf);
1839         rq = cpu_rq(new_cpu);
1840 
1841         rq_lock(rq, rf);
1842         BUG_ON(task_cpu(p) != new_cpu);
1843         activate_task(rq, p, 0);
1844         check_preempt_curr(rq, p, 0);
1845 
1846         return rq;
1847 }
1848 
1849 struct migration_arg {
1850         struct task_struct *task;
1851         int dest_cpu;
1852 };
1853 
1854 /*
1855  * Move (not current) task off this CPU, onto the destination CPU. We're doing
1856  * this because either it can't run here any more (set_cpus_allowed()
1857  * away from this CPU, or CPU going down), or because we're
1858  * attempting to rebalance this task on exec (sched_exec).
1859  *
1860  * So we race with normal scheduler movements, but that's OK, as long
1861  * as the task is no longer on this CPU.
1862  */
1863 static struct rq *__migrate_task(struct rq *rq, struct rq_flags *rf,
1864                                  struct task_struct *p, int dest_cpu)
1865 {
1866         /* Affinity changed (again). */
1867         if (!is_cpu_allowed(p, dest_cpu))
1868                 return rq;
1869 
1870         update_rq_clock(rq);
1871         rq = move_queued_task(rq, rf, p, dest_cpu);
1872 
1873         return rq;
1874 }
1875 
1876 /*
1877  * migration_cpu_stop - this will be executed by a highprio stopper thread
1878  * and performs thread migration by bumping thread off CPU then
1879  * 'pushing' onto another runqueue.
1880  */
1881 static int migration_cpu_stop(void *data)
1882 {
1883         struct migration_arg *arg = data;
1884         struct task_struct *p = arg->task;
1885         struct rq *rq = this_rq();
1886         struct rq_flags rf;
1887 
1888         /*
1889          * The original target CPU might have gone down and we might
1890          * be on another CPU but it doesn't matter.
1891          */
1892         local_irq_disable();
1893         /*
1894          * We need to explicitly wake pending tasks before running
1895          * __migrate_task() such that we will not miss enforcing cpus_ptr
1896          * during wakeups, see set_cpus_allowed_ptr()'s TASK_WAKING test.
1897          */
1898         flush_smp_call_function_from_idle();
1899 
1900         raw_spin_lock(&p->pi_lock);
1901         rq_lock(rq, &rf);
1902         /*
1903          * If task_rq(p) != rq, it cannot be migrated here, because we're
1904          * holding rq->lock, if p->on_rq == 0 it cannot get enqueued because
1905          * we're holding p->pi_lock.
1906          */
1907         if (task_rq(p) == rq) {
1908                 if (task_on_rq_queued(p))
1909                         rq = __migrate_task(rq, &rf, p, arg->dest_cpu);
1910                 else
1911                         p->wake_cpu = arg->dest_cpu;
1912         }
1913         rq_unlock(rq, &rf);
1914         raw_spin_unlock(&p->pi_lock);
1915 
1916         local_irq_enable();
1917         return 0;
1918 }
1919 
1920 /*
1921  * sched_class::set_cpus_allowed must do the below, but is not required to
1922  * actually call this function.
1923  */
1924 void set_cpus_allowed_common(struct task_struct *p, const struct cpumask *new_mask)
1925 {
1926         cpumask_copy(&p->cpus_mask, new_mask);
1927         p->nr_cpus_allowed = cpumask_weight(new_mask);
1928         trace_android_rvh_set_cpus_allowed_comm(p, new_mask);
1929 }
1930 
1931 void do_set_cpus_allowed(struct task_struct *p, const struct cpumask *new_mask)
1932 {
1933         struct rq *rq = task_rq(p);
1934         bool queued, running;
1935 
1936         lockdep_assert_held(&p->pi_lock);
1937 
1938         queued = task_on_rq_queued(p);
1939         running = task_current(rq, p);
1940 
1941         if (queued) {
1942                 /*
1943                  * Because __kthread_bind() calls this on blocked tasks without
1944                  * holding rq->lock.
1945                  */
1946                 lockdep_assert_held(&rq->lock);
1947                 dequeue_task(rq, p, DEQUEUE_SAVE | DEQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
1948         }
1949         if (running)
1950                 put_prev_task(rq, p);
1951 
1952         p->sched_class->set_cpus_allowed(p, new_mask);
1953 
1954         if (queued)
1955                 enqueue_task(rq, p, ENQUEUE_RESTORE | ENQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
1956         if (running)
1957                 set_next_task(rq, p);
1958 }
1959 
1960 /*
1961  * Called with both p->pi_lock and rq->lock held; drops both before returning.
1962  */
1963 static int __set_cpus_allowed_ptr_locked(struct task_struct *p,
1964                                          const struct cpumask *new_mask,
1965                                          bool check,
1966                                          struct rq *rq,
1967                                          struct rq_flags *rf)
1968 {
1969         const struct cpumask *cpu_valid_mask = cpu_active_mask;
1970         const struct cpumask *cpu_allowed_mask = task_cpu_possible_mask(p);
1971         unsigned int dest_cpu;
1972         int ret = 0;
1973 
1974         update_rq_clock(rq);
1975 
1976         if (p->flags & PF_KTHREAD) {
1977                 /*
1978                  * Kernel threads are allowed on online && !active CPUs
1979                  */
1980                 cpu_valid_mask = cpu_online_mask;
1981         } else if (!cpumask_subset(new_mask, cpu_allowed_mask)) {
1982                 ret = -EINVAL;
1983                 goto out;
1984         }
1985 
1986         /*
1987          * Must re-check here, to close a race against __kthread_bind(),
1988          * sched_setaffinity() is not guaranteed to observe the flag.
1989          */
1990         if (check && (p->flags & PF_NO_SETAFFINITY)) {
1991                 ret = -EINVAL;
1992                 goto out;
1993         }
1994 
1995         if (cpumask_equal(&p->cpus_mask, new_mask))
1996                 goto out;
1997 
1998         /*
1999          * Picking a ~random cpu helps in cases where we are changing affinity
2000          * for groups of tasks (ie. cpuset), so that load balancing is not
2001          * immediately required to distribute the tasks within their new mask.
2002          */
2003         dest_cpu = cpumask_any_and_distribute(cpu_valid_mask, new_mask);
2004         if (dest_cpu >= nr_cpu_ids) {
2005                 ret = -EINVAL;
2006                 goto out;
2007         }
2008 
2009         do_set_cpus_allowed(p, new_mask);
2010 
2011         if (p->flags & PF_KTHREAD) {
2012                 /*
2013                  * For kernel threads that do indeed end up on online &&
2014                  * !active we want to ensure they are strict per-CPU threads.
2015                  */
2016                 WARN_ON(cpumask_intersects(new_mask, cpu_online_mask) &&
2017                         !cpumask_intersects(new_mask, cpu_active_mask) &&
2018                         p->nr_cpus_allowed != 1);
2019         }
2020 
2021         /* Can the task run on the task's current CPU? If so, we're done */
2022         if (cpumask_test_cpu(task_cpu(p), new_mask))
2023                 goto out;
2024 
2025         if (task_running(rq, p) || p->state == TASK_WAKING) {
2026                 struct migration_arg arg = { p, dest_cpu };
2027                 /* Need help from migration thread: drop lock and wait. */
2028                 task_rq_unlock(rq, p, rf);
2029                 stop_one_cpu(cpu_of(rq), migration_cpu_stop, &arg);
2030                 return 0;
2031         } else if (task_on_rq_queued(p)) {
2032                 /*
2033                  * OK, since we're going to drop the lock immediately
2034                  * afterwards anyway.
2035                  */
2036                 rq = move_queued_task(rq, rf, p, dest_cpu);
2037         }
2038 out:
2039         task_rq_unlock(rq, p, rf);
2040 
2041         return ret;
2042 }
2043 
2044 /*
2045  * Change a given task's CPU affinity. Migrate the thread to a
2046  * proper CPU and schedule it away if the CPU it's executing on
2047  * is removed from the allowed bitmask.
2048  *
2049  * NOTE: the caller must have a valid reference to the task, the
2050  * task must not exit() & deallocate itself prematurely. The
2051  * call is not atomic; no spinlocks may be held.
2052  */
2053 static int __set_cpus_allowed_ptr(struct task_struct *p,
2054                                   const struct cpumask *new_mask, bool check)
2055 {
2056         struct rq_flags rf;
2057         struct rq *rq;
2058 
2059         rq = task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
2060         return __set_cpus_allowed_ptr_locked(p, new_mask, check, rq, &rf);
2061 }
2062 
2063 int set_cpus_allowed_ptr(struct task_struct *p, const struct cpumask *new_mask)
2064 {
2065         return __set_cpus_allowed_ptr(p, new_mask, false);
2066 }
2067 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(set_cpus_allowed_ptr);
2068 
2069 /*
2070  * Change a given task's CPU affinity to the intersection of its current
2071  * affinity mask and @subset_mask, writing the resulting mask to @new_mask.
2072  * If the resulting mask is empty, leave the affinity unchanged and return
2073  * -EINVAL.
2074  */
2075 static int restrict_cpus_allowed_ptr(struct task_struct *p,
2076                                      struct cpumask *new_mask,
2077                                      const struct cpumask *subset_mask)
2078 {
2079         struct rq_flags rf;
2080         struct rq *rq;
2081 
2082         rq = task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
2083         if (!cpumask_and(new_mask, &p->cpus_mask, subset_mask)) {
2084                 task_rq_unlock(rq, p, &rf);
2085                 return -EINVAL;
2086         }
2087 
2088         return __set_cpus_allowed_ptr_locked(p, new_mask, false, rq, &rf);
2089 }
2090 
2091 /*
2092  * Restrict a given task's CPU affinity so that it is a subset of
2093  * task_cpu_possible_mask(). If the resulting mask is empty, we warn and
2094  * walk up the cpuset hierarchy until we find a suitable mask.
2095  */
2096 void force_compatible_cpus_allowed_ptr(struct task_struct *p)
2097 {
2098         cpumask_var_t new_mask;
2099         const struct cpumask *override_mask = task_cpu_possible_mask(p);
2100 
2101         alloc_cpumask_var(&new_mask, GFP_KERNEL);
2102 
2103         /*
2104          * __migrate_task() can fail silently in the face of concurrent
2105          * offlining of the chosen destination CPU, so take the hotplug
2106          * lock to ensure that the migration succeeds.
2107          */
2108         trace_android_vh_force_compatible_pre(NULL);
2109         cpus_read_lock();
2110         if (!cpumask_available(new_mask))
2111                 goto out_set_mask;
2112 
2113         if (!restrict_cpus_allowed_ptr(p, new_mask, override_mask))
2114                 goto out_free_mask;
2115 
2116         /*
2117          * We failed to find a valid subset of the affinity mask for the
2118          * task, so override it based on its cpuset hierarchy.
2119          */
2120         cpuset_cpus_allowed(p, new_mask);
2121         override_mask = new_mask;
2122 
2123 out_set_mask:
2124         if (printk_ratelimit()) {
2125                 printk_deferred("Overriding affinity for process %d (%s) to CPUs %*pbl\n",
2126                                 task_pid_nr(p), p->comm,
2127                                 cpumask_pr_args(override_mask));
2128         }
2129 
2130         WARN_ON(set_cpus_allowed_ptr(p, override_mask));
2131 out_free_mask:
2132         cpus_read_unlock();
2133         trace_android_vh_force_compatible_post(NULL);
2134         free_cpumask_var(new_mask);
2135 }
2136 
2137 void set_task_cpu(struct task_struct *p, unsigned int new_cpu)
2138 {
2139 #ifdef CONFIG_SCHED_DEBUG
2140         /*
2141          * We should never call set_task_cpu() on a blocked task,
2142          * ttwu() will sort out the placement.
2143          */
2144         WARN_ON_ONCE(p->state != TASK_RUNNING && p->state != TASK_WAKING &&
2145                         !p->on_rq);
2146 
2147         /*
2148          * Migrating fair class task must have p->on_rq = TASK_ON_RQ_MIGRATING,
2149          * because schedstat_wait_{start,end} rebase migrating task's wait_start
2150          * time relying on p->on_rq.
2151          */
2152         WARN_ON_ONCE(p->state == TASK_RUNNING &&
2153                      p->sched_class == &fair_sched_class &&
2154                      (p->on_rq && !task_on_rq_migrating(p)));
2155 
2156 #ifdef CONFIG_LOCKDEP
2157         /*
2158          * The caller should hold either p->pi_lock or rq->lock, when changing
2159          * a task's CPU. ->pi_lock for waking tasks, rq->lock for runnable tasks.
2160          *
2161          * sched_move_task() holds both and thus holding either pins the cgroup,
2162          * see task_group().
2163          *
2164          * Furthermore, all task_rq users should acquire both locks, see
2165          * task_rq_lock().
2166          */
2167         WARN_ON_ONCE(debug_locks && !(lockdep_is_held(&p->pi_lock) ||
2168                                       lockdep_is_held(&task_rq(p)->lock)));
2169 #endif
2170         /*
2171          * Clearly, migrating tasks to offline CPUs is a fairly daft thing.
2172          */
2173         WARN_ON_ONCE(!cpu_online(new_cpu));
2174 #endif
2175 
2176         trace_sched_migrate_task(p, new_cpu);
2177 
2178         if (task_cpu(p) != new_cpu) {
2179                 if (p->sched_class->migrate_task_rq)
2180                         p->sched_class->migrate_task_rq(p, new_cpu);
2181                 p->se.nr_migrations++;
2182                 rseq_migrate(p);
2183                 perf_event_task_migrate(p);
2184                 trace_android_rvh_set_task_cpu(p, new_cpu);
2185         }
2186 
2187         __set_task_cpu(p, new_cpu);
2188 }
2189 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(set_task_cpu);
2190 
2191 static void __migrate_swap_task(struct task_struct *p, int cpu)
2192 {
2193         if (task_on_rq_queued(p)) {
2194                 struct rq *src_rq, *dst_rq;
2195                 struct rq_flags srf, drf;
2196 
2197                 src_rq = task_rq(p);
2198                 dst_rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
2199 
2200                 rq_pin_lock(src_rq, &srf);
2201                 rq_pin_lock(dst_rq, &drf);
2202 
2203                 deactivate_task(src_rq, p, 0);
2204                 set_task_cpu(p, cpu);
2205                 activate_task(dst_rq, p, 0);
2206                 check_preempt_curr(dst_rq, p, 0);
2207 
2208                 rq_unpin_lock(dst_rq, &drf);
2209                 rq_unpin_lock(src_rq, &srf);
2210 
2211         } else {
2212                 /*
2213                  * Task isn't running anymore; make it appear like we migrated
