2214                  * it before it went to sleep. This means on wakeup we make the
2215                  * previous CPU our target instead of where it really is.
2216                  */
2217                 p->wake_cpu = cpu;
2218         }
2219 }
2220 
2221 struct migration_swap_arg {
2222         struct task_struct *src_task, *dst_task;
2223         int src_cpu, dst_cpu;
2224 };
2225 
2226 static int migrate_swap_stop(void *data)
2227 {
2228         struct migration_swap_arg *arg = data;
2229         struct rq *src_rq, *dst_rq;
2230         int ret = -EAGAIN;
2231 
2232         if (!cpu_active(arg->src_cpu) || !cpu_active(arg->dst_cpu))
2233                 return -EAGAIN;
2234 
2235         src_rq = cpu_rq(arg->src_cpu);
2236         dst_rq = cpu_rq(arg->dst_cpu);
2237 
2238         double_raw_lock(&arg->src_task->pi_lock,
2239                         &arg->dst_task->pi_lock);
2240         double_rq_lock(src_rq, dst_rq);
2241 
2242         if (task_cpu(arg->dst_task) != arg->dst_cpu)
2243                 goto unlock;
2244 
2245         if (task_cpu(arg->src_task) != arg->src_cpu)
2246                 goto unlock;
2247 
2248         if (!cpumask_test_cpu(arg->dst_cpu, arg->src_task->cpus_ptr))
2249                 goto unlock;
2250 
2251         if (!cpumask_test_cpu(arg->src_cpu, arg->dst_task->cpus_ptr))
2252                 goto unlock;
2253 
2254         __migrate_swap_task(arg->src_task, arg->dst_cpu);
2255         __migrate_swap_task(arg->dst_task, arg->src_cpu);
2256 
2257         ret = 0;
2258 
2259 unlock:
2260         double_rq_unlock(src_rq, dst_rq);
2261         raw_spin_unlock(&arg->dst_task->pi_lock);
2262         raw_spin_unlock(&arg->src_task->pi_lock);
2263 
2264         return ret;
2265 }
2266 
2267 /*
2268  * Cross migrate two tasks
2269  */
2270 int migrate_swap(struct task_struct *cur, struct task_struct *p,
2271                 int target_cpu, int curr_cpu)
2272 {
2273         struct migration_swap_arg arg;
2274         int ret = -EINVAL;
2275 
2276         arg = (struct migration_swap_arg){
2277                 .src_task = cur,
2278                 .src_cpu = curr_cpu,
2279                 .dst_task = p,
2280                 .dst_cpu = target_cpu,
2281         };
2282 
2283         if (arg.src_cpu == arg.dst_cpu)
2284                 goto out;
2285 
2286         /*
2287          * These three tests are all lockless; this is OK since all of them
2288          * will be re-checked with proper locks held further down the line.
2289          */
2290         if (!cpu_active(arg.src_cpu) || !cpu_active(arg.dst_cpu))
2291                 goto out;
2292 
2293         if (!cpumask_test_cpu(arg.dst_cpu, arg.src_task->cpus_ptr))
2294                 goto out;
2295 
2296         if (!cpumask_test_cpu(arg.src_cpu, arg.dst_task->cpus_ptr))
2297                 goto out;
2298 
2299         trace_sched_swap_numa(cur, arg.src_cpu, p, arg.dst_cpu);
2300         ret = stop_two_cpus(arg.dst_cpu, arg.src_cpu, migrate_swap_stop, &arg);
2301 
2302 out:
2303         return ret;
2304 }
2305 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(migrate_swap);
2306 
2307 /*
2308  * wait_task_inactive - wait for a thread to unschedule.
2309  *
2310  * If @match_state is nonzero, it's the @p->state value just checked and
2311  * not expected to change.  If it changes, i.e. @p might have woken up,
2312  * then return zero.  When we succeed in waiting for @p to be off its CPU,
2313  * we return a positive number (its total switch count).  If a second call
2314  * a short while later returns the same number, the caller can be sure that
2315  * @p has remained unscheduled the whole time.
2316  *
2317  * The caller must ensure that the task *will* unschedule sometime soon,
2318  * else this function might spin for a *long* time. This function can't
2319  * be called with interrupts off, or it may introduce deadlock with
2320  * smp_call_function() if an IPI is sent by the same process we are
2321  * waiting to become inactive.
2322  */
2323 unsigned long wait_task_inactive(struct task_struct *p, long match_state)
2324 {
2325         int running, queued;
2326         struct rq_flags rf;
2327         unsigned long ncsw;
2328         struct rq *rq;
2329 
2330         for (;;) {
2331                 /*
2332                  * We do the initial early heuristics without holding
2333                  * any task-queue locks at all. We'll only try to get
2334                  * the runqueue lock when things look like they will
2335                  * work out!
2336                  */
2337                 rq = task_rq(p);
2338 
2339                 /*
2340                  * If the task is actively running on another CPU
2341                  * still, just relax and busy-wait without holding
2342                  * any locks.
2343                  *
2344                  * NOTE! Since we don't hold any locks, it's not
2345                  * even sure that "rq" stays as the right runqueue!
2346                  * But we don't care, since "task_running()" will
2347                  * return false if the runqueue has changed and p
2348                  * is actually now running somewhere else!
2349                  */
2350                 while (task_running(rq, p)) {
2351                         if (match_state && unlikely(p->state != match_state))
2352                                 return 0;
2353                         cpu_relax();
2354                 }
2355 
2356                 /*
2357                  * Ok, time to look more closely! We need the rq
2358                  * lock now, to be *sure*. If we're wrong, we'll
2359                  * just go back and repeat.
2360                  */
2361                 rq = task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
2362                 trace_sched_wait_task(p);
2363                 running = task_running(rq, p);
2364                 queued = task_on_rq_queued(p);
2365                 ncsw = 0;
2366                 if (!match_state || p->state == match_state)
2367                         ncsw = p->nvcsw | LONG_MIN; /* sets MSB */
2368                 task_rq_unlock(rq, p, &rf);
2369 
2370                 /*
2371                  * If it changed from the expected state, bail out now.
2372                  */
2373                 if (unlikely(!ncsw))
2374                         break;
2375 
2376                 /*
2377                  * Was it really running after all now that we
2378                  * checked with the proper locks actually held?
2379                  *
2380                  * Oops. Go back and try again..
2381                  */
2382                 if (unlikely(running)) {
2383                         cpu_relax();
2384                         continue;
2385                 }
2386 
2387                 /*
2388                  * It's not enough that it's not actively running,
2389                  * it must be off the runqueue _entirely_, and not
2390                  * preempted!
2391                  *
2392                  * So if it was still runnable (but just not actively
2393                  * running right now), it's preempted, and we should
2394                  * yield - it could be a while.
2395                  */
2396                 if (unlikely(queued)) {
2397                         ktime_t to = NSEC_PER_SEC / HZ;
2398 
2399                         set_current_state(TASK_UNINTERRUPTIBLE);
2400                         schedule_hrtimeout(&to, HRTIMER_MODE_REL);
2401                         continue;
2402                 }
2403 
2404                 /*
2405                  * Ahh, all good. It wasn't running, and it wasn't
2406                  * runnable, which means that it will never become
2407                  * running in the future either. We're all done!
2408                  */
2409                 break;
2410         }
2411 
2412         return ncsw;
2413 }
2414 
2415 /***
2416  * kick_process - kick a running thread to enter/exit the kernel
2417  * @p: the to-be-kicked thread
2418  *
2419  * Cause a process which is running on another CPU to enter
2420  * kernel-mode, without any delay. (to get signals handled.)
2421  *
2422  * NOTE: this function doesn't have to take the runqueue lock,
2423  * because all it wants to ensure is that the remote task enters
2424  * the kernel. If the IPI races and the task has been migrated
2425  * to another CPU then no harm is done and the purpose has been
2426  * achieved as well.
2427  */
2428 void kick_process(struct task_struct *p)
2429 {
2430         int cpu;
2431 
2432         preempt_disable();
2433         cpu = task_cpu(p);
2434         if ((cpu != smp_processor_id()) && task_curr(p))
2435                 smp_send_reschedule(cpu);
2436         preempt_enable();
2437 }
2438 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(kick_process);
2439 
2440 /*
2441  * ->cpus_ptr is protected by both rq->lock and p->pi_lock
2442  *
2443  * A few notes on cpu_active vs cpu_online:
2444  *
2445  *  - cpu_active must be a subset of cpu_online
2446  *
2447  *  - on CPU-up we allow per-CPU kthreads on the online && !active CPU,
2448  *    see __set_cpus_allowed_ptr(). At this point the newly online
2449  *    CPU isn't yet part of the sched domains, and balancing will not
2450  *    see it.
2451  *
2452  *  - on CPU-down we clear cpu_active() to mask the sched domains and
2453  *    avoid the load balancer to place new tasks on the to be removed
2454  *    CPU. Existing tasks will remain running there and will be taken
2455  *    off.
2456  *
2457  * This means that fallback selection must not select !active CPUs.
2458  * And can assume that any active CPU must be online. Conversely
2459  * select_task_rq() below may allow selection of !active CPUs in order
2460  * to satisfy the above rules.
2461  */
2462 static int select_fallback_rq(int cpu, struct task_struct *p)
2463 {
2464         int nid = cpu_to_node(cpu);
2465         const struct cpumask *nodemask = NULL;
2466         enum { cpuset, possible, fail } state = cpuset;
2467         int dest_cpu = -1;
2468 
2469         trace_android_rvh_select_fallback_rq(cpu, p, &dest_cpu);
2470         if (dest_cpu >= 0)
2471                 return dest_cpu;
2472 
2473         /*
2474          * If the node that the CPU is on has been offlined, cpu_to_node()
2475          * will return -1. There is no CPU on the node, and we should
2476          * select the CPU on the other node.
2477          */
2478         if (nid != -1) {
2479                 nodemask = cpumask_of_node(nid);
2480 
2481                 /* Look for allowed, online CPU in same node. */
2482                 for_each_cpu(dest_cpu, nodemask) {
2483                         if (!cpu_active(dest_cpu))
2484                                 continue;
2485                         if (cpumask_test_cpu(dest_cpu, p->cpus_ptr))
2486                                 return dest_cpu;
2487                 }
2488         }
2489 
2490         for (;;) {
2491                 /* Any allowed, online CPU? */
2492                 for_each_cpu(dest_cpu, p->cpus_ptr) {
2493                         if (!is_cpu_allowed(p, dest_cpu))
2494                                 continue;
2495 
2496                         goto out;
2497                 }
2498 
2499                 /* No more Mr. Nice Guy. */
2500                 switch (state) {
2501                 case cpuset:
2502                         if (IS_ENABLED(CONFIG_CPUSETS)) {
2503                                 cpuset_cpus_allowed_fallback(p);
2504                                 state = possible;
2505                                 break;
2506                         }
2507                         fallthrough;
2508                 case possible:
2509                         do_set_cpus_allowed(p, task_cpu_possible_mask(p));
2510                         state = fail;
2511                         break;
2512                 case fail:
2513                         BUG();
2514                         break;
2515                 }
2516         }
2517 
2518 out:
2519         if (state != cpuset) {
2520                 /*
2521                  * Don't tell them about moving exiting tasks or
2522                  * kernel threads (both mm NULL), since they never
2523                  * leave kernel.
2524                  */
2525                 if (p->mm && printk_ratelimit()) {
2526                         printk_deferred("process %d (%s) no longer affine to cpu%d\n",
2527                                         task_pid_nr(p), p->comm, cpu);
2528                 }
2529         }
2530 
2531         return dest_cpu;
2532 }
2533 
2534 /*
2535  * The caller (fork, wakeup) owns p->pi_lock, ->cpus_ptr is stable.
2536  */
2537 static inline
2538 int select_task_rq(struct task_struct *p, int cpu, int sd_flags, int wake_flags)
2539 {
2540         lockdep_assert_held(&p->pi_lock);
2541 
2542         if (p->nr_cpus_allowed > 1)
2543                 cpu = p->sched_class->select_task_rq(p, cpu, sd_flags, wake_flags);
2544         else
2545                 cpu = cpumask_any(p->cpus_ptr);
2546 
2547         /*
2548          * In order not to call set_task_cpu() on a blocking task we need
2549          * to rely on ttwu() to place the task on a valid ->cpus_ptr
2550          * CPU.
2551          *
2552          * Since this is common to all placement strategies, this lives here.
2553          *
2554          * [ this allows ->select_task() to simply return task_cpu(p) and
2555          *   not worry about this generic constraint ]
2556          */
2557         if (unlikely(!is_cpu_allowed(p, cpu)))
2558                 cpu = select_fallback_rq(task_cpu(p), p);
2559 
2560         return cpu;
2561 }
2562 
2563 void sched_set_stop_task(int cpu, struct task_struct *stop)
2564 {
2565         struct sched_param param = { .sched_priority = MAX_RT_PRIO - 1 };
2566         struct task_struct *old_stop = cpu_rq(cpu)->stop;
2567 
2568         if (stop) {
2569                 /*
2570                  * Make it appear like a SCHED_FIFO task, its something
2571                  * userspace knows about and won't get confused about.
2572                  *
2573                  * Also, it will make PI more or less work without too
2574                  * much confusion -- but then, stop work should not
2575                  * rely on PI working anyway.
2576                  */
2577                 sched_setscheduler_nocheck(stop, SCHED_FIFO, &param);
2578 
2579                 stop->sched_class = &stop_sched_class;
2580         }
2581 
2582         cpu_rq(cpu)->stop = stop;
2583 
2584         if (old_stop) {
2585                 /*
2586                  * Reset it back to a normal scheduling class so that
2587                  * it can die in pieces.
2588                  */
2589                 old_stop->sched_class = &rt_sched_class;
2590         }
2591 }
2592 
2593 #else
2594 
2595 static inline int __set_cpus_allowed_ptr(struct task_struct *p,
2596                                          const struct cpumask *new_mask, bool check)
2597 {
2598         return set_cpus_allowed_ptr(p, new_mask);
2599 }
2600 
2601 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
2602 
2603 static void
2604 ttwu_stat(struct task_struct *p, int cpu, int wake_flags)
2605 {
2606         struct rq *rq;
2607 
2608         if (!schedstat_enabled())
2609                 return;
2610 
2611         rq = this_rq();
2612 
2613 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
2614         if (cpu == rq->cpu) {
2615                 __schedstat_inc(rq->ttwu_local);
2616                 __schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_wakeups_local);
2617         } else {
2618                 struct sched_domain *sd;
2619 
2620                 __schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_wakeups_remote);
2621                 rcu_read_lock();
2622                 for_each_domain(rq->cpu, sd) {
2623                         if (cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, sched_domain_span(sd))) {
2624                                 __schedstat_inc(sd->ttwu_wake_remote);
2625                                 break;
2626                         }
2627                 }
2628                 rcu_read_unlock();
2629         }
2630 
2631         if (wake_flags & WF_MIGRATED)
2632                 __schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_wakeups_migrate);
2633 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
2634 
2635         __schedstat_inc(rq->ttwu_count);
2636         __schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_wakeups);
2637 
2638         if (wake_flags & WF_SYNC)
2639                 __schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_wakeups_sync);
2640 }
2641 
2642 /*
2643  * Mark the task runnable and perform wakeup-preemption.
2644  */
2645 static void ttwu_do_wakeup(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int wake_flags,
2646                            struct rq_flags *rf)
2647 {
2648         check_preempt_curr(rq, p, wake_flags);
2649         p->state = TASK_RUNNING;
2650         trace_sched_wakeup(p);
2651 
2652 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
2653         if (p->sched_class->task_woken) {
2654                 /*
2655                  * Our task @p is fully woken up and running; so its safe to
2656                  * drop the rq->lock, hereafter rq is only used for statistics.
2657                  */
2658                 rq_unpin_lock(rq, rf);
2659                 p->sched_class->task_woken(rq, p);
2660                 rq_repin_lock(rq, rf);
2661         }
2662 
2663         if (rq->idle_stamp) {
2664                 u64 delta = rq_clock(rq) - rq->idle_stamp;
2665                 u64 max = 2*rq->max_idle_balance_cost;
2666 
2667                 update_avg(&rq->avg_idle, delta);
2668 
2669                 if (rq->avg_idle > max)
2670                         rq->avg_idle = max;
2671 
2672                 rq->idle_stamp = 0;
2673         }
2674 #endif
2675 }
2676 
2677 static void
2678 ttwu_do_activate(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int wake_flags,
2679                  struct rq_flags *rf)
2680 {
2681         int en_flags = ENQUEUE_WAKEUP | ENQUEUE_NOCLOCK;
2682 
2683         if (wake_flags & WF_SYNC)
2684                 en_flags |= ENQUEUE_WAKEUP_SYNC;
2685 
2686         lockdep_assert_held(&rq->lock);
2687 
2688         if (p->sched_contributes_to_load)
2689                 rq->nr_uninterruptible--;
2690 
2691 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
2692         if (wake_flags & WF_MIGRATED)
2693                 en_flags |= ENQUEUE_MIGRATED;
2694         else
2695 #endif
2696         if (p->in_iowait) {
2697                 delayacct_blkio_end(p);
2698                 atomic_dec(&task_rq(p)->nr_iowait);
2699         }
2700 
2701         activate_task(rq, p, en_flags);
2702         ttwu_do_wakeup(rq, p, wake_flags, rf);
2703 }
2704 
2705 /*
2706  * Consider @p being inside a wait loop:
2707  *
2708  *   for (;;) {
2709  *      set_current_state(TASK_UNINTERRUPTIBLE);
2710  *
2711  *      if (CONDITION)
2712  *         break;
2713  *
2714  *      schedule();
2715  *   }
2716  *   __set_current_state(TASK_RUNNING);
2717  *
2718  * between set_current_state() and schedule(). In this case @p is still
2719  * runnable, so all that needs doing is change p->state back to TASK_RUNNING in
2720  * an atomic manner.
2721  *
2722  * By taking task_rq(p)->lock we serialize against schedule(), if @p->on_rq
2723  * then schedule() must still happen and p->state can be changed to
2724  * TASK_RUNNING. Otherwise we lost the race, schedule() has happened, and we
2725  * need to do a full wakeup with enqueue.
2726  *
2727  * Returns: %true when the wakeup is done,
2728  *          %false otherwise.
2729  */
2730 static int ttwu_runnable(struct task_struct *p, int wake_flags)
2731 {
2732         struct rq_flags rf;
2733         struct rq *rq;
2734         int ret = 0;
2735 
2736         rq = __task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
2737         if (task_on_rq_queued(p)) {
2738                 /* check_preempt_curr() may use rq clock */
2739                 update_rq_clock(rq);
2740                 ttwu_do_wakeup(rq, p, wake_flags, &rf);
2741                 ret = 1;
2742         }
2743         __task_rq_unlock(rq, &rf);
2744 
2745         return ret;
2746 }
2747 
2748 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
2749 void sched_ttwu_pending(void *arg)
2750 {
2751         struct llist_node *llist = arg;
2752         struct rq *rq = this_rq();
2753         struct task_struct *p, *t;
2754         struct rq_flags rf;
2755 
2756         if (!llist)
2757                 return;
2758 
2759         /*
2760          * rq::ttwu_pending racy indication of out-standing wakeups.
2761          * Races such that false-negatives are possible, since they
2762          * are shorter lived that false-positives would be.
2763          */
2764         WRITE_ONCE(rq->ttwu_pending, 0);
2765 
2766         rq_lock_irqsave(rq, &rf);
2767         update_rq_clock(rq);
2768 
2769         llist_for_each_entry_safe(p, t, llist, wake_entry.llist) {
2770                 if (WARN_ON_ONCE(p->on_cpu))
2771                         smp_cond_load_acquire(&p->on_cpu, !VAL);
2772 
2773                 if (WARN_ON_ONCE(task_cpu(p) != cpu_of(rq)))
2774                         set_task_cpu(p, cpu_of(rq));
2775 
2776                 ttwu_do_activate(rq, p, p->sched_remote_wakeup ? WF_MIGRATED : 0, &rf);
2777         }
2778 
2779         rq_unlock_irqrestore(rq, &rf);
2780 }
2781 
2782 void send_call_function_single_ipi(int cpu)
2783 {
2784         struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
2785 
2786         if (!set_nr_if_polling(rq->idle))
2787                 arch_send_call_function_single_ipi(cpu);
2788         else
2789                 trace_sched_wake_idle_without_ipi(cpu);
2790 }
2791 
2792 /*
2793  * Queue a task on the target CPUs wake_list and wake the CPU via IPI if
2794  * necessary. The wakee CPU on receipt of the IPI will queue the task
2795  * via sched_ttwu_wakeup() for activation so the wakee incurs the cost
2796  * of the wakeup instead of the waker.
2797  */
2798 static void __ttwu_queue_wakelist(struct task_struct *p, int cpu, int wake_flags)
2799 {
2800         struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
2801 
2802         p->sched_remote_wakeup = !!(wake_flags & WF_MIGRATED);
2803 
2804         WRITE_ONCE(rq->ttwu_pending, 1);
2805         __smp_call_single_queue(cpu, &p->wake_entry.llist);
2806 }
2807 
2808 void wake_up_if_idle(int cpu)
2809 {
2810         struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
2811         struct rq_flags rf;
2812 
2813         rcu_read_lock();
2814 
2815         if (!is_idle_task(rcu_dereference(rq->curr)))
2816                 goto out;
2817 
2818         if (set_nr_if_polling(rq->idle)) {
2819                 trace_sched_wake_idle_without_ipi(cpu);
2820         } else {
2821                 rq_lock_irqsave(rq, &rf);
2822                 if (is_idle_task(rq->curr))
2823                         smp_send_reschedule(cpu);
2824                 /* Else CPU is not idle, do nothing here: */
2825                 rq_unlock_irqrestore(rq, &rf);
2826         }
2827 
2828 out:
2829         rcu_read_unlock();
2830 }
2831 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(wake_up_if_idle);
2832 
2833 bool cpus_share_cache(int this_cpu, int that_cpu)
2834 {
2835         return per_cpu(sd_llc_id, this_cpu) == per_cpu(sd_llc_id, that_cpu);
2836 }
2837 
2838 static inline bool ttwu_queue_cond(int cpu, int wake_flags)
2839 {
2840         /*
2841          * If the CPU does not share cache, then queue the task on the
2842          * remote rqs wakelist to avoid accessing remote data.
2843          */
2844         if (!cpus_share_cache(smp_processor_id(), cpu))
2845                 return true;
2846 
2847         /*
2848          * If the task is descheduling and the only running task on the
2849          * CPU then use the wakelist to offload the task activation to
2850          * the soon-to-be-idle CPU as the current CPU is likely busy.
2851          * nr_running is checked to avoid unnecessary task stacking.
2852          */
2853         if ((wake_flags & WF_ON_CPU) && cpu_rq(cpu)->nr_running <= 1)
2854                 return true;
2855 
2856         return false;
2857 }
2858 
2859 static bool ttwu_queue_wakelist(struct task_struct *p, int cpu, int wake_flags)
2860 {
2861         bool cond = false;
2862 
2863         trace_android_rvh_ttwu_cond(&cond);
2864 
2865         if ((sched_feat(TTWU_QUEUE) && ttwu_queue_cond(cpu, wake_flags)) ||
2866                         cond) {
2867                 if (WARN_ON_ONCE(cpu == smp_processor_id()))
2868                         return false;
2869 
2870                 sched_clock_cpu(cpu); /* Sync clocks across CPUs */
2871                 __ttwu_queue_wakelist(p, cpu, wake_flags);
2872                 return true;
2873         }
2874 
2875         return false;
2876 }
2877 
2878 #else /* !CONFIG_SMP */
2879 
2880 static inline bool ttwu_queue_wakelist(struct task_struct *p, int cpu, int wake_flags)
2881 {
2882         return false;
2883 }
2884 
2885 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
2886 
2887 static void ttwu_queue(struct task_struct *p, int cpu, int wake_flags)
2888 {
2889         struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
2890         struct rq_flags rf;
2891 
2892         if (ttwu_queue_wakelist(p, cpu, wake_flags))
2893                 return;
2894 
2895         rq_lock(rq, &rf);
2896         update_rq_clock(rq);
2897         ttwu_do_activate(rq, p, wake_flags, &rf);
2898         rq_unlock(rq, &rf);
2899 }
2900 
2901 /*
2902  * Notes on Program-Order guarantees on SMP systems.
2903  *
2904  *  MIGRATION
2905  *
2906  * The basic program-order guarantee on SMP systems is that when a task [t]
2907  * migrates, all its activity on its old CPU [c0] happens-before any subsequent
2908  * execution on its new CPU [c1].
2909  *
2910  * For migration (of runnable tasks) this is provided by the following means:
2911  *
2912  *  A) UNLOCK of the rq(c0)->lock scheduling out task t
2913  *  B) migration for t is required to synchronize *both* rq(c0)->lock and
2914  *     rq(c1)->lock (if not at the same time, then in that order).
2915  *  C) LOCK of the rq(c1)->lock scheduling in task
2916  *
2917  * Release/acquire chaining guarantees that B happens after A and C after B.
2918  * Note: the CPU doing B need not be c0 or c1
2919  *
2920  * Example:
2921  *
2922  *   CPU0            CPU1            CPU2
2923  *
2924  *   LOCK rq(0)->lock
2925  *   sched-out X
2926  *   sched-in Y
2927  *   UNLOCK rq(0)->lock
2928  *
2929  *                                   LOCK rq(0)->lock // orders against CPU0
2930  *                                   dequeue X
2931  *                                   UNLOCK rq(0)->lock
2932  *
2933  *                                   LOCK rq(1)->lock
2934  *                                   enqueue X
2935  *                                   UNLOCK rq(1)->lock
2936  *
2937  *                   LOCK rq(1)->lock // orders against CPU2
2938  *                   sched-out Z
2939  *                   sched-in X
2940  *                   UNLOCK rq(1)->lock
2941  *
2942  *
2943  *  BLOCKING -- aka. SLEEP + WAKEUP
2944  *
2945  * For blocking we (obviously) need to provide the same guarantee as for
2946  * migration. However the means are completely different as there is no lock
2947  * chain to provide order. Instead we do:
2948  *
2949  *   1) smp_store_release(X->on_cpu, 0)   -- finish_task()
2950  *   2) smp_cond_load_acquire(!X->on_cpu) -- try_to_wake_up()
2951  *
2952  * Example:
2953  *
2954  *   CPU0 (schedule)  CPU1 (try_to_wake_up) CPU2 (schedule)
2955  *
2956  *   LOCK rq(0)->lock LOCK X->pi_lock
2957  *   dequeue X
2958  *   sched-out X
2959  *   smp_store_release(X->on_cpu, 0);
2960  *
2961  *                    smp_cond_load_acquire(&X->on_cpu, !VAL);
2962  *                    X->state = WAKING
2963  *                    set_task_cpu(X,2)
2964  *
2965  *                    LOCK rq(2)->lock
2966  *                    enqueue X
2967  *                    X->state = RUNNING
2968  *                    UNLOCK rq(2)->lock
2969  *
2970  *                                          LOCK rq(2)->lock // orders against CPU1
2971  *                                          sched-out Z
2972  *                                          sched-in X
2973  *                                          UNLOCK rq(2)->lock
2974  *
2975  *                    UNLOCK X->pi_lock
2976  *   UNLOCK rq(0)->lock
2977  *
2978  *
2979  * However, for wakeups there is a second guarantee we must provide, namely we
2980  * must ensure that CONDITION=1 done by the caller can not be reordered with
2981  * accesses to the task state; see try_to_wake_up() and set_current_state().
2982  */
2983 
2984 /**
2985  * try_to_wake_up - wake up a thread
2986  * @p: the thread to be awakened
2987  * @state: the mask of task states that can be woken
2988  * @wake_flags: wake modifier flags (WF_*)
2989  *
2990  * Conceptually does:
2991  *
2992  *   If (@state & @p->state) @p->state = TASK_RUNNING.
2993  *
2994  * If the task was not queued/runnable, also place it back on a runqueue.
2995  *
2996  * This function is atomic against schedule() which would dequeue the task.
2997  *
2998  * It issues a full memory barrier before accessing @p->state, see the comment
2999  * with set_current_state().
3000  *
3001  * Uses p->pi_lock to serialize against concurrent wake-ups.
3002  *
3003  * Relies on p->pi_lock stabilizing:
3004  *  - p->sched_class
3005  *  - p->cpus_ptr
3006  *  - p->sched_task_group
3007  * in order to do migration, see its use of select_task_rq()/set_task_cpu().
3008  *
3009  * Tries really hard to only take one task_rq(p)->lock for performance.
3010  * Takes rq->lock in:
3011  *  - ttwu_runnable()    -- old rq, unavoidable, see comment there;
3012  *  - ttwu_queue()       -- new rq, for enqueue of the task;
3013  *  - psi_ttwu_dequeue() -- much sadness :-( accounting will kill us.
3014  *
3015  * As a consequence we race really badly with just about everything. See the
3016  * many memory barriers and their comments for details.
3017  *
3018  * Return: %true if @p->state changes (an actual wakeup was done),
3019  *         %false otherwise.
3020  */
3021 static int
3022 try_to_wake_up(struct task_struct *p, unsigned int state, int wake_flags)
3023 {
3024         unsigned long flags;
3025         int cpu, success = 0;
3026 
3027         preempt_disable();
3028         if (p == current) {
3029                 /*
3030                  * We're waking current, this means 'p->on_rq' and 'task_cpu(p)
3031                  * == smp_processor_id()'. Together this means we can special
3032                  * case the whole 'p->on_rq && ttwu_runnable()' case below
3033                  * without taking any locks.
3034                  *
3035                  * In particular:
3036                  *  - we rely on Program-Order guarantees for all the ordering,
3037                  *  - we're serialized against set_special_state() by virtue of
3038                  *    it disabling IRQs (this allows not taking ->pi_lock).
3039                  */
3040                 if (!(p->state & state))
3041                         goto out;
3042 
3043                 success = 1;
3044                 trace_sched_waking(p);
3045                 p->state = TASK_RUNNING;
3046                 trace_sched_wakeup(p);
3047                 goto out;
3048         }
3049 
3050         /*
3051          * If we are going to wake up a thread waiting for CONDITION we
3052          * need to ensure that CONDITION=1 done by the caller can not be
3053          * reordered with p->state check below. This pairs with smp_store_mb()
3054          * in set_current_state() that the waiting thread does.
3055          */
3056         raw_spin_lock_irqsave(&p->pi_lock, flags);
3057         smp_mb__after_spinlock();
3058         if (!(p->state & state))
3059                 goto unlock;
3060 
3061 #ifdef CONFIG_FREEZER
3062         /*
3063          * If we're going to wake up a thread which may be frozen, then
3064          * we can only do so if we have an active CPU which is capable of
3065          * running it. This may not be the case when resuming from suspend,
3066          * as the secondary CPUs may not yet be back online. See __thaw_task()
3067          * for the actual wakeup.
3068          */
3069         if (unlikely(frozen_or_skipped(p)) &&
3070             !cpumask_intersects(cpu_active_mask, task_cpu_possible_mask(p)))
3071                 goto unlock;
3072 #endif
3073 
3074         trace_sched_waking(p);
3075 
3076         /* We're going to change ->state: */
3077         success = 1;
3078 
3079         /*
3080          * Ensure we load p->on_rq _after_ p->state, otherwise it would
3081          * be possible to, falsely, observe p->on_rq == 0 and get stuck
3082          * in smp_cond_load_acquire() below.
3083          *
3084          * sched_ttwu_pending()                 try_to_wake_up()
3085          *   STORE p->on_rq = 1                   LOAD p->state
3086          *   UNLOCK rq->lock
3087          *
3088          * __schedule() (switch to task 'p')
3089          *   LOCK rq->lock                        smp_rmb();
3090          *   smp_mb__after_spinlock();
3091          *   UNLOCK rq->lock
3092          *
3093          * [task p]
3094          *   STORE p->state = UNINTERRUPTIBLE     LOAD p->on_rq
3095          *
3096          * Pairs with the LOCK+smp_mb__after_spinlock() on rq->lock in
3097          * __schedule().  See the comment for smp_mb__after_spinlock().
3098          *
3099          * A similar smb_rmb() lives in try_invoke_on_locked_down_task().
3100          */
3101         smp_rmb();
3102         if (READ_ONCE(p->on_rq) && ttwu_runnable(p, wake_flags))
3103                 goto unlock;
3104 
3105 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3106         /*
3107          * Ensure we load p->on_cpu _after_ p->on_rq, otherwise it would be
3108          * possible to, falsely, observe p->on_cpu == 0.
3109          *
3110          * One must be running (->on_cpu == 1) in order to remove oneself
3111          * from the runqueue.
3112          *
3113          * __schedule() (switch to task 'p')    try_to_wake_up()
3114          *   STORE p->on_cpu = 1                  LOAD p->on_rq
3115          *   UNLOCK rq->lock
3116          *
3117          * __schedule() (put 'p' to sleep)
3118          *   LOCK rq->lock                        smp_rmb();
3119          *   smp_mb__after_spinlock();
3120          *   STORE p->on_rq = 0                   LOAD p->on_cpu
3121          *
3122          * Pairs with the LOCK+smp_mb__after_spinlock() on rq->lock in
3123          * __schedule().  See the comment for smp_mb__after_spinlock().
3124          *
3125          * Form a control-dep-acquire with p->on_rq == 0 above, to ensure
3126          * schedule()'s deactivate_task() has 'happened' and p will no longer
3127          * care about it's own p->state. See the comment in __schedule().
3128          */
3129         smp_acquire__after_ctrl_dep();
3130 
3131         /*
3132          * We're doing the wakeup (@success == 1), they did a dequeue (p->on_rq
3133          * == 0), which means we need to do an enqueue, change p->state to
3134          * TASK_WAKING such that we can unlock p->pi_lock before doing the
3135          * enqueue, such as ttwu_queue_wakelist().
3136          */
3137         p->state = TASK_WAKING;
3138 
3139         /*
3140          * If the owning (remote) CPU is still in the middle of schedule() with
3141          * this task as prev, considering queueing p on the remote CPUs wake_list
3142          * which potentially sends an IPI instead of spinning on p->on_cpu to
3143          * let the waker make forward progress. This is safe because IRQs are
3144          * disabled and the IPI will deliver after on_cpu is cleared.
3145          *
3146          * Ensure we load task_cpu(p) after p->on_cpu:
3147          *
3148          * set_task_cpu(p, cpu);
3149          *   STORE p->cpu = @cpu
3150          * __schedule() (switch to task 'p')
3151          *   LOCK rq->lock
3152          *   smp_mb__after_spin_lock()          smp_cond_load_acquire(&p->on_cpu)
3153          *   STORE p->on_cpu = 1                LOAD p->cpu
3154          *
3155          * to ensure we observe the correct CPU on which the task is currently
3156          * scheduling.
3157          */
3158         if (smp_load_acquire(&p->on_cpu) &&
3159             ttwu_queue_wakelist(p, task_cpu(p), wake_flags | WF_ON_CPU))
3160                 goto unlock;
3161 
3162         /*
3163          * If the owning (remote) CPU is still in the middle of schedule() with
3164          * this task as prev, wait until its done referencing the task.
3165          *
3166          * Pairs with the smp_store_release() in finish_task().
3167          *
3168          * This ensures that tasks getting woken will be fully ordered against
3169          * their previous state and preserve Program Order.
3170          */
3171         smp_cond_load_acquire(&p->on_cpu, !VAL);
3172 
3173         trace_android_rvh_try_to_wake_up(p);
3174 
3175         cpu = select_task_rq(p, p->wake_cpu, SD_BALANCE_WAKE, wake_flags);
3176         if (task_cpu(p) != cpu) {
3177                 if (p->in_iowait) {
3178                         delayacct_blkio_end(p);
3179                         atomic_dec(&task_rq(p)->nr_iowait);
3180                 }
3181 
3182                 wake_flags |= WF_MIGRATED;
3183                 psi_ttwu_dequeue(p);
3184                 set_task_cpu(p, cpu);
3185         }
3186 #else
3187         cpu = task_cpu(p);
3188 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
3189 
3190         ttwu_queue(p, cpu, wake_flags);
3191 unlock:
3192         raw_spin_unlock_irqrestore(&p->pi_lock, flags);
3193 out:
3194         if (success) {
3195                 trace_android_rvh_try_to_wake_up_success(p);
3196                 ttwu_stat(p, task_cpu(p), wake_flags);
3197         }
3198         preempt_enable();
3199 
3200         return success;
3201 }
3202 
3203 /**
3204  * try_invoke_on_locked_down_task - Invoke a function on task in fixed state
3205  * @p: Process for which the function is to be invoked, can be @current.
3206  * @func: Function to invoke.
3207  * @arg: Argument to function.
3208  *
3209  * If the specified task can be quickly locked into a definite state
3210  * (either sleeping or on a given runqueue), arrange to keep it in that
3211  * state while invoking @func(@arg).  This function can use ->on_rq and
3212  * task_curr() to work out what the state is, if required.  Given that
3213  * @func can be invoked with a runqueue lock held, it had better be quite
3214  * lightweight.
3215  *
3216  * Returns:
3217  *      @false if the task slipped out from under the locks.
3218  *      @true if the task was locked onto a runqueue or is sleeping.
3219  *              However, @func can override this by returning @false.
3220  */
3221 bool try_invoke_on_locked_down_task(struct task_struct *p, bool (*func)(struct task_struct *t, void *arg), void *arg)
3222 {
3223         struct rq_flags rf;
3224         bool ret = false;
3225         struct rq *rq;
3226 
3227         raw_spin_lock_irqsave(&p->pi_lock, rf.flags);
3228         if (p->on_rq) {
3229                 rq = __task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
3230                 if (task_rq(p) == rq)
3231                         ret = func(p, arg);
3232                 rq_unlock(rq, &rf);
3233         } else {
3234                 switch (p->state) {
3235                 case TASK_RUNNING:
3236                 case TASK_WAKING:
3237                         break;
3238                 default:
3239                         smp_rmb(); // See smp_rmb() comment in try_to_wake_up().
3240                         if (!p->on_rq)
3241                                 ret = func(p, arg);
3242                 }
3243         }
3244         raw_spin_unlock_irqrestore(&p->pi_lock, rf.flags);
3245         return ret;
3246 }
3247 
3248 /**
3249  * wake_up_process - Wake up a specific process
3250  * @p: The process to be woken up.
3251  *
3252  * Attempt to wake up the nominated process and move it to the set of runnable
3253  * processes.
3254  *
3255  * Return: 1 if the process was woken up, 0 if it was already running.
3256  *
3257  * This function executes a full memory barrier before accessing the task state.
3258  */
3259 int wake_up_process(struct task_struct *p)
3260 {
3261         return try_to_wake_up(p, TASK_NORMAL, 0);
3262 }
3263 EXPORT_SYMBOL(wake_up_process);
3264 
3265 int wake_up_state(struct task_struct *p, unsigned int state)
3266 {
3267         return try_to_wake_up(p, state, 0);
3268 }
3269 
3270 /*
3271  * Perform scheduler related setup for a newly forked process p.
3272  * p is forked by current.
3273  *
3274  * __sched_fork() is basic setup used by init_idle() too:
3275  */
3276 static void __sched_fork(unsigned long clone_flags, struct task_struct *p)
3277 {
3278         p->on_rq                        = 0;
3279 
3280         p->se.on_rq                     = 0;
3281         p->se.exec_start                = 0;
3282         p->se.sum_exec_runtime          = 0;
3283         p->se.prev_sum_exec_runtime     = 0;
3284         p->se.nr_migrations             = 0;
3285         p->se.vruntime                  = 0;
3286         INIT_LIST_HEAD(&p->se.group_node);
3287 
3288 #ifdef CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED
3289         p->se.cfs_rq                    = NULL;
3290 #endif
3291 
3292         trace_android_rvh_sched_fork_init(p);
3293 
3294 #ifdef CONFIG_SCHEDSTATS
3295         /* Even if schedstat is disabled, there should not be garbage */
3296         memset(&p->se.statistics, 0, sizeof(p->se.statistics));
3297 #endif
3298 
3299         RB_CLEAR_NODE(&p->dl.rb_node);
3300         init_dl_task_timer(&p->dl);
3301         init_dl_inactive_task_timer(&p->dl);
3302         __dl_clear_params(p);
3303 
3304         INIT_LIST_HEAD(&p->rt.run_list);
3305         p->rt.timeout           = 0;
3306         p->rt.time_slice        = sched_rr_timeslice;
3307         p->rt.on_rq             = 0;
3308         p->rt.on_list           = 0;
3309 
3310 #ifdef CONFIG_PREEMPT_NOTIFIERS
3311         INIT_HLIST_HEAD(&p->preempt_notifiers);
3312 #endif
3313 
3314 #ifdef CONFIG_COMPACTION
3315         p->capture_control = NULL;
3316 #endif
3317         init_numa_balancing(clone_flags, p);
3318 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3319         p->wake_entry.u_flags = CSD_TYPE_TTWU;
3320 #endif
3321 }
3322 
3323 DEFINE_STATIC_KEY_FALSE(sched_numa_balancing);
3324 
3325 #ifdef CONFIG_NUMA_BALANCING
3326 
3327 void set_numabalancing_state(bool enabled)
3328 {
3329         if (enabled)
3330                 static_branch_enable(&sched_numa_balancing);
3331         else
3332                 static_branch_disable(&sched_numa_balancing);
3333 }
3334 
3335 #ifdef CONFIG_PROC_SYSCTL
3336 int sysctl_numa_balancing(struct ctl_table *table, int write,
3337                           void *buffer, size_t *lenp, loff_t *ppos)
3338 {
3339         struct ctl_table t;
3340         int err;
3341         int state = static_branch_likely(&sched_numa_balancing);
3342 
3343         if (write && !capable(CAP_SYS_ADMIN))
3344                 return -EPERM;
3345 
3346         t = *table;
3347         t.data = &state;
3348         err = proc_dointvec_minmax(&t, write, buffer, lenp, ppos);
3349         if (err < 0)
3350                 return err;
3351         if (write)
3352                 set_numabalancing_state(state);
3353         return err;
3354 }
3355 #endif
3356 #endif
3357 
3358 #ifdef CONFIG_SCHEDSTATS
3359 
3360 DEFINE_STATIC_KEY_FALSE(sched_schedstats);
3361 static bool __initdata __sched_schedstats = false;
3362 
3363 static void set_schedstats(bool enabled)
3364 {
3365         if (enabled)
3366                 static_branch_enable(&sched_schedstats);
3367         else
3368                 static_branch_disable(&sched_schedstats);
3369 }
3370 
3371 void force_schedstat_enabled(void)
3372 {
3373         if (!schedstat_enabled()) {
3374                 pr_info("kernel profiling enabled schedstats, disable via kernel.sched_schedstats.\n");
3375                 static_branch_enable(&sched_schedstats);
3376         }
3377 }
3378 
3379 static int __init setup_schedstats(char *str)
3380 {
3381         int ret = 0;
3382         if (!str)
3383                 goto out;
3384 
3385         /*
3386          * This code is called before jump labels have been set up, so we can't
3387          * change the static branch directly just yet.  Instead set a temporary
3388          * variable so init_schedstats() can do it later.
3389          */
3390         if (!strcmp(str, "enable")) {
3391                 __sched_schedstats = true;
3392                 ret = 1;
3393         } else if (!strcmp(str, "disable")) {
3394                 __sched_schedstats = false;
3395                 ret = 1;
3396         }
3397 out:
3398         if (!ret)
3399                 pr_warn("Unable to parse schedstats=\n");
3400 
3401         return ret;
3402 }
3403 __setup("schedstats=", setup_schedstats);
3404 
3405 static void __init init_schedstats(void)
3406 {
3407         set_schedstats(__sched_schedstats);
3408 }
3409 
3410 #ifdef CONFIG_PROC_SYSCTL
3411 int sysctl_schedstats(struct ctl_table *table, int write, void *buffer,
3412                 size_t *lenp, loff_t *ppos)
3413 {
3414         struct ctl_table t;
3415         int err;
3416         int state = static_branch_likely(&sched_schedstats);
3417 
3418         if (write && !capable(CAP_SYS_ADMIN))
3419                 return -EPERM;
3420 
3421         t = *table;
3422         t.data = &state;
3423         err = proc_dointvec_minmax(&t, write, buffer, lenp, ppos);
3424         if (err < 0)
3425                 return err;
3426         if (write)
3427                 set_schedstats(state);
3428         return err;
3429 }
3430 #endif /* CONFIG_PROC_SYSCTL */
3431 #else  /* !CONFIG_SCHEDSTATS */
3432 static inline void init_schedstats(void) {}
3433 #endif /* CONFIG_SCHEDSTATS */
3434 
3435 /*
3436  * fork()/clone()-time setup:
3437  */
3438 int sched_fork(unsigned long clone_flags, struct task_struct *p)
3439 {
3440         unsigned long flags;
3441 
3442         trace_android_rvh_sched_fork(p);
3443 
3444         __sched_fork(clone_flags, p);
3445         /*
3446          * We mark the process as NEW here. This guarantees that
3447          * nobody will actually run it, and a signal or other external
3448          * event cannot wake it up and insert it on the runqueue either.
3449          */
3450         p->state = TASK_NEW;
3451 
3452         /*
3453          * Make sure we do not leak PI boosting priority to the child.
3454          */
3455         p->prio = current->normal_prio;
3456         trace_android_rvh_prepare_prio_fork(p);
3457 
3458         uclamp_fork(p);
3459 
3460         /*
3461          * Revert to default priority/policy on fork if requested.
3462          */
3463         if (unlikely(p->sched_reset_on_fork)) {
3464                 if (task_has_dl_policy(p) || task_has_rt_policy(p)) {
3465                         p->policy = SCHED_NORMAL;
3466                         p->static_prio = NICE_TO_PRIO(0);
3467                         p->rt_priority = 0;
3468                 } else if (PRIO_TO_NICE(p->static_prio) < 0)
3469                         p->static_prio = NICE_TO_PRIO(0);
3470 
3471                 p->prio = p->normal_prio = __normal_prio(p);
3472                 set_load_weight(p, false);
3473 
3474                 /*
3475                  * We don't need the reset flag anymore after the fork. It has
3476                  * fulfilled its duty:
3477                  */
3478                 p->sched_reset_on_fork = 0;
3479         }
3480 
3481         if (dl_prio(p->prio))
3482                 return -EAGAIN;
3483         else if (rt_prio(p->prio))
3484                 p->sched_class = &rt_sched_class;
3485         else
3486                 p->sched_class = &fair_sched_class;
3487 
3488         init_entity_runnable_average(&p->se);
3489         trace_android_rvh_finish_prio_fork(p);
3490 
3491         /*
3492          * The child is not yet in the pid-hash so no cgroup attach races,
3493          * and the cgroup is pinned to this child due to cgroup_fork()
3494          * is ran before sched_fork().
3495          *
3496          * Silence PROVE_RCU.
3497          */
3498         raw_spin_lock_irqsave(&p->pi_lock, flags);
3499         rseq_migrate(p);
3500         /*
3501          * We're setting the CPU for the first time, we don't migrate,
3502          * so use __set_task_cpu().
3503          */
3504         __set_task_cpu(p, smp_processor_id());
3505         if (p->sched_class->task_fork)
3506                 p->sched_class->task_fork(p);
3507         raw_spin_unlock_irqrestore(&p->pi_lock, flags);
3508 
3509 #ifdef CONFIG_SCHED_INFO
3510         if (likely(sched_info_on()))
3511                 memset(&p->sched_info, 0, sizeof(p->sched_info));
3512 #endif
3513 #if defined(CONFIG_SMP)
3514         p->on_cpu = 0;
3515 #endif
3516         init_task_preempt_count(p);
3517 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3518         plist_node_init(&p->pushable_tasks, MAX_PRIO);
3519         RB_CLEAR_NODE(&p->pushable_dl_tasks);
3520 #endif
3521         return 0;
3522 }
3523 
3524 void sched_post_fork(struct task_struct *p)
3525 {
3526         uclamp_post_fork(p);
3527 }
3528 
3529 unsigned long to_ratio(u64 period, u64 runtime)
3530 {
3531         if (runtime == RUNTIME_INF)
3532                 return BW_UNIT;
3533 
3534         /*
3535          * Doing this here saves a lot of checks in all
3536          * the calling paths, and returning zero seems
3537          * safe for them anyway.
3538          */
3539         if (period == 0)
3540                 return 0;
3541 
3542         return div64_u64(runtime << BW_SHIFT, period);
3543 }
3544 
3545 /*
3546  * wake_up_new_task - wake up a newly created task for the first time.
3547  *
3548  * This function will do some initial scheduler statistics housekeeping
3549  * that must be done for every newly created context, then puts the task
3550  * on the runqueue and wakes it.
3551  */
3552 void wake_up_new_task(struct task_struct *p)
3553 {
3554         struct rq_flags rf;
3555         struct rq *rq;
3556 
3557         trace_android_rvh_wake_up_new_task(p);
3558 
3559         raw_spin_lock_irqsave(&p->pi_lock, rf.flags);
3560         p->state = TASK_RUNNING;
3561 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3562         /*
3563          * Fork balancing, do it here and not earlier because:
3564          *  - cpus_ptr can change in the fork path
3565          *  - any previously selected CPU might disappear through hotplug
3566          *
3567          * Use __set_task_cpu() to avoid calling sched_class::migrate_task_rq,
3568          * as we're not fully set-up yet.
3569          */
3570         p->recent_used_cpu = task_cpu(p);
3571         rseq_migrate(p);
3572         __set_task_cpu(p, select_task_rq(p, task_cpu(p), SD_BALANCE_FORK, 0));
3573 #endif
3574         rq = __task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
3575         update_rq_clock(rq);
3576         post_init_entity_util_avg(p);
3577         trace_android_rvh_new_task_stats(p);
3578 
3579         activate_task(rq, p, ENQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
3580         trace_sched_wakeup_new(p);
3581         check_preempt_curr(rq, p, WF_FORK);
3582 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3583         if (p->sched_class->task_woken) {
3584                 /*
3585                  * Nothing relies on rq->lock after this, so its fine to
3586                  * drop it.
3587                  */
3588                 rq_unpin_lock(rq, &rf);
3589                 p->sched_class->task_woken(rq, p);
3590                 rq_repin_lock(rq, &rf);
3591         }
3592 #endif
3593         task_rq_unlock(rq, p, &rf);
3594 }
3595 
3596 #ifdef CONFIG_PREEMPT_NOTIFIERS
3597 
3598 static DEFINE_STATIC_KEY_FALSE(preempt_notifier_key);
3599 
3600 void preempt_notifier_inc(void)
3601 {
3602         static_branch_inc(&preempt_notifier_key);
3603 }
3604 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(preempt_notifier_inc);
3605 
3606 void preempt_notifier_dec(void)
3607 {
3608         static_branch_dec(&preempt_notifier_key);
3609 }
3610 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(preempt_notifier_dec);
3611 
3612 /**
3613  * preempt_notifier_register - tell me when current is being preempted & rescheduled
3614  * @notifier: notifier struct to register
3615  */
3616 void preempt_notifier_register(struct preempt_notifier *notifier)
3617 {
3618         if (!static_branch_unlikely(&preempt_notifier_key))
3619                 WARN(1, "registering preempt_notifier while notifiers disabled\n");
3620 
3621         hlist_add_head(&notifier->link, &current->preempt_notifiers);
3622 }
3623 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(preempt_notifier_register);
3624 
3625 /**
3626  * preempt_notifier_unregister - no longer interested in preemption notifications
3627  * @notifier: notifier struct to unregister
3628  *
3629  * This is *not* safe to call from within a preemption notifier.
3630  */
3631 void preempt_notifier_unregister(struct preempt_notifier *notifier)
3632 {
3633         hlist_del(&notifier->link);
3634 }
3635 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(preempt_notifier_unregister);
3636 
3637 static void __fire_sched_in_preempt_notifiers(struct task_struct *curr)
3638 {
3639         struct preempt_notifier *notifier;
3640 
3641         hlist_for_each_entry(notifier, &curr->preempt_notifiers, link)
3642                 notifier->ops->sched_in(notifier, raw_smp_processor_id());
3643 }
3644 
3645 static __always_inline void fire_sched_in_preempt_notifiers(struct task_struct *curr)
3646 {
3647         if (static_branch_unlikely(&preempt_notifier_key))
3648                 __fire_sched_in_preempt_notifiers(curr);
3649 }
3650 
3651 static void
3652 __fire_sched_out_preempt_notifiers(struct task_struct *curr,
3653                                    struct task_struct *next)
3654 {
3655         struct preempt_notifier *notifier;
3656 
3657         hlist_for_each_entry(notifier, &curr->preempt_notifiers, link)
3658                 notifier->ops->sched_out(notifier, next);
3659 }
3660 
3661 static __always_inline void
3662 fire_sched_out_preempt_notifiers(struct task_struct *curr,
3663                                  struct task_struct *next)
3664 {
3665         if (static_branch_unlikely(&preempt_notifier_key))
3666                 __fire_sched_out_preempt_notifiers(curr, next);
3667 }
3668 
3669 #else /* !CONFIG_PREEMPT_NOTIFIERS */
3670 
3671 static inline void fire_sched_in_preempt_notifiers(struct task_struct *curr)
3672 {
3673 }
3674 
3675 static inline void
3676 fire_sched_out_preempt_notifiers(struct task_struct *curr,
3677                                  struct task_struct *next)
3678 {
3679 }
3680 
3681 #endif /* CONFIG_PREEMPT_NOTIFIERS */
3682 
3683 static inline void prepare_task(struct task_struct *next)
3684 {
3685 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3686         /*
3687          * Claim the task as running, we do this before switching to it
3688          * such that any running task will have this set.
3689          *
3690          * See the ttwu() WF_ON_CPU case and its ordering comment.
3691          */
3692         WRITE_ONCE(next->on_cpu, 1);
3693 #endif
3694 }
3695 
3696 static inline void finish_task(struct task_struct *prev)
3697 {
3698 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3699         /*
3700          * This must be the very last reference to @prev from this CPU. After
3701          * p->on_cpu is cleared, the task can be moved to a different CPU. We
3702          * must ensure this doesn't happen until the switch is completely
3703          * finished.
3704          *
3705          * In particular, the load of prev->state in finish_task_switch() must
3706          * happen before this.
3707          *
3708          * Pairs with the smp_cond_load_acquire() in try_to_wake_up().
3709          */
3710         smp_store_release(&prev->on_cpu, 0);
3711 #endif
3712 }
3713 
3714 static inline void
3715 prepare_lock_switch(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *next, struct rq_flags *rf)
3716 {
3717         /*
3718          * Since the runqueue lock will be released by the next
3719          * task (which is an invalid locking op but in the case
3720          * of the scheduler it's an obvious special-case), so we
3721          * do an early lockdep release here:
3722          */
3723         rq_unpin_lock(rq, rf);
3724         spin_release(&rq->lock.dep_map, _THIS_IP_);
3725 #ifdef CONFIG_DEBUG_SPINLOCK
3726         /* this is a valid case when another task releases the spinlock */
3727         rq->lock.owner = next;
3728 #endif
3729 }
3730 
3731 static inline void finish_lock_switch(struct rq *rq)
3732 {
3733         /*
3734          * If we are tracking spinlock dependencies then we have to
3735          * fix up the runqueue lock - which gets 'carried over' from
3736          * prev into current:
3737          */
3738         spin_acquire(&rq->lock.dep_map, 0, 0, _THIS_IP_);
3739         raw_spin_unlock_irq(&rq->lock);
3740 }
3741 
3742 /*
3743  * NOP if the arch has not defined these:
3744  */
3745 
3746 #ifndef prepare_arch_switch
3747 # define prepare_arch_switch(next)      do { } while (0)
3748 #endif
3749 
3750 #ifndef finish_arch_post_lock_switch
3751 # define finish_arch_post_lock_switch() do { } while (0)
3752 #endif
3753 
3754 /**
3755  * prepare_task_switch - prepare to switch tasks
3756  * @rq: the runqueue preparing to switch
3757  * @prev: the current task that is being switched out
3758  * @next: the task we are going to switch to.
3759  *
3760  * This is called with the rq lock held and interrupts off. It must
3761  * be paired with a subsequent finish_task_switch after the context
3762  * switch.
3763  *
3764  * prepare_task_switch sets up locking and calls architecture specific
3765  * hooks.
3766  */
3767 static inline void
3768 prepare_task_switch(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *prev,
3769                     struct task_struct *next)
3770 {
3771         kcov_prepare_switch(prev);
3772         sched_info_switch(rq, prev, next);
3773         perf_event_task_sched_out(prev, next);
3774         rseq_preempt(prev);
3775         fire_sched_out_preempt_notifiers(prev, next);
3776         prepare_task(next);
3777         prepare_arch_switch(next);
3778 }
3779 
3780 /**
3781  * finish_task_switch - clean up after a task-switch
3782  * @prev: the thread we just switched away from.
3783  *
3784  * finish_task_switch must be called after the context switch, paired
3785  * with a prepare_task_switch call before the context switch.
3786  * finish_task_switch will reconcile locking set up by prepare_task_switch,
3787  * and do any other architecture-specific cleanup actions.
3788  *
3789  * Note that we may have delayed dropping an mm in context_switch(). If
3790  * so, we finish that here outside of the runqueue lock. (Doing it
3791  * with the lock held can cause deadlocks; see schedule() for
3792  * details.)
3793  *
3794  * The context switch have flipped the stack from under us and restored the
3795  * local variables which were saved when this task called schedule() in the
3796  * past. prev == current is still correct but we need to recalculate this_rq
3797  * because prev may have moved to another CPU.
3798  */
3799 static struct rq *finish_task_switch(struct task_struct *prev)
3800         __releases(rq->lock)
3801 {
3802         struct rq *rq = this_rq();
3803         struct mm_struct *mm = rq->prev_mm;
3804         long prev_state;
3805 
3806         /*
3807          * The previous task will have left us with a preempt_count of 2
3808          * because it left us after:
3809          *
3810          *      schedule()
3811          *        preempt_disable();                    // 1
3812          *        __schedule()
3813          *          raw_spin_lock_irq(&rq->lock)        // 2
3814          *
3815          * Also, see FORK_PREEMPT_COUNT.
3816          */
3817         if (WARN_ONCE(preempt_count() != 2*PREEMPT_DISABLE_OFFSET,
3818                       "corrupted preempt_count: %s/%d/0x%x\n",
3819                       current->comm, current->pid, preempt_count()))
3820                 preempt_count_set(FORK_PREEMPT_COUNT);
3821 
3822         rq->prev_mm = NULL;
3823 
3824         /*
3825          * A task struct has one reference for the use as "current".
3826          * If a task dies, then it sets TASK_DEAD in tsk->state and calls
3827          * schedule one last time. The schedule call will never return, and
3828          * the scheduled task must drop that reference.
3829          *
3830          * We must observe prev->state before clearing prev->on_cpu (in
3831          * finish_task), otherwise a concurrent wakeup can get prev
3832          * running on another CPU and we could rave with its RUNNING -> DEAD
3833          * transition, resulting in a double drop.
3834          */
3835         prev_state = prev->state;
3836         vtime_task_switch(prev);
3837         perf_event_task_sched_in(prev, current);
3838         finish_task(prev);
3839         finish_lock_switch(rq);
3840         finish_arch_post_lock_switch();
3841         kcov_finish_switch(current);
3842 
3843         fire_sched_in_preempt_notifiers(current);
3844         /*
3845          * When switching through a kernel thread, the loop in
3846          * membarrier_{private,global}_expedited() may have observed that
3847          * kernel thread and not issued an IPI. It is therefore possible to
3848          * schedule between user->kernel->user threads without passing though
3849          * switch_mm(). Membarrier requires a barrier after storing to
3850          * rq->curr, before returning to userspace, so provide them here:
3851          *
3852          * - a full memory barrier for {PRIVATE,GLOBAL}_EXPEDITED, implicitly
3853          *   provided by mmdrop(),
3854          * - a sync_core for SYNC_CORE.
3855          */
3856         if (mm) {
3857                 membarrier_mm_sync_core_before_usermode(mm);
3858                 mmdrop(mm);
3859         }
3860         if (unlikely(prev_state == TASK_DEAD)) {
3861                 if (prev->sched_class->task_dead)
3862                         prev->sched_class->task_dead(prev);
3863 
3864                 /*
3865                  * Remove function-return probe instances associated with this
3866                  * task and put them back on the free list.
3867                  */
3868                 kprobe_flush_task(prev);
3869                 trace_android_rvh_flush_task(prev);
3870 
3871                 /* Task is done with its stack. */
3872                 put_task_stack(prev);
3873 
3874                 put_task_struct_rcu_user(prev);
3875         }
3876 
3877         tick_nohz_task_switch();
3878         return rq;
3879 }
3880 
3881 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3882 
3883 /* rq->lock is NOT held, but preemption is disabled */
3884 static void __balance_callback(struct rq *rq)
3885 {
3886         struct callback_head *head, *next;
3887         void (*func)(struct rq *rq);
3888         unsigned long flags;
3889 
3890         raw_spin_lock_irqsave(&rq->lock, flags);
3891         head = rq->balance_callback;
3892         rq->balance_callback = NULL;
3893         while (head) {
3894                 func = (void (*)(struct rq *))head->func;
3895                 next = head->next;
3896                 head->next = NULL;
3897                 head = next;
3898 
3899                 func(rq);
3900         }
3901         raw_spin_unlock_irqrestore(&rq->lock, flags);
3902 }
3903 
3904 static inline void balance_callback(struct rq *rq)
3905 {
3906         if (unlikely(rq->balance_callback))
3907                 __balance_callback(rq);
3908 }
3909 
3910 #else
3911 
3912 static inline void balance_callback(struct rq *rq)
3913 {
3914 }
3915 
3916 #endif
3917 
3918 /**
3919  * schedule_tail - first thing a freshly forked thread must call.
3920  * @prev: the thread we just switched away from.
3921  */
3922 asmlinkage __visible void schedule_tail(struct task_struct *prev)
3923         __releases(rq->lock)
3924 {
3925         struct rq *rq;
3926 
3927         /*
3928          * New tasks start with FORK_PREEMPT_COUNT, see there and
3929          * finish_task_switch() for details.
3930          *
3931          * finish_task_switch() will drop rq->lock() and lower preempt_count
3932          * and the preempt_enable() will end up enabling preemption (on
3933          * PREEMPT_COUNT kernels).
3934          */
3935 
3936         rq = finish_task_switch(prev);
3937         balance_callback(rq);
3938         preempt_enable();
3939 
3940         if (current->set_child_tid)
3941                 put_user(task_pid_vnr(current), current->set_child_tid);
3942 
3943         calculate_sigpending();
3944 }
3945 
3946 /*
3947  * context_switch - switch to the new MM and the new thread's register state.
3948  */
3949 static __always_inline struct rq *
3950 context_switch(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *prev,
3951                struct task_struct *next, struct rq_flags *rf)
3952 {
3953         prepare_task_switch(rq, prev, next);
3954 
3955         /*
3956          * For paravirt, this is coupled with an exit in switch_to to
3957          * combine the page table reload and the switch backend into
3958          * one hypercall.
3959          */
3960         arch_start_context_switch(prev);
3961 
3962         /*
3963          * kernel -> kernel   lazy + transfer active
3964          *   user -> kernel   lazy + mmgrab() active
3965          *
3966          * kernel ->   user   switch + mmdrop() active
3967          *   user ->   user   switch
3968          */
3969         if (!next->mm) {                                // to kernel
3970                 enter_lazy_tlb(prev->active_mm, next);
3971 
3972                 next->active_mm = prev->active_mm;
3973                 if (prev->mm)                           // from user
3974                         mmgrab(prev->active_mm);
3975                 else
3976                         prev->active_mm = NULL;
3977         } else {                                        // to user
3978                 membarrier_switch_mm(rq, prev->active_mm, next->mm);
3979                 /*
3980                  * sys_membarrier() requires an smp_mb() between setting
3981                  * rq->curr / membarrier_switch_mm() and returning to userspace.
3982                  *
3983                  * The below provides this either through switch_mm(), or in
3984                  * case 'prev->active_mm == next->mm' through
3985                  * finish_task_switch()'s mmdrop().
3986                  */
3987                 switch_mm_irqs_off(prev->active_mm, next->mm, next);
3988 
3989                 if (!prev->mm) {                        // from kernel
3990                         /* will mmdrop() in finish_task_switch(). */
3991                         rq->prev_mm = prev->active_mm;
3992                         prev->active_mm = NULL;
3993                 }
3994         }
3995 
3996         rq->clock_update_flags &= ~(RQCF_ACT_SKIP|RQCF_REQ_SKIP);
3997 
3998         prepare_lock_switch(rq, next, rf);
3999 
4000         /* Here we just switch the register state and the stack. */
4001         switch_to(prev, next, prev);
4002         barrier();
4003 
4004         return finish_task_switch(prev);
4005 }
4006 
4007 /*
4008  * nr_running and nr_context_switches:
4009  *
4010  * externally visible scheduler statistics: current number of runnable
4011  * threads, total number of context switches performed since bootup.
4012  */
4013 unsigned long nr_running(void)
4014 {
4015         unsigned long i, sum = 0;
4016 
4017         for_each_online_cpu(i)
4018                 sum += cpu_rq(i)->nr_running;
4019 
4020         return sum;
4021 }
4022 
4023 /*
4024  * Check if only the current task is running on the CPU.
4025  *
4026  * Caution: this function does not check that the caller has disabled
4027  * preemption, thus the result might have a time-of-check-to-time-of-use
4028  * race.  The caller is responsible to use it correctly, for example:
4029  *
4030  * - from a non-preemptible section (of course)
4031  *
4032  * - from a thread that is bound to a single CPU
4033  *
4034  * - in a loop with very short iterations (e.g. a polling loop)
4035  */
4036 bool single_task_running(void)
4037 {
4038         return raw_rq()->nr_running == 1;
4039 }
4040 EXPORT_SYMBOL(single_task_running);
4041 
4042 unsigned long long nr_context_switches(void)
4043 {
4044         int i;
4045         unsigned long long sum = 0;
4046 
4047         for_each_possible_cpu(i)
4048                 sum += cpu_rq(i)->nr_switches;
4049 
4050         return sum;
4051 }
4052 
4053 /*
4054  * Consumers of these two interfaces, like for example the cpuidle menu
4055  * governor, are using nonsensical data. Preferring shallow idle state selection
4056  * for a CPU that has IO-wait which might not even end up running the task when
4057  * it does become runnable.
4058  */
4059 
4060 unsigned long nr_iowait_cpu(int cpu)
4061 {
4062         return atomic_read(&cpu_rq(cpu)->nr_iowait);
4063 }
4064 
4065 /*
4066  * IO-wait accounting, and how its mostly bollocks (on SMP).
4067  *
4068  * The idea behind IO-wait account is to account the idle time that we could
4069  * have spend running if it were not for IO. That is, if we were to improve the
4070  * storage performance, we'd have a proportional reduction in IO-wait time.
4071  *
4072  * This all works nicely on UP, where, when a task blocks on IO, we account
4073  * idle time as IO-wait, because if the storage were faster, it could've been
4074  * running and we'd not be idle.
4075  *
4076  * This has been extended to SMP, by doing the same for each CPU. This however
4077  * is broken.
4078  *
4079  * Imagine for instance the case where two tasks block on one CPU, only the one
4080  * CPU will have IO-wait accounted, while the other has regular idle. Even
4081  * though, if the storage were faster, both could've ran at the same time,
4082  * utilising both CPUs.
4083  *
4084  * This means, that when looking globally, the current IO-wait accounting on
4085  * SMP is a lower bound, by reason of under accounting.
4086  *
4087  * Worse, since the numbers are provided per CPU, they are sometimes
4088  * interpreted per CPU, and that is nonsensical. A blocked task isn't strictly
4089  * associated with any one particular CPU, it can wake to another CPU than it
4090  * blocked on. This means the per CPU IO-wait number is meaningless.
4091  *
4092  * Task CPU affinities can make all that even more 'interesting'.
4093  */
4094 
4095 unsigned long nr_iowait(void)
4096 {
4097         unsigned long i, sum = 0;
4098 
4099         for_each_possible_cpu(i)
4100                 sum += nr_iowait_cpu(i);
4101 
4102         return sum;
4103 }
4104 
4105 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
4106 
4107 /*
4108  * sched_exec - execve() is a valuable balancing opportunity, because at
4109  * this point the task has the smallest effective memory and cache footprint.
4110  */
4111 void sched_exec(void)
4112 {
4113         struct task_struct *p = current;
4114         unsigned long flags;
4115         int dest_cpu;
4116         bool cond = false;
4117 
4118         trace_android_rvh_sched_exec(&cond);
4119         if (cond)
4120                 return;
4121 
4122         raw_spin_lock_irqsave(&p->pi_lock, flags);
4123         dest_cpu = p->sched_class->select_task_rq(p, task_cpu(p), SD_BALANCE_EXEC, 0);
4124         if (dest_cpu == smp_processor_id())
4125                 goto unlock;
4126 
4127         if (likely(cpu_active(dest_cpu))) {
4128                 struct migration_arg arg = { p, dest_cpu };
4129 
4130                 raw_spin_unlock_irqrestore(&p->pi_lock, flags);
4131                 stop_one_cpu(task_cpu(p), migration_cpu_stop, &arg);
4132                 return;
4133         }
4134 unlock:
4135         raw_spin_unlock_irqrestore(&p->pi_lock, flags);
4136 }
4137 
4138 #endif
4139 
4140 DEFINE_PER_CPU(struct kernel_stat, kstat);
4141 DEFINE_PER_CPU(struct kernel_cpustat, kernel_cpustat);
4142 
4143 EXPORT_PER_CPU_SYMBOL(kstat);
4144 EXPORT_PER_CPU_SYMBOL(kernel_cpustat);
4145 
4146 /*
4147  * The function fair_sched_class.update_curr accesses the struct curr
4148  * and its field curr->exec_start; when called from task_sched_runtime(),
4149  * we observe a high rate of cache misses in practice.
4150  * Prefetching this data results in improved performance.
4151  */
4152 static inline void prefetch_curr_exec_start(struct task_struct *p)
4153 {
4154 #ifdef CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED
4155         struct sched_entity *curr = (&p->se)->cfs_rq->curr;
4156 #else
4157         struct sched_entity *curr = (&task_rq(p)->cfs)->curr;
4158 #endif
4159         prefetch(curr);
4160         prefetch(&curr->exec_start);
4161 }
4162 
4163 /*
4164  * Return accounted runtime for the task.
4165  * In case the task is currently running, return the runtime plus current's
4166  * pending runtime that have not been accounted yet.
4167  */
4168 unsigned long long task_sched_runtime(struct task_struct *p)
4169 {
4170         struct rq_flags rf;
4171         struct rq *rq;
4172         u64 ns;
4173 
4174 #if defined(CONFIG_64BIT) && defined(CONFIG_SMP)
4175         /*
4176          * 64-bit doesn't need locks to atomically read a 64-bit value.
4177          * So we have a optimization chance when the task's delta_exec is 0.
4178          * Reading ->on_cpu is racy, but this is ok.
4179          *
4180          * If we race with it leaving CPU, we'll take a lock. So we're correct.
4181          * If we race with it entering CPU, unaccounted time is 0. This is
4182          * indistinguishable from the read occurring a few cycles earlier.
4183          * If we see ->on_cpu without ->on_rq, the task is leaving, and has
4184          * been accounted, so we're correct here as well.
4185          */
4186         if (!p->on_cpu || !task_on_rq_queued(p))
4187                 return p->se.sum_exec_runtime;
4188 #endif
4189 
4190         rq = task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
4191         /*
4192          * Must be ->curr _and_ ->on_rq.  If dequeued, we would
4193          * project cycles that may never be accounted to this
4194          * thread, breaking clock_gettime().
4195          */
4196         if (task_current(rq, p) && task_on_rq_queued(p)) {
4197                 prefetch_curr_exec_start(p);
4198                 update_rq_clock(rq);
4199                 p->sched_class->update_curr(rq);
4200         }
4201         ns = p->se.sum_exec_runtime;
4202         task_rq_unlock(rq, p, &rf);
4203 
4204         return ns;
4205 }
4206 
4207 /*
4208  * This function gets called by the timer code, with HZ frequency.
4209  * We call it with interrupts disabled.
4210  */
4211 void scheduler_tick(void)
4212 {
4213         int cpu = smp_processor_id();
4214         struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
4215         struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
4216         struct rq_flags rf;
4217         unsigned long thermal_pressure;
4218 
4219         arch_scale_freq_tick();
4220         sched_clock_tick();
4221 
4222         rq_lock(rq, &rf);
4223 
4224         trace_android_rvh_tick_entry(rq);
4225         update_rq_clock(rq);
4226         thermal_pressure = arch_scale_thermal_pressure(cpu_of(rq));
4227         update_thermal_load_avg(rq_clock_thermal(rq), rq, thermal_pressure);
4228         curr->sched_class->task_tick(rq, curr, 0);
4229         calc_global_load_tick(rq);
4230         psi_task_tick(rq);
4231 
4232         rq_unlock(rq, &rf);
4233 
4234         perf_event_task_tick();
4235 
4236 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
4237         rq->idle_balance = idle_cpu(cpu);
4238         trigger_load_balance(rq);
4239 #endif
4240 
4241         trace_android_vh_scheduler_tick(rq);
4242 }
4243 
4244 #ifdef CONFIG_NO_HZ_FULL
4245 
4246 struct tick_work {
4247         int                     cpu;
4248         atomic_t                state;
4249         struct delayed_work     work;
4250 };
4251 /* Values for ->state, see diagram below. */
4252 #define TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_OFFLINE       0
4253 #define TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_OFFLINING     1
4254 #define TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_RUNNING       2
4255 
4256 /*
4257  * State diagram for ->state:
4258  *
4259  *
4260  *          TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_OFFLINE
4261  *                    |   ^
4262  *                    |   |
4263  *                    |   | sched_tick_remote()
4264  *                    |   |
4265  *                    |   |
4266  *                    +--TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_OFFLINING
4267  *                    |   ^
4268  *                    |   |
4269  * sched_tick_start() |   | sched_tick_stop()
4270  *                    |   |
4271  *                    V   |
4272  *          TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_RUNNING
4273  *
4274  *
4275  * Other transitions get WARN_ON_ONCE(), except that sched_tick_remote()
4276  * and sched_tick_start() are happy to leave the state in RUNNING.
4277  */
4278 
4279 static struct tick_work __percpu *tick_work_cpu;
4280 
4281 static void sched_tick_remote(struct work_struct *work)
4282 {
4283         struct delayed_work *dwork = to_delayed_work(work);
4284         struct tick_work *twork = container_of(dwork, struct tick_work, work);
4285         int cpu = twork->cpu;
4286         struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
4287         struct task_struct *curr;
4288         struct rq_flags rf;
4289         u64 delta;
4290         int os;
4291 
4292         /*
4293          * Handle the tick only if it appears the remote CPU is running in full
4294          * dynticks mode. The check is racy by nature, but missing a tick or
4295          * having one too much is no big deal because the scheduler tick updates
4296          * statistics and checks timeslices in a time-independent way, regardless
4297          * of when exactly it is running.
4298          */
4299         if (!tick_nohz_tick_stopped_cpu(cpu))
4300                 goto out_requeue;
4301 
4302         rq_lock_irq(rq, &rf);
4303         curr = rq->curr;
4304         if (cpu_is_offline(cpu))
4305                 goto out_unlock;
4306 
4307         update_rq_clock(rq);
4308 
4309         if (!is_idle_task(curr)) {
4310                 /*
4311                  * Make sure the next tick runs within a reasonable
4312                  * amount of time.
4313                  */
4314                 delta = rq_clock_task(rq) - curr->se.exec_start;
4315                 WARN_ON_ONCE(delta > (u64)NSEC_PER_SEC * 3);
4316         }
4317         curr->sched_class->task_tick(rq, curr, 0);
4318 
4319         calc_load_nohz_remote(rq);
4320 out_unlock:
4321         rq_unlock_irq(rq, &rf);
4322 out_requeue:
4323 
4324         /*
4325          * Run the remote tick once per second (1Hz). This arbitrary
4326          * frequency is large enough to avoid overload but short enough
4327          * to keep scheduler internal stats reasonably up to date.  But
4328          * first update state to reflect hotplug activity if required.
4329          */
4330         os = atomic_fetch_add_unless(&twork->state, -1, TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_RUNNING);
4331         WARN_ON_ONCE(os == TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_OFFLINE);
4332         if (os == TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_RUNNING)
4333                 queue_delayed_work(system_unbound_wq, dwork, HZ);
4334 }
4335 
4336 static void sched_tick_start(int cpu)
4337 {
4338         int os;
4339         struct tick_work *twork;
4340 
4341         if (housekeeping_cpu(cpu, HK_FLAG_TICK))
4342                 return;
4343 
4344         WARN_ON_ONCE(!tick_work_cpu);
4345 
4346         twork = per_cpu_ptr(tick_work_cpu, cpu);
4347         os = atomic_xchg(&twork->state, TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_RUNNING);
4348         WARN_ON_ONCE(os == TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_RUNNING);
4349         if (os == TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_OFFLINE) {
4350                 twork->cpu = cpu;
4351                 INIT_DELAYED_WORK(&twork->work, sched_tick_remote);
4352                 queue_delayed_work(system_unbound_wq, &twork->work, HZ);
4353         }
4354 }
4355 
4356 #ifdef CONFIG_HOTPLUG_CPU
4357 static void sched_tick_stop(int cpu)
4358 {
4359         struct tick_work *twork;
4360         int os;
4361 
4362         if (housekeeping_cpu(cpu, HK_FLAG_TICK))
4363                 return;
4364 
4365         WARN_ON_ONCE(!tick_work_cpu);
4366 
4367         twork = per_cpu_ptr(tick_work_cpu, cpu);
4368         /* There cannot be competing actions, but don't rely on stop-machine. */
4369         os = atomic_xchg(&twork->state, TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_OFFLINING);
