4370         WARN_ON_ONCE(os != TICK_SCHED_REMOTE_RUNNING);
4371         /* Don't cancel, as this would mess up the state machine. */
4372 }
4373 #endif /* CONFIG_HOTPLUG_CPU */
4374 
4375 int __init sched_tick_offload_init(void)
4376 {
4377         tick_work_cpu = alloc_percpu(struct tick_work);
4378         BUG_ON(!tick_work_cpu);
4379         return 0;
4380 }
4381 
4382 #else /* !CONFIG_NO_HZ_FULL */
4383 static inline void sched_tick_start(int cpu) { }
4384 static inline void sched_tick_stop(int cpu) { }
4385 #endif
4386 
4387 #if defined(CONFIG_PREEMPTION) && (defined(CONFIG_DEBUG_PREEMPT) || \
4388                                 defined(CONFIG_TRACE_PREEMPT_TOGGLE))
4389 /*
4390  * If the value passed in is equal to the current preempt count
4391  * then we just disabled preemption. Start timing the latency.
4392  */
4393 static inline void preempt_latency_start(int val)
4394 {
4395         if (preempt_count() == val) {
4396                 unsigned long ip = get_lock_parent_ip();
4397 #ifdef CONFIG_DEBUG_PREEMPT
4398                 current->preempt_disable_ip = ip;
4399 #endif
4400                 trace_preempt_off(CALLER_ADDR0, ip);
4401         }
4402 }
4403 
4404 void preempt_count_add(int val)
4405 {
4406 #ifdef CONFIG_DEBUG_PREEMPT
4407         /*
4408          * Underflow?
4409          */
4410         if (DEBUG_LOCKS_WARN_ON((preempt_count() < 0)))
4411                 return;
4412 #endif
4413         __preempt_count_add(val);
4414 #ifdef CONFIG_DEBUG_PREEMPT
4415         /*
4416          * Spinlock count overflowing soon?
4417          */
4418         DEBUG_LOCKS_WARN_ON((preempt_count() & PREEMPT_MASK) >=
4419                                 PREEMPT_MASK - 10);
4420 #endif
4421         preempt_latency_start(val);
4422 }
4423 EXPORT_SYMBOL(preempt_count_add);
4424 NOKPROBE_SYMBOL(preempt_count_add);
4425 
4426 /*
4427  * If the value passed in equals to the current preempt count
4428  * then we just enabled preemption. Stop timing the latency.
4429  */
4430 static inline void preempt_latency_stop(int val)
4431 {
4432         if (preempt_count() == val)
4433                 trace_preempt_on(CALLER_ADDR0, get_lock_parent_ip());
4434 }
4435 
4436 void preempt_count_sub(int val)
4437 {
4438 #ifdef CONFIG_DEBUG_PREEMPT
4439         /*
4440          * Underflow?
4441          */
4442         if (DEBUG_LOCKS_WARN_ON(val > preempt_count()))
4443                 return;
4444         /*
4445          * Is the spinlock portion underflowing?
4446          */
4447         if (DEBUG_LOCKS_WARN_ON((val < PREEMPT_MASK) &&
4448                         !(preempt_count() & PREEMPT_MASK)))
4449                 return;
4450 #endif
4451 
4452         preempt_latency_stop(val);
4453         __preempt_count_sub(val);
4454 }
4455 EXPORT_SYMBOL(preempt_count_sub);
4456 NOKPROBE_SYMBOL(preempt_count_sub);
4457 
4458 #else
4459 static inline void preempt_latency_start(int val) { }
4460 static inline void preempt_latency_stop(int val) { }
4461 #endif
4462 
4463 static inline unsigned long get_preempt_disable_ip(struct task_struct *p)
4464 {
4465 #ifdef CONFIG_DEBUG_PREEMPT
4466         return p->preempt_disable_ip;
4467 #else
4468         return 0;
4469 #endif
4470 }
4471 
4472 /*
4473  * Print scheduling while atomic bug:
4474  */
4475 static noinline void __schedule_bug(struct task_struct *prev)
4476 {
4477         /* Save this before calling printk(), since that will clobber it */
4478         unsigned long preempt_disable_ip = get_preempt_disable_ip(current);
4479 
4480         if (oops_in_progress)
4481                 return;
4482 
4483         printk(KERN_ERR "BUG: scheduling while atomic: %s/%d/0x%08x\n",
4484                 prev->comm, prev->pid, preempt_count());
4485 
4486         debug_show_held_locks(prev);
4487         print_modules();
4488         if (irqs_disabled())
4489                 print_irqtrace_events(prev);
4490         if (IS_ENABLED(CONFIG_DEBUG_PREEMPT)
4491             && in_atomic_preempt_off()) {
4492                 pr_err("Preemption disabled at:");
4493                 print_ip_sym(KERN_ERR, preempt_disable_ip);
4494         }
4495         if (panic_on_warn)
4496                 panic("scheduling while atomic\n");
4497 
4498         trace_android_rvh_schedule_bug(prev);
4499 
4500         dump_stack();
4501         add_taint(TAINT_WARN, LOCKDEP_STILL_OK);
4502 }
4503 
4504 /*
4505  * Various schedule()-time debugging checks and statistics:
4506  */
4507 static inline void schedule_debug(struct task_struct *prev, bool preempt)
4508 {
4509 #ifdef CONFIG_SCHED_STACK_END_CHECK
4510         if (task_stack_end_corrupted(prev))
4511                 panic("corrupted stack end detected inside scheduler\n");
4512 
4513         if (task_scs_end_corrupted(prev))
4514                 panic("corrupted shadow stack detected inside scheduler\n");
4515 #endif
4516 
4517 #ifdef CONFIG_DEBUG_ATOMIC_SLEEP
4518         if (!preempt && prev->state && prev->non_block_count) {
4519                 printk(KERN_ERR "BUG: scheduling in a non-blocking section: %s/%d/%i\n",
4520                         prev->comm, prev->pid, prev->non_block_count);
4521                 dump_stack();
4522                 add_taint(TAINT_WARN, LOCKDEP_STILL_OK);
4523         }
4524 #endif
4525 
4526         if (unlikely(in_atomic_preempt_off())) {
4527                 __schedule_bug(prev);
4528                 preempt_count_set(PREEMPT_DISABLED);
4529         }
4530         rcu_sleep_check();
4531 
4532         profile_hit(SCHED_PROFILING, __builtin_return_address(0));
4533 
4534         schedstat_inc(this_rq()->sched_count);
4535 }
4536 
4537 static void put_prev_task_balance(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *prev,
4538                                   struct rq_flags *rf)
4539 {
4540 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
4541         const struct sched_class *class;
4542         /*
4543          * We must do the balancing pass before put_prev_task(), such
4544          * that when we release the rq->lock the task is in the same
4545          * state as before we took rq->lock.
4546          *
4547          * We can terminate the balance pass as soon as we know there is
4548          * a runnable task of @class priority or higher.
4549          */
4550         for_class_range(class, prev->sched_class, &idle_sched_class) {
4551                 if (class->balance(rq, prev, rf))
4552                         break;
4553         }
4554 #endif
4555 
4556         put_prev_task(rq, prev);
4557 }
4558 
4559 /*
4560  * Pick up the highest-prio task:
4561  */
4562 static inline struct task_struct *
4563 pick_next_task(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *prev, struct rq_flags *rf)
4564 {
4565         const struct sched_class *class;
4566         struct task_struct *p;
4567 
4568         /*
4569          * Optimization: we know that if all tasks are in the fair class we can
4570          * call that function directly, but only if the @prev task wasn't of a
4571          * higher scheduling class, because otherwise those loose the
4572          * opportunity to pull in more work from other CPUs.
4573          */
4574         if (likely(prev->sched_class <= &fair_sched_class &&
4575                    rq->nr_running == rq->cfs.h_nr_running)) {
4576 
4577                 p = pick_next_task_fair(rq, prev, rf);
4578                 if (unlikely(p == RETRY_TASK))
4579                         goto restart;
4580 
4581                 /* Assumes fair_sched_class->next == idle_sched_class */
4582                 if (!p) {
4583                         put_prev_task(rq, prev);
4584                         p = pick_next_task_idle(rq);
4585                 }
4586 
4587                 return p;
4588         }
4589 
4590 restart:
4591         put_prev_task_balance(rq, prev, rf);
4592 
4593         for_each_class(class) {
4594                 p = class->pick_next_task(rq);
4595                 if (p)
4596                         return p;
4597         }
4598 
4599         /* The idle class should always have a runnable task: */
4600         BUG();
4601 }
4602 
4603 /*
4604  * __schedule() is the main scheduler function.
4605  *
4606  * The main means of driving the scheduler and thus entering this function are:
4607  *
4608  *   1. Explicit blocking: mutex, semaphore, waitqueue, etc.
4609  *
4610  *   2. TIF_NEED_RESCHED flag is checked on interrupt and userspace return
4611  *      paths. For example, see arch/x86/entry_64.S.
4612  *
4613  *      To drive preemption between tasks, the scheduler sets the flag in timer
4614  *      interrupt handler scheduler_tick().
4615  *
4616  *   3. Wakeups don't really cause entry into schedule(). They add a
4617  *      task to the run-queue and that's it.
4618  *
4619  *      Now, if the new task added to the run-queue preempts the current
4620  *      task, then the wakeup sets TIF_NEED_RESCHED and schedule() gets
4621  *      called on the nearest possible occasion:
4622  *
4623  *       - If the kernel is preemptible (CONFIG_PREEMPTION=y):
4624  *
4625  *         - in syscall or exception context, at the next outmost
4626  *           preempt_enable(). (this might be as soon as the wake_up()'s
4627  *           spin_unlock()!)
4628  *
4629  *         - in IRQ context, return from interrupt-handler to
4630  *           preemptible context
4631  *
4632  *       - If the kernel is not preemptible (CONFIG_PREEMPTION is not set)
4633  *         then at the next:
4634  *
4635  *          - cond_resched() call
4636  *          - explicit schedule() call
4637  *          - return from syscall or exception to user-space
4638  *          - return from interrupt-handler to user-space
4639  *
4640  * WARNING: must be called with preemption disabled!
4641  */
4642 static void __sched notrace __schedule(bool preempt)
4643 {
4644         struct task_struct *prev, *next;
4645         unsigned long *switch_count;
4646         unsigned long prev_state;
4647         struct rq_flags rf;
4648         struct rq *rq;
4649         int cpu;
4650 
4651         cpu = smp_processor_id();
4652         rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
4653         prev = rq->curr;
4654 
4655         schedule_debug(prev, preempt);
4656 
4657         if (sched_feat(HRTICK))
4658                 hrtick_clear(rq);
4659 
4660         local_irq_disable();
4661         rcu_note_context_switch(preempt);
4662 
4663         /*
4664          * Make sure that signal_pending_state()->signal_pending() below
4665          * can't be reordered with __set_current_state(TASK_INTERRUPTIBLE)
4666          * done by the caller to avoid the race with signal_wake_up():
4667          *
4668          * __set_current_state(@state)          signal_wake_up()
4669          * schedule()                             set_tsk_thread_flag(p, TIF_SIGPENDING)
4670          *                                        wake_up_state(p, state)
4671          *   LOCK rq->lock                          LOCK p->pi_state
4672          *   smp_mb__after_spinlock()               smp_mb__after_spinlock()
4673          *     if (signal_pending_state())          if (p->state & @state)
4674          *
4675          * Also, the membarrier system call requires a full memory barrier
4676          * after coming from user-space, before storing to rq->curr.
4677          */
4678         rq_lock(rq, &rf);
4679         smp_mb__after_spinlock();
4680 
4681         /* Promote REQ to ACT */
4682         rq->clock_update_flags <<= 1;
4683         update_rq_clock(rq);
4684 
4685         switch_count = &prev->nivcsw;
4686 
4687         /*
4688          * We must load prev->state once (task_struct::state is volatile), such
4689          * that:
4690          *
4691          *  - we form a control dependency vs deactivate_task() below.
4692          *  - ptrace_{,un}freeze_traced() can change ->state underneath us.
4693          */
4694         prev_state = prev->state;
4695         if (!preempt && prev_state) {
4696                 if (signal_pending_state(prev_state, prev)) {
4697                         prev->state = TASK_RUNNING;
4698                 } else {
4699                         prev->sched_contributes_to_load =
4700                                 (prev_state & TASK_UNINTERRUPTIBLE) &&
4701                                 !(prev_state & TASK_NOLOAD) &&
4702                                 !(prev->flags & PF_FROZEN);
4703 
4704                         if (prev->sched_contributes_to_load)
4705                                 rq->nr_uninterruptible++;
4706 
4707                         /*
4708                          * __schedule()                 ttwu()
4709                          *   prev_state = prev->state;    if (p->on_rq && ...)
4710                          *   if (prev_state)                goto out;
4711                          *     p->on_rq = 0;              smp_acquire__after_ctrl_dep();
4712                          *                                p->state = TASK_WAKING
4713                          *
4714                          * Where __schedule() and ttwu() have matching control dependencies.
4715                          *
4716                          * After this, schedule() must not care about p->state any more.
4717                          */
4718                         deactivate_task(rq, prev, DEQUEUE_SLEEP | DEQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
4719 
4720                         if (prev->in_iowait) {
4721                                 atomic_inc(&rq->nr_iowait);
4722                                 delayacct_blkio_start();
4723                         }
4724                 }
4725                 switch_count = &prev->nvcsw;
4726         }
4727 
4728         next = pick_next_task(rq, prev, &rf);
4729         clear_tsk_need_resched(prev);
4730         clear_preempt_need_resched();
4731 
4732         trace_android_rvh_schedule(prev, next, rq);
4733         if (likely(prev != next)) {
4734                 rq->nr_switches++;
4735                 /*
4736                  * RCU users of rcu_dereference(rq->curr) may not see
4737                  * changes to task_struct made by pick_next_task().
4738                  */
4739                 RCU_INIT_POINTER(rq->curr, next);
4740                 /*
4741                  * The membarrier system call requires each architecture
4742                  * to have a full memory barrier after updating
4743                  * rq->curr, before returning to user-space.
4744                  *
4745                  * Here are the schemes providing that barrier on the
4746                  * various architectures:
4747                  * - mm ? switch_mm() : mmdrop() for x86, s390, sparc, PowerPC.
4748                  *   switch_mm() rely on membarrier_arch_switch_mm() on PowerPC.
4749                  * - finish_lock_switch() for weakly-ordered
4750                  *   architectures where spin_unlock is a full barrier,
4751                  * - switch_to() for arm64 (weakly-ordered, spin_unlock
4752                  *   is a RELEASE barrier),
4753                  */
4754                 ++*switch_count;
4755 
4756                 psi_sched_switch(prev, next, !task_on_rq_queued(prev));
4757 
4758                 trace_sched_switch(preempt, prev, next);
4759 
4760                 /* Also unlocks the rq: */
4761                 rq = context_switch(rq, prev, next, &rf);
4762         } else {
4763                 rq->clock_update_flags &= ~(RQCF_ACT_SKIP|RQCF_REQ_SKIP);
4764                 rq_unlock_irq(rq, &rf);
4765         }
4766 
4767         balance_callback(rq);
4768 }
4769 
4770 void __noreturn do_task_dead(void)
4771 {
4772         /* Causes final put_task_struct in finish_task_switch(): */
4773         set_special_state(TASK_DEAD);
4774 
4775         /* Tell freezer to ignore us: */
4776         current->flags |= PF_NOFREEZE;
4777 
4778         __schedule(false);
4779         BUG();
4780 
4781         /* Avoid "noreturn function does return" - but don't continue if BUG() is a NOP: */
4782         for (;;)
4783                 cpu_relax();
4784 }
4785 
4786 static inline void sched_submit_work(struct task_struct *tsk)
4787 {
4788         unsigned int task_flags;
4789 
4790         if (!tsk->state)
4791                 return;
4792 
4793         task_flags = tsk->flags;
4794         /*
4795          * If a worker went to sleep, notify and ask workqueue whether
4796          * it wants to wake up a task to maintain concurrency.
4797          * As this function is called inside the schedule() context,
4798          * we disable preemption to avoid it calling schedule() again
4799          * in the possible wakeup of a kworker and because wq_worker_sleeping()
4800          * requires it.
4801          */
4802         if (task_flags & (PF_WQ_WORKER | PF_IO_WORKER)) {
4803                 preempt_disable();
4804                 if (task_flags & PF_WQ_WORKER)
4805                         wq_worker_sleeping(tsk);
4806                 else
4807                         io_wq_worker_sleeping(tsk);
4808                 preempt_enable_no_resched();
4809         }
4810 
4811         if (tsk_is_pi_blocked(tsk))
4812                 return;
4813 
4814         /*
4815          * If we are going to sleep and we have plugged IO queued,
4816          * make sure to submit it to avoid deadlocks.
4817          */
4818         if (blk_needs_flush_plug(tsk))
4819                 blk_schedule_flush_plug(tsk);
4820 }
4821 
4822 static void sched_update_worker(struct task_struct *tsk)
4823 {
4824         if (tsk->flags & (PF_WQ_WORKER | PF_IO_WORKER)) {
4825                 if (tsk->flags & PF_WQ_WORKER)
4826                         wq_worker_running(tsk);
4827                 else
4828                         io_wq_worker_running(tsk);
4829         }
4830 }
4831 
4832 asmlinkage __visible void __sched schedule(void)
4833 {
4834         struct task_struct *tsk = current;
4835 
4836         sched_submit_work(tsk);
4837         do {
4838                 preempt_disable();
4839                 __schedule(false);
4840                 sched_preempt_enable_no_resched();
4841         } while (need_resched());
4842         sched_update_worker(tsk);
4843 }
4844 EXPORT_SYMBOL(schedule);
4845 
4846 /*
4847  * synchronize_rcu_tasks() makes sure that no task is stuck in preempted
4848  * state (have scheduled out non-voluntarily) by making sure that all
4849  * tasks have either left the run queue or have gone into user space.
4850  * As idle tasks do not do either, they must not ever be preempted
4851  * (schedule out non-voluntarily).
4852  *
4853  * schedule_idle() is similar to schedule_preempt_disable() except that it
4854  * never enables preemption because it does not call sched_submit_work().
4855  */
4856 void __sched schedule_idle(void)
4857 {
4858         /*
4859          * As this skips calling sched_submit_work(), which the idle task does
4860          * regardless because that function is a nop when the task is in a
4861          * TASK_RUNNING state, make sure this isn't used someplace that the
4862          * current task can be in any other state. Note, idle is always in the
4863          * TASK_RUNNING state.
4864          */
4865         WARN_ON_ONCE(current->state);
4866         do {
4867                 __schedule(false);
4868         } while (need_resched());
4869 }
4870 
4871 #ifdef CONFIG_CONTEXT_TRACKING
4872 asmlinkage __visible void __sched schedule_user(void)
4873 {
4874         /*
4875          * If we come here after a random call to set_need_resched(),
4876          * or we have been woken up remotely but the IPI has not yet arrived,
4877          * we haven't yet exited the RCU idle mode. Do it here manually until
4878          * we find a better solution.
4879          *
4880          * NB: There are buggy callers of this function.  Ideally we
4881          * should warn if prev_state != CONTEXT_USER, but that will trigger
4882          * too frequently to make sense yet.
4883          */
4884         enum ctx_state prev_state = exception_enter();
4885         schedule();
4886         exception_exit(prev_state);
4887 }
4888 #endif
4889 
4890 /**
4891  * schedule_preempt_disabled - called with preemption disabled
4892  *
4893  * Returns with preemption disabled. Note: preempt_count must be 1
4894  */
4895 void __sched schedule_preempt_disabled(void)
4896 {
4897         sched_preempt_enable_no_resched();
4898         schedule();
4899         preempt_disable();
4900 }
4901 
4902 static void __sched notrace preempt_schedule_common(void)
4903 {
4904         do {
4905                 /*
4906                  * Because the function tracer can trace preempt_count_sub()
4907                  * and it also uses preempt_enable/disable_notrace(), if
4908                  * NEED_RESCHED is set, the preempt_enable_notrace() called
4909                  * by the function tracer will call this function again and
4910                  * cause infinite recursion.
4911                  *
4912                  * Preemption must be disabled here before the function
4913                  * tracer can trace. Break up preempt_disable() into two
4914                  * calls. One to disable preemption without fear of being
4915                  * traced. The other to still record the preemption latency,
4916                  * which can also be traced by the function tracer.
4917                  */
4918                 preempt_disable_notrace();
4919                 preempt_latency_start(1);
4920                 __schedule(true);
4921                 preempt_latency_stop(1);
4922                 preempt_enable_no_resched_notrace();
4923 
4924                 /*
4925                  * Check again in case we missed a preemption opportunity
4926                  * between schedule and now.
4927                  */
4928         } while (need_resched());
4929 }
4930 
4931 #ifdef CONFIG_PREEMPTION
4932 /*
4933  * This is the entry point to schedule() from in-kernel preemption
4934  * off of preempt_enable.
4935  */
4936 asmlinkage __visible void __sched notrace preempt_schedule(void)
4937 {
4938         /*
4939          * If there is a non-zero preempt_count or interrupts are disabled,
4940          * we do not want to preempt the current task. Just return..
4941          */
4942         if (likely(!preemptible()))
4943                 return;
4944 
4945         preempt_schedule_common();
4946 }
4947 NOKPROBE_SYMBOL(preempt_schedule);
4948 EXPORT_SYMBOL(preempt_schedule);
4949 
4950 /**
4951  * preempt_schedule_notrace - preempt_schedule called by tracing
4952  *
4953  * The tracing infrastructure uses preempt_enable_notrace to prevent
4954  * recursion and tracing preempt enabling caused by the tracing
4955  * infrastructure itself. But as tracing can happen in areas coming
4956  * from userspace or just about to enter userspace, a preempt enable
4957  * can occur before user_exit() is called. This will cause the scheduler
4958  * to be called when the system is still in usermode.
4959  *
4960  * To prevent this, the preempt_enable_notrace will use this function
4961  * instead of preempt_schedule() to exit user context if needed before
4962  * calling the scheduler.
4963  */
4964 asmlinkage __visible void __sched notrace preempt_schedule_notrace(void)
4965 {
4966         enum ctx_state prev_ctx;
4967 
4968         if (likely(!preemptible()))
4969                 return;
4970 
4971         do {
4972                 /*
4973                  * Because the function tracer can trace preempt_count_sub()
4974                  * and it also uses preempt_enable/disable_notrace(), if
4975                  * NEED_RESCHED is set, the preempt_enable_notrace() called
4976                  * by the function tracer will call this function again and
4977                  * cause infinite recursion.
4978                  *
4979                  * Preemption must be disabled here before the function
4980                  * tracer can trace. Break up preempt_disable() into two
4981                  * calls. One to disable preemption without fear of being
4982                  * traced. The other to still record the preemption latency,
4983                  * which can also be traced by the function tracer.
4984                  */
4985                 preempt_disable_notrace();
4986                 preempt_latency_start(1);
4987                 /*
4988                  * Needs preempt disabled in case user_exit() is traced
4989                  * and the tracer calls preempt_enable_notrace() causing
4990                  * an infinite recursion.
4991                  */
4992                 prev_ctx = exception_enter();
4993                 __schedule(true);
4994                 exception_exit(prev_ctx);
4995 
4996                 preempt_latency_stop(1);
4997                 preempt_enable_no_resched_notrace();
4998         } while (need_resched());
4999 }
5000 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(preempt_schedule_notrace);
5001 
5002 #endif /* CONFIG_PREEMPTION */
5003 
5004 /*
5005  * This is the entry point to schedule() from kernel preemption
5006  * off of irq context.
5007  * Note, that this is called and return with irqs disabled. This will
5008  * protect us against recursive calling from irq.
5009  */
5010 asmlinkage __visible void __sched preempt_schedule_irq(void)
5011 {
5012         enum ctx_state prev_state;
5013 
5014         /* Catch callers which need to be fixed */
5015         BUG_ON(preempt_count() || !irqs_disabled());
5016 
5017         prev_state = exception_enter();
5018 
5019         do {
5020                 preempt_disable();
5021                 local_irq_enable();
5022                 __schedule(true);
5023                 local_irq_disable();
5024                 sched_preempt_enable_no_resched();
5025         } while (need_resched());
5026 
5027         exception_exit(prev_state);
5028 }
5029 
5030 int default_wake_function(wait_queue_entry_t *curr, unsigned mode, int wake_flags,
5031                           void *key)
5032 {
5033         WARN_ON_ONCE(IS_ENABLED(CONFIG_SCHED_DEBUG) && wake_flags & ~(WF_SYNC | WF_ANDROID_VENDOR));
5034         return try_to_wake_up(curr->private, mode, wake_flags);
5035 }
5036 EXPORT_SYMBOL(default_wake_function);
5037 
5038 #ifdef CONFIG_RT_MUTEXES
5039 
5040 static inline int __rt_effective_prio(struct task_struct *pi_task, int prio)
5041 {
5042         if (pi_task)
5043                 prio = min(prio, pi_task->prio);
5044 
5045         return prio;
5046 }
5047 
5048 static inline int rt_effective_prio(struct task_struct *p, int prio)
5049 {
5050         struct task_struct *pi_task = rt_mutex_get_top_task(p);
5051 
5052         return __rt_effective_prio(pi_task, prio);
5053 }
5054 
5055 /*
5056  * rt_mutex_setprio - set the current priority of a task
5057  * @p: task to boost
5058  * @pi_task: donor task
5059  *
5060  * This function changes the 'effective' priority of a task. It does
5061  * not touch ->normal_prio like __setscheduler().
5062  *
5063  * Used by the rt_mutex code to implement priority inheritance
5064  * logic. Call site only calls if the priority of the task changed.
5065  */
5066 void rt_mutex_setprio(struct task_struct *p, struct task_struct *pi_task)
5067 {
5068         int prio, oldprio, queued, running, queue_flag =
5069                 DEQUEUE_SAVE | DEQUEUE_MOVE | DEQUEUE_NOCLOCK;
5070         const struct sched_class *prev_class;
5071         struct rq_flags rf;
5072         struct rq *rq;
5073 
5074         trace_android_rvh_rtmutex_prepare_setprio(p, pi_task);
5075         /* XXX used to be waiter->prio, not waiter->task->prio */
5076         prio = __rt_effective_prio(pi_task, p->normal_prio);
5077 
5078         /*
5079          * If nothing changed; bail early.
5080          */
5081         if (p->pi_top_task == pi_task && prio == p->prio && !dl_prio(prio))
5082                 return;
5083 
5084         rq = __task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
5085         update_rq_clock(rq);
5086         /*
5087          * Set under pi_lock && rq->lock, such that the value can be used under
5088          * either lock.
5089          *
5090          * Note that there is loads of tricky to make this pointer cache work
5091          * right. rt_mutex_slowunlock()+rt_mutex_postunlock() work together to
5092          * ensure a task is de-boosted (pi_task is set to NULL) before the
5093          * task is allowed to run again (and can exit). This ensures the pointer
5094          * points to a blocked task -- which guaratees the task is present.
5095          */
5096         p->pi_top_task = pi_task;
5097 
5098         /*
5099          * For FIFO/RR we only need to set prio, if that matches we're done.
5100          */
5101         if (prio == p->prio && !dl_prio(prio))
5102                 goto out_unlock;
5103 
5104         /*
5105          * Idle task boosting is a nono in general. There is one
5106          * exception, when PREEMPT_RT and NOHZ is active:
5107          *
5108          * The idle task calls get_next_timer_interrupt() and holds
5109          * the timer wheel base->lock on the CPU and another CPU wants
5110          * to access the timer (probably to cancel it). We can safely
5111          * ignore the boosting request, as the idle CPU runs this code
5112          * with interrupts disabled and will complete the lock
5113          * protected section without being interrupted. So there is no
5114          * real need to boost.
5115          */
5116         if (unlikely(p == rq->idle)) {
5117                 WARN_ON(p != rq->curr);
5118                 WARN_ON(p->pi_blocked_on);
5119                 goto out_unlock;
5120         }
5121 
5122         trace_sched_pi_setprio(p, pi_task);
5123         oldprio = p->prio;
5124 
5125         if (oldprio == prio)
5126                 queue_flag &= ~DEQUEUE_MOVE;
5127 
5128         prev_class = p->sched_class;
5129         queued = task_on_rq_queued(p);
5130         running = task_current(rq, p);
5131         if (queued)
5132                 dequeue_task(rq, p, queue_flag);
5133         if (running)
5134                 put_prev_task(rq, p);
5135 
5136         /*
5137          * Boosting condition are:
5138          * 1. -rt task is running and holds mutex A
5139          *      --> -dl task blocks on mutex A
5140          *
5141          * 2. -dl task is running and holds mutex A
5142          *      --> -dl task blocks on mutex A and could preempt the
5143          *          running task
5144          */
5145         if (dl_prio(prio)) {
5146                 if (!dl_prio(p->normal_prio) ||
5147                     (pi_task && dl_prio(pi_task->prio) &&
5148                      dl_entity_preempt(&pi_task->dl, &p->dl))) {
5149                         p->dl.pi_se = pi_task->dl.pi_se;
5150                         queue_flag |= ENQUEUE_REPLENISH;
5151                 } else {
5152                         p->dl.pi_se = &p->dl;
5153                 }
5154                 p->sched_class = &dl_sched_class;
5155         } else if (rt_prio(prio)) {
5156                 if (dl_prio(oldprio))
5157                         p->dl.pi_se = &p->dl;
5158                 if (oldprio < prio)
5159                         queue_flag |= ENQUEUE_HEAD;
5160                 p->sched_class = &rt_sched_class;
5161         } else {
5162                 if (dl_prio(oldprio))
5163                         p->dl.pi_se = &p->dl;
5164                 if (rt_prio(oldprio))
5165                         p->rt.timeout = 0;
5166                 p->sched_class = &fair_sched_class;
5167         }
5168 
5169         p->prio = prio;
5170 
5171         if (queued)
5172                 enqueue_task(rq, p, queue_flag);
5173         if (running)
5174                 set_next_task(rq, p);
5175 
5176         check_class_changed(rq, p, prev_class, oldprio);
5177 out_unlock:
5178         /* Avoid rq from going away on us: */
5179         preempt_disable();
5180         __task_rq_unlock(rq, &rf);
5181 
5182         balance_callback(rq);
5183         preempt_enable();
5184 }
5185 #else
5186 static inline int rt_effective_prio(struct task_struct *p, int prio)
5187 {
5188         return prio;
5189 }
5190 #endif
5191 
5192 void set_user_nice(struct task_struct *p, long nice)
5193 {
5194         bool queued, running, allowed = false;
5195         int old_prio;
5196         struct rq_flags rf;
5197         struct rq *rq;
5198 
5199         trace_android_rvh_set_user_nice(p, &nice, &allowed);
5200         if ((task_nice(p) == nice || nice < MIN_NICE || nice > MAX_NICE) && !allowed)
5201                 return;
5202         /*
5203          * We have to be careful, if called from sys_setpriority(),
5204          * the task might be in the middle of scheduling on another CPU.
5205          */
5206         rq = task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
5207         update_rq_clock(rq);
5208 
5209         /*
5210          * The RT priorities are set via sched_setscheduler(), but we still
5211          * allow the 'normal' nice value to be set - but as expected
5212          * it wont have any effect on scheduling until the task is
5213          * SCHED_DEADLINE, SCHED_FIFO or SCHED_RR:
5214          */
5215         if (task_has_dl_policy(p) || task_has_rt_policy(p)) {
5216                 p->static_prio = NICE_TO_PRIO(nice);
5217                 goto out_unlock;
5218         }
5219         queued = task_on_rq_queued(p);
5220         running = task_current(rq, p);
5221         if (queued)
5222                 dequeue_task(rq, p, DEQUEUE_SAVE | DEQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
5223         if (running)
5224                 put_prev_task(rq, p);
5225 
5226         p->static_prio = NICE_TO_PRIO(nice);
5227         set_load_weight(p, true);
5228         old_prio = p->prio;
5229         p->prio = effective_prio(p);
5230 
5231         if (queued)
5232                 enqueue_task(rq, p, ENQUEUE_RESTORE | ENQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
5233         if (running)
5234                 set_next_task(rq, p);
5235 
5236         /*
5237          * If the task increased its priority or is running and
5238          * lowered its priority, then reschedule its CPU:
5239          */
5240         p->sched_class->prio_changed(rq, p, old_prio);
5241 
5242 out_unlock:
5243         task_rq_unlock(rq, p, &rf);
5244 }
5245 EXPORT_SYMBOL(set_user_nice);
5246 
5247 /*
5248  * can_nice - check if a task can reduce its nice value
5249  * @p: task
5250  * @nice: nice value
5251  */
5252 int can_nice(const struct task_struct *p, const int nice)
5253 {
5254         /* Convert nice value [19,-20] to rlimit style value [1,40]: */
5255         int nice_rlim = nice_to_rlimit(nice);
5256 
5257         return (nice_rlim <= task_rlimit(p, RLIMIT_NICE) ||
5258                 capable(CAP_SYS_NICE));
5259 }
5260 
5261 #ifdef __ARCH_WANT_SYS_NICE
5262 
5263 /*
5264  * sys_nice - change the priority of the current process.
5265  * @increment: priority increment
5266  *
5267  * sys_setpriority is a more generic, but much slower function that
5268  * does similar things.
5269  */
5270 SYSCALL_DEFINE1(nice, int, increment)
5271 {
5272         long nice, retval;
5273 
5274         /*
5275          * Setpriority might change our priority at the same moment.
5276          * We don't have to worry. Conceptually one call occurs first
5277          * and we have a single winner.
5278          */
5279         increment = clamp(increment, -NICE_WIDTH, NICE_WIDTH);
5280         nice = task_nice(current) + increment;
5281 
5282         nice = clamp_val(nice, MIN_NICE, MAX_NICE);
5283         if (increment < 0 && !can_nice(current, nice))
5284                 return -EPERM;
5285 
5286         retval = security_task_setnice(current, nice);
5287         if (retval)
5288                 return retval;
5289 
5290         set_user_nice(current, nice);
5291         return 0;
5292 }
5293 
5294 #endif
5295 
5296 /**
5297  * task_prio - return the priority value of a given task.
5298  * @p: the task in question.
5299  *
5300  * Return: The priority value as seen by users in /proc.
5301  * RT tasks are offset by -200. Normal tasks are centered
5302  * around 0, value goes from -16 to +15.
5303  */
5304 int task_prio(const struct task_struct *p)
5305 {
5306         return p->prio - MAX_RT_PRIO;
5307 }
5308 
5309 /**
5310  * idle_cpu - is a given CPU idle currently?
5311  * @cpu: the processor in question.
5312  *
5313  * Return: 1 if the CPU is currently idle. 0 otherwise.
5314  */
5315 int idle_cpu(int cpu)
5316 {
5317         struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
5318 
5319         if (rq->curr != rq->idle)
5320                 return 0;
5321 
5322         if (rq->nr_running)
5323                 return 0;
5324 
5325 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
5326         if (rq->ttwu_pending)
5327                 return 0;
5328 #endif
5329 
5330         return 1;
5331 }
5332 
5333 /**
5334  * available_idle_cpu - is a given CPU idle for enqueuing work.
5335  * @cpu: the CPU in question.
5336  *
5337  * Return: 1 if the CPU is currently idle. 0 otherwise.
5338  */
5339 int available_idle_cpu(int cpu)
5340 {
5341         if (!idle_cpu(cpu))
5342                 return 0;
5343 
5344         if (vcpu_is_preempted(cpu))
5345                 return 0;
5346 
5347         return 1;
5348 }
5349 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(available_idle_cpu);
5350 
5351 /**
5352  * idle_task - return the idle task for a given CPU.
5353  * @cpu: the processor in question.
5354  *
5355  * Return: The idle task for the CPU @cpu.
5356  */
5357 struct task_struct *idle_task(int cpu)
5358 {
5359         return cpu_rq(cpu)->idle;
5360 }
5361 
5362 /**
5363  * find_process_by_pid - find a process with a matching PID value.
5364  * @pid: the pid in question.
5365  *
5366  * The task of @pid, if found. %NULL otherwise.
5367  */
5368 static struct task_struct *find_process_by_pid(pid_t pid)
5369 {
5370         return pid ? find_task_by_vpid(pid) : current;
5371 }
5372 
5373 /*
5374  * sched_setparam() passes in -1 for its policy, to let the functions
5375  * it calls know not to change it.
5376  */
5377 #define SETPARAM_POLICY -1
5378 
5379 static void __setscheduler_params(struct task_struct *p,
5380                 const struct sched_attr *attr)
5381 {
5382         int policy = attr->sched_policy;
5383 
5384         if (policy == SETPARAM_POLICY)
5385                 policy = p->policy;
5386 
5387         p->policy = policy;
5388 
5389         if (dl_policy(policy))
5390                 __setparam_dl(p, attr);
5391         else if (fair_policy(policy))
5392                 p->static_prio = NICE_TO_PRIO(attr->sched_nice);
5393 
5394         /*
5395          * __sched_setscheduler() ensures attr->sched_priority == 0 when
5396          * !rt_policy. Always setting this ensures that things like
5397          * getparam()/getattr() don't report silly values for !rt tasks.
5398          */
5399         p->rt_priority = attr->sched_priority;
5400         p->normal_prio = normal_prio(p);
5401         set_load_weight(p, true);
5402 }
5403 
5404 /* Actually do priority change: must hold pi & rq lock. */
5405 static void __setscheduler(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p,
5406                            const struct sched_attr *attr, bool keep_boost)
5407 {
5408         /*
5409          * If params can't change scheduling class changes aren't allowed
5410          * either.
5411          */
5412         if (attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_KEEP_PARAMS)
5413                 return;
5414 
5415         __setscheduler_params(p, attr);
5416 
5417         /*
5418          * Keep a potential priority boosting if called from
5419          * sched_setscheduler().
5420          */
5421         p->prio = normal_prio(p);
5422         if (keep_boost)
5423                 p->prio = rt_effective_prio(p, p->prio);
5424 
5425         if (dl_prio(p->prio))
5426                 p->sched_class = &dl_sched_class;
5427         else if (rt_prio(p->prio))
5428                 p->sched_class = &rt_sched_class;
5429         else
5430                 p->sched_class = &fair_sched_class;
5431 
5432         trace_android_rvh_setscheduler(p);
5433 }
5434 
5435 /*
5436  * Check the target process has a UID that matches the current process's:
5437  */
5438 static bool check_same_owner(struct task_struct *p)
5439 {
5440         const struct cred *cred = current_cred(), *pcred;
5441         bool match;
5442 
5443         rcu_read_lock();
5444         pcred = __task_cred(p);
5445         match = (uid_eq(cred->euid, pcred->euid) ||
5446                  uid_eq(cred->euid, pcred->uid));
5447         rcu_read_unlock();
5448         return match;
5449 }
5450 
5451 static int __sched_setscheduler(struct task_struct *p,
5452                                 const struct sched_attr *attr,
5453                                 bool user, bool pi)
5454 {
5455         int newprio = dl_policy(attr->sched_policy) ? MAX_DL_PRIO - 1 :
5456                       MAX_RT_PRIO - 1 - attr->sched_priority;
5457         int retval, oldprio, oldpolicy = -1, queued, running;
5458         int new_effective_prio, policy = attr->sched_policy;
5459         const struct sched_class *prev_class;
5460         struct rq_flags rf;
5461         int reset_on_fork;
5462         int queue_flags = DEQUEUE_SAVE | DEQUEUE_MOVE | DEQUEUE_NOCLOCK;
5463         struct rq *rq;
5464 
5465         /* The pi code expects interrupts enabled */
5466         BUG_ON(pi && in_interrupt());
5467 recheck:
5468         /* Double check policy once rq lock held: */
5469         if (policy < 0) {
5470                 reset_on_fork = p->sched_reset_on_fork;
5471                 policy = oldpolicy = p->policy;
5472         } else {
5473                 reset_on_fork = !!(attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_RESET_ON_FORK);
5474 
5475                 if (!valid_policy(policy))
5476                         return -EINVAL;
5477         }
5478 
5479         if (attr->sched_flags & ~(SCHED_FLAG_ALL | SCHED_FLAG_SUGOV))
5480                 return -EINVAL;
5481 
5482         /*
5483          * Valid priorities for SCHED_FIFO and SCHED_RR are
5484          * 1..MAX_USER_RT_PRIO-1, valid priority for SCHED_NORMAL,
5485          * SCHED_BATCH and SCHED_IDLE is 0.
5486          */
5487         if ((p->mm && attr->sched_priority > MAX_USER_RT_PRIO-1) ||
5488             (!p->mm && attr->sched_priority > MAX_RT_PRIO-1))
5489                 return -EINVAL;
5490         if ((dl_policy(policy) && !__checkparam_dl(attr)) ||
5491             (rt_policy(policy) != (attr->sched_priority != 0)))
5492                 return -EINVAL;
5493 
5494         /*
5495          * Allow unprivileged RT tasks to decrease priority:
5496          */
5497         if (user && !capable(CAP_SYS_NICE)) {
5498                 if (fair_policy(policy)) {
5499                         if (attr->sched_nice < task_nice(p) &&
5500                             !can_nice(p, attr->sched_nice))
5501                                 return -EPERM;
5502                 }
5503 
5504                 if (rt_policy(policy)) {
5505                         unsigned long rlim_rtprio =
5506                                         task_rlimit(p, RLIMIT_RTPRIO);
5507 
5508                         /* Can't set/change the rt policy: */
5509                         if (policy != p->policy && !rlim_rtprio)
5510                                 return -EPERM;
5511 
5512                         /* Can't increase priority: */
5513                         if (attr->sched_priority > p->rt_priority &&
5514                             attr->sched_priority > rlim_rtprio)
5515                                 return -EPERM;
5516                 }
5517 
5518                  /*
5519                   * Can't set/change SCHED_DEADLINE policy at all for now
5520                   * (safest behavior); in the future we would like to allow
5521                   * unprivileged DL tasks to increase their relative deadline
5522                   * or reduce their runtime (both ways reducing utilization)
5523                   */
5524                 if (dl_policy(policy))
5525                         return -EPERM;
5526 
5527                 /*
5528                  * Treat SCHED_IDLE as nice 20. Only allow a switch to
5529                  * SCHED_NORMAL if the RLIMIT_NICE would normally permit it.
5530                  */
5531                 if (task_has_idle_policy(p) && !idle_policy(policy)) {
5532                         if (!can_nice(p, task_nice(p)))
5533                                 return -EPERM;
5534                 }
5535 
5536                 /* Can't change other user's priorities: */
5537                 if (!check_same_owner(p))
5538                         return -EPERM;
5539 
5540                 /* Normal users shall not reset the sched_reset_on_fork flag: */
5541                 if (p->sched_reset_on_fork && !reset_on_fork)
5542                         return -EPERM;
5543         }
5544 
5545         if (user) {
5546                 if (attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_SUGOV)
5547                         return -EINVAL;
5548 
5549                 retval = security_task_setscheduler(p);
5550                 if (retval)
5551                         return retval;
5552         }
5553 
5554         /* Update task specific "requested" clamps */
5555         if (attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP) {
5556                 retval = uclamp_validate(p, attr);
5557                 if (retval)
5558                         return retval;
5559         }
5560 
5561         /*
5562          * Make sure no PI-waiters arrive (or leave) while we are
5563          * changing the priority of the task:
5564          *
5565          * To be able to change p->policy safely, the appropriate
5566          * runqueue lock must be held.
5567          */
5568         rq = task_rq_lock(p, &rf);
5569         update_rq_clock(rq);
5570 
5571         /*
5572          * Changing the policy of the stop threads its a very bad idea:
5573          */
5574         if (p == rq->stop) {
5575                 retval = -EINVAL;
5576                 goto unlock;
5577         }
5578 
5579         /*
5580          * If not changing anything there's no need to proceed further,
5581          * but store a possible modification of reset_on_fork.
5582          */
5583         if (unlikely(policy == p->policy)) {
5584                 if (fair_policy(policy) && attr->sched_nice != task_nice(p))
5585                         goto change;
5586                 if (rt_policy(policy) && attr->sched_priority != p->rt_priority)
5587                         goto change;
5588                 if (dl_policy(policy) && dl_param_changed(p, attr))
5589                         goto change;
5590                 if (attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP)
5591                         goto change;
5592 
5593                 p->sched_reset_on_fork = reset_on_fork;
5594                 retval = 0;
5595                 goto unlock;
5596         }
5597 change:
5598 
5599         if (user) {
5600 #ifdef CONFIG_RT_GROUP_SCHED
5601                 /*
5602                  * Do not allow realtime tasks into groups that have no runtime
5603                  * assigned.
5604                  */
5605                 if (rt_bandwidth_enabled() && rt_policy(policy) &&
5606                                 task_group(p)->rt_bandwidth.rt_runtime == 0 &&
5607                                 !task_group_is_autogroup(task_group(p))) {
5608                         retval = -EPERM;
5609                         goto unlock;
5610                 }
5611 #endif
5612 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
5613                 if (dl_bandwidth_enabled() && dl_policy(policy) &&
5614                                 !(attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_SUGOV)) {
5615                         cpumask_t *span = rq->rd->span;
5616 
5617                         /*
5618                          * Don't allow tasks with an affinity mask smaller than
5619                          * the entire root_domain to become SCHED_DEADLINE. We
5620                          * will also fail if there's no bandwidth available.
5621                          */
5622                         if (!cpumask_subset(span, p->cpus_ptr) ||
5623                             rq->rd->dl_bw.bw == 0) {
5624                                 retval = -EPERM;
5625                                 goto unlock;
5626                         }
5627                 }
5628 #endif
5629         }
5630 
5631         /* Re-check policy now with rq lock held: */
5632         if (unlikely(oldpolicy != -1 && oldpolicy != p->policy)) {
5633                 policy = oldpolicy = -1;
5634                 task_rq_unlock(rq, p, &rf);
5635                 goto recheck;
5636         }
5637 
5638         /*
5639          * If setscheduling to SCHED_DEADLINE (or changing the parameters
5640          * of a SCHED_DEADLINE task) we need to check if enough bandwidth
5641          * is available.
5642          */
5643         if ((dl_policy(policy) || dl_task(p)) && sched_dl_overflow(p, policy, attr)) {
5644                 retval = -EBUSY;
5645                 goto unlock;
5646         }
5647 
5648         p->sched_reset_on_fork = reset_on_fork;
5649         oldprio = p->prio;
5650 
5651         if (pi) {
5652                 /*
5653                  * Take priority boosted tasks into account. If the new
5654                  * effective priority is unchanged, we just store the new
5655                  * normal parameters and do not touch the scheduler class and
5656                  * the runqueue. This will be done when the task deboost
5657                  * itself.
5658                  */
5659                 new_effective_prio = rt_effective_prio(p, newprio);
5660                 if (new_effective_prio == oldprio)
5661                         queue_flags &= ~DEQUEUE_MOVE;
5662         }
5663 
5664         queued = task_on_rq_queued(p);
5665         running = task_current(rq, p);
5666         if (queued)
5667                 dequeue_task(rq, p, queue_flags);
5668         if (running)
5669                 put_prev_task(rq, p);
5670 
5671         prev_class = p->sched_class;
5672 
5673         __setscheduler(rq, p, attr, pi);
5674         __setscheduler_uclamp(p, attr);
5675 
5676         if (queued) {
5677                 /*
5678                  * We enqueue to tail when the priority of a task is
5679                  * increased (user space view).
5680                  */
5681                 if (oldprio < p->prio)
5682                         queue_flags |= ENQUEUE_HEAD;
5683 
5684                 enqueue_task(rq, p, queue_flags);
5685         }
5686         if (running)
5687                 set_next_task(rq, p);
5688 
5689         check_class_changed(rq, p, prev_class, oldprio);
5690 
5691         /* Avoid rq from going away on us: */
5692         preempt_disable();
5693         task_rq_unlock(rq, p, &rf);
5694 
5695         if (pi)
5696                 rt_mutex_adjust_pi(p);
5697 
5698         /* Run balance callbacks after we've adjusted the PI chain: */
5699         balance_callback(rq);
5700         preempt_enable();
5701 
5702         return 0;
5703 
5704 unlock:
5705         task_rq_unlock(rq, p, &rf);
5706         return retval;
5707 }
5708 
5709 static int _sched_setscheduler(struct task_struct *p, int policy,
5710                                const struct sched_param *param, bool check)
5711 {
5712         struct sched_attr attr = {
5713                 .sched_policy   = policy,
5714                 .sched_priority = param->sched_priority,
5715                 .sched_nice     = PRIO_TO_NICE(p->static_prio),
5716         };
5717 
5718         /* Fixup the legacy SCHED_RESET_ON_FORK hack. */
5719         if ((policy != SETPARAM_POLICY) && (policy & SCHED_RESET_ON_FORK)) {
5720                 attr.sched_flags |= SCHED_FLAG_RESET_ON_FORK;
5721                 policy &= ~SCHED_RESET_ON_FORK;
5722                 attr.sched_policy = policy;
5723         }
5724 
5725         return __sched_setscheduler(p, &attr, check, true);
5726 }
5727 /**
5728  * sched_setscheduler - change the scheduling policy and/or RT priority of a thread.
5729  * @p: the task in question.
5730  * @policy: new policy.
5731  * @param: structure containing the new RT priority.
5732  *
5733  * Use sched_set_fifo(), read its comment.
5734  *
5735  * Return: 0 on success. An error code otherwise.
5736  *
5737  * NOTE that the task may be already dead.
5738  */
5739 int sched_setscheduler(struct task_struct *p, int policy,
5740                        const struct sched_param *param)
5741 {
5742         return _sched_setscheduler(p, policy, param, true);
5743 }
5744 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(sched_setscheduler);
5745 
5746 int sched_setattr(struct task_struct *p, const struct sched_attr *attr)
5747 {
5748         return __sched_setscheduler(p, attr, true, true);
5749 }
5750 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(sched_setattr);
5751 
5752 int sched_setattr_nocheck(struct task_struct *p, const struct sched_attr *attr)
5753 {
5754         return __sched_setscheduler(p, attr, false, true);
5755 }
5756 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(sched_setattr_nocheck);
5757 
5758 /**
5759  * sched_setscheduler_nocheck - change the scheduling policy and/or RT priority of a thread from kernelspace.
5760  * @p: the task in question.
5761  * @policy: new policy.
5762  * @param: structure containing the new RT priority.
5763  *
5764  * Just like sched_setscheduler, only don't bother checking if the
5765  * current context has permission.  For example, this is needed in
5766  * stop_machine(): we create temporary high priority worker threads,
5767  * but our caller might not have that capability.
5768  *
5769  * Return: 0 on success. An error code otherwise.
5770  */
5771 int sched_setscheduler_nocheck(struct task_struct *p, int policy,
5772                                const struct sched_param *param)
5773 {
5774         return _sched_setscheduler(p, policy, param, false);
5775 }
5776 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(sched_setscheduler_nocheck);
5777 
5778 /*
5779  * SCHED_FIFO is a broken scheduler model; that is, it is fundamentally
5780  * incapable of resource management, which is the one thing an OS really should
5781  * be doing.
5782  *
5783  * This is of course the reason it is limited to privileged users only.
5784  *
5785  * Worse still; it is fundamentally impossible to compose static priority
5786  * workloads. You cannot take two correctly working static prio workloads
5787  * and smash them together and still expect them to work.
5788  *
5789  * For this reason 'all' FIFO tasks the kernel creates are basically at:
5790  *
5791  *   MAX_RT_PRIO / 2
5792  *
5793  * The administrator _MUST_ configure the system, the kernel simply doesn't
5794  * know enough information to make a sensible choice.
5795  */
5796 void sched_set_fifo(struct task_struct *p)
5797 {
5798         struct sched_param sp = { .sched_priority = MAX_RT_PRIO / 2 };
5799         WARN_ON_ONCE(sched_setscheduler_nocheck(p, SCHED_FIFO, &sp) != 0);
5800 }
5801 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(sched_set_fifo);
5802 
5803 /*
5804  * For when you don't much care about FIFO, but want to be above SCHED_NORMAL.
5805  */
5806 void sched_set_fifo_low(struct task_struct *p)
5807 {
5808         struct sched_param sp = { .sched_priority = 1 };
5809         WARN_ON_ONCE(sched_setscheduler_nocheck(p, SCHED_FIFO, &sp) != 0);
5810 }
5811 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(sched_set_fifo_low);
5812 
5813 void sched_set_normal(struct task_struct *p, int nice)
5814 {
5815         struct sched_attr attr = {
5816                 .sched_policy = SCHED_NORMAL,
5817                 .sched_nice = nice,
5818         };
5819         WARN_ON_ONCE(sched_setattr_nocheck(p, &attr) != 0);
5820 }
5821 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(sched_set_normal);
5822 
5823 static int
5824 do_sched_setscheduler(pid_t pid, int policy, struct sched_param __user *param)
5825 {
5826         struct sched_param lparam;
5827         struct task_struct *p;
5828         int retval;
5829 
5830         if (!param || pid < 0)
5831                 return -EINVAL;
5832         if (copy_from_user(&lparam, param, sizeof(struct sched_param)))
5833                 return -EFAULT;
5834 
5835         rcu_read_lock();
5836         retval = -ESRCH;
5837         p = find_process_by_pid(pid);
5838         if (p != NULL)
5839                 retval = sched_setscheduler(p, policy, &lparam);
5840         rcu_read_unlock();
5841 
5842         return retval;
5843 }
5844 
5845 /*
5846  * Mimics kernel/events/core.c perf_copy_attr().
5847  */
5848 static int sched_copy_attr(struct sched_attr __user *uattr, struct sched_attr *attr)
5849 {
5850         u32 size;
5851         int ret;
5852 
5853         /* Zero the full structure, so that a short copy will be nice: */
5854         memset(attr, 0, sizeof(*attr));
5855 
5856         ret = get_user(size, &uattr->size);
5857         if (ret)
5858                 return ret;
5859 
5860         /* ABI compatibility quirk: */
5861         if (!size)
5862                 size = SCHED_ATTR_SIZE_VER0;
5863         if (size < SCHED_ATTR_SIZE_VER0 || size > PAGE_SIZE)
5864                 goto err_size;
5865 
5866         ret = copy_struct_from_user(attr, sizeof(*attr), uattr, size);
5867         if (ret) {
5868                 if (ret == -E2BIG)
5869                         goto err_size;
5870                 return ret;
5871         }
5872 
5873         if ((attr->sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_UTIL_CLAMP) &&
5874             size < SCHED_ATTR_SIZE_VER1)
5875                 return -EINVAL;
5876 
5877         /*
5878          * XXX: Do we want to be lenient like existing syscalls; or do we want
5879          * to be strict and return an error on out-of-bounds values?
5880          */
5881         attr->sched_nice = clamp(attr->sched_nice, MIN_NICE, MAX_NICE);
5882 
5883         return 0;
5884 
5885 err_size:
5886         put_user(sizeof(*attr), &uattr->size);
5887         return -E2BIG;
5888 }
5889 
5890 /**
5891  * sys_sched_setscheduler - set/change the scheduler policy and RT priority
5892  * @pid: the pid in question.
5893  * @policy: new policy.
5894  * @param: structure containing the new RT priority.
5895  *
5896  * Return: 0 on success. An error code otherwise.
5897  */
5898 SYSCALL_DEFINE3(sched_setscheduler, pid_t, pid, int, policy, struct sched_param __user *, param)
5899 {
5900         if (policy < 0)
5901                 return -EINVAL;
5902 
5903         return do_sched_setscheduler(pid, policy, param);
5904 }
5905 
5906 /**
5907  * sys_sched_setparam - set/change the RT priority of a thread
5908  * @pid: the pid in question.
5909  * @param: structure containing the new RT priority.
5910  *
5911  * Return: 0 on success. An error code otherwise.
5912  */
5913 SYSCALL_DEFINE2(sched_setparam, pid_t, pid, struct sched_param __user *, param)
5914 {
5915         return do_sched_setscheduler(pid, SETPARAM_POLICY, param);
5916 }
5917 
5918 /**
5919  * sys_sched_setattr - same as above, but with extended sched_attr
5920  * @pid: the pid in question.
5921  * @uattr: structure containing the extended parameters.
5922  * @flags: for future extension.
5923  */
5924 SYSCALL_DEFINE3(sched_setattr, pid_t, pid, struct sched_attr __user *, uattr,
5925                                unsigned int, flags)
5926 {
5927         struct sched_attr attr;
5928         struct task_struct *p;
5929         int retval;
5930 
5931         if (!uattr || pid < 0 || flags)
5932                 return -EINVAL;
5933 
5934         retval = sched_copy_attr(uattr, &attr);
5935         if (retval)
5936                 return retval;
5937 
5938         if ((int)attr.sched_policy < 0)
5939                 return -EINVAL;
5940         if (attr.sched_flags & SCHED_FLAG_KEEP_POLICY)
5941                 attr.sched_policy = SETPARAM_POLICY;
5942 
5943         rcu_read_lock();
5944         retval = -ESRCH;
5945         p = find_process_by_pid(pid);
5946         if (likely(p))
5947                 get_task_struct(p);
5948         rcu_read_unlock();
5949 
5950         if (likely(p)) {
5951                 retval = sched_setattr(p, &attr);
5952                 put_task_struct(p);
5953         }
5954 
5955         return retval;
5956 }
5957 
5958 /**
5959  * sys_sched_getscheduler - get the policy (scheduling class) of a thread
5960  * @pid: the pid in question.
5961  *
5962  * Return: On success, the policy of the thread. Otherwise, a negative error
5963  * code.
5964  */
5965 SYSCALL_DEFINE1(sched_getscheduler, pid_t, pid)
5966 {
5967         struct task_struct *p;
5968         int retval;
5969 
5970         if (pid < 0)
5971                 return -EINVAL;
5972 
5973         retval = -ESRCH;
5974         rcu_read_lock();
5975         p = find_process_by_pid(pid);
5976         if (p) {
5977                 retval = security_task_getscheduler(p);
5978                 if (!retval)
5979                         retval = p->policy
5980                                 | (p->sched_reset_on_fork ? SCHED_RESET_ON_FORK : 0);
5981         }
5982         rcu_read_unlock();
5983         return retval;
5984 }
5985 
5986 /**
5987  * sys_sched_getparam - get the RT priority of a thread
5988  * @pid: the pid in question.
5989  * @param: structure containing the RT priority.
5990  *
5991  * Return: On success, 0 and the RT priority is in @param. Otherwise, an error
5992  * code.
5993  */
5994 SYSCALL_DEFINE2(sched_getparam, pid_t, pid, struct sched_param __user *, param)
5995 {
5996         struct sched_param lp = { .sched_priority = 0 };
5997         struct task_struct *p;
5998         int retval;
5999 
6000         if (!param || pid < 0)
6001                 return -EINVAL;
6002 
6003         rcu_read_lock();
6004         p = find_process_by_pid(pid);
6005         retval = -ESRCH;
6006         if (!p)
6007                 goto out_unlock;
6008 
6009         retval = security_task_getscheduler(p);
6010         if (retval)
6011                 goto out_unlock;
6012 
6013         if (task_has_rt_policy(p))
6014                 lp.sched_priority = p->rt_priority;
6015         rcu_read_unlock();
6016 
6017         /*
6018          * This one might sleep, we cannot do it with a spinlock held ...
6019          */
6020         retval = copy_to_user(param, &lp, sizeof(*param)) ? -EFAULT : 0;
6021 
6022         return retval;
6023 
6024 out_unlock:
6025         rcu_read_unlock();
6026         return retval;
6027 }
6028 
6029 /*
6030  * Copy the kernel size attribute structure (which might be larger
6031  * than what user-space knows about) to user-space.
6032  *
6033  * Note that all cases are valid: user-space buffer can be larger or
6034  * smaller than the kernel-space buffer. The usual case is that both
6035  * have the same size.
6036  */
6037 static int
6038 sched_attr_copy_to_user(struct sched_attr __user *uattr,
6039                         struct sched_attr *kattr,
6040                         unsigned int usize)
6041 {
6042         unsigned int ksize = sizeof(*kattr);
6043 
6044         if (!access_ok(uattr, usize))
6045                 return -EFAULT;
6046 
6047         /*
6048          * sched_getattr() ABI forwards and backwards compatibility:
6049          *
6050          * If usize == ksize then we just copy everything to user-space and all is good.
6051          *
6052          * If usize < ksize then we only copy as much as user-space has space for,
6053          * this keeps ABI compatibility as well. We skip the rest.
6054          *
6055          * If usize > ksize then user-space is using a newer version of the ABI,
6056          * which part the kernel doesn't know about. Just ignore it - tooling can
6057          * detect the kernel's knowledge of attributes from the attr->size value
6058          * which is set to ksize in this case.
6059          */
6060         kattr->size = min(usize, ksize);
6061 
6062         if (copy_to_user(uattr, kattr, kattr->size))
6063                 return -EFAULT;
6064 
6065         return 0;
6066 }
6067 
6068 /**
6069  * sys_sched_getattr - similar to sched_getparam, but with sched_attr
6070  * @pid: the pid in question.
6071  * @uattr: structure containing the extended parameters.
6072  * @usize: sizeof(attr) for fwd/bwd comp.
6073  * @flags: for future extension.
6074  */
6075 SYSCALL_DEFINE4(sched_getattr, pid_t, pid, struct sched_attr __user *, uattr,
6076                 unsigned int, usize, unsigned int, flags)
6077 {
6078         struct sched_attr kattr = { };
6079         struct task_struct *p;
6080         int retval;
6081 
6082         if (!uattr || pid < 0 || usize > PAGE_SIZE ||
6083             usize < SCHED_ATTR_SIZE_VER0 || flags)
6084                 return -EINVAL;
6085 
6086         rcu_read_lock();
6087         p = find_process_by_pid(pid);
6088         retval = -ESRCH;
6089         if (!p)
6090                 goto out_unlock;
6091 
6092         retval = security_task_getscheduler(p);
6093         if (retval)
6094                 goto out_unlock;
6095 
6096         kattr.sched_policy = p->policy;
6097         if (p->sched_reset_on_fork)
6098                 kattr.sched_flags |= SCHED_FLAG_RESET_ON_FORK;
6099         if (task_has_dl_policy(p))
6100                 __getparam_dl(p, &kattr);
6101         else if (task_has_rt_policy(p))
6102                 kattr.sched_priority = p->rt_priority;
6103         else
6104                 kattr.sched_nice = task_nice(p);
6105 
6106 #ifdef CONFIG_UCLAMP_TASK
6107         /*
6108          * This could race with another potential updater, but this is fine
6109          * because it'll correctly read the old or the new value. We don't need
6110          * to guarantee who wins the race as long as it doesn't return garbage.
6111          */
6112         kattr.sched_util_min = p->uclamp_req[UCLAMP_MIN].value;
6113         kattr.sched_util_max = p->uclamp_req[UCLAMP_MAX].value;
6114 #endif
6115 
6116         rcu_read_unlock();
6117 
6118         return sched_attr_copy_to_user(uattr, &kattr, usize);
6119 
6120 out_unlock:
6121         rcu_read_unlock();
6122         return retval;
6123 }
6124 
6125 long sched_setaffinity(pid_t pid, const struct cpumask *in_mask)
6126 {
6127         cpumask_var_t cpus_allowed, new_mask;
6128         struct task_struct *p;
6129         int retval;
6130         int skip = 0;
6131 
6132         rcu_read_lock();
6133 
6134         p = find_process_by_pid(pid);
6135         if (!p) {
6136                 rcu_read_unlock();
6137                 return -ESRCH;
6138         }
6139 
6140         /* Prevent p going away */
6141         get_task_struct(p);
6142         rcu_read_unlock();
6143 
6144         if (p->flags & PF_NO_SETAFFINITY) {
6145                 retval = -EINVAL;
6146                 goto out_put_task;
6147         }
6148         if (!alloc_cpumask_var(&cpus_allowed, GFP_KERNEL)) {
6149                 retval = -ENOMEM;
6150                 goto out_put_task;
6151         }
6152         if (!alloc_cpumask_var(&new_mask, GFP_KERNEL)) {
6153                 retval = -ENOMEM;
6154                 goto out_free_cpus_allowed;
6155         }
6156         retval = -EPERM;
6157         if (!check_same_owner(p)) {
6158                 rcu_read_lock();
6159                 if (!ns_capable(__task_cred(p)->user_ns, CAP_SYS_NICE)) {
6160                         rcu_read_unlock();
6161                         goto out_free_new_mask;
6162                 }
6163                 rcu_read_unlock();
6164         }
6165 
6166         trace_android_vh_sched_setaffinity_early(p, in_mask, &skip);
6167         if (skip)
6168                 goto out_free_new_mask;
6169         retval = security_task_setscheduler(p);
6170         if (retval)
6171                 goto out_free_new_mask;
6172 
6173 
6174         cpuset_cpus_allowed(p, cpus_allowed);
6175         cpumask_and(new_mask, in_mask, cpus_allowed);
6176 
6177         /*
6178          * Since bandwidth control happens on root_domain basis,
6179          * if admission test is enabled, we only admit -deadline
6180          * tasks allowed to run on all the CPUs in the task's
6181          * root_domain.
6182          */
6183 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
6184         if (task_has_dl_policy(p) && dl_bandwidth_enabled()) {
6185                 rcu_read_lock();
6186                 if (!cpumask_subset(task_rq(p)->rd->span, new_mask)) {
6187                         retval = -EBUSY;
6188                         rcu_read_unlock();
6189                         goto out_free_new_mask;
6190                 }
6191                 rcu_read_unlock();
6192         }
6193 #endif
6194 again:
6195         retval = __set_cpus_allowed_ptr(p, new_mask, true);
6196 
6197         if (!retval) {
6198                 cpuset_cpus_allowed(p, cpus_allowed);
6199                 if (!cpumask_subset(new_mask, cpus_allowed)) {
6200                         /*
6201                          * We must have raced with a concurrent cpuset
6202                          * update. Just reset the cpus_allowed to the
6203                          * cpuset's cpus_allowed
6204                          */
6205                         cpumask_copy(new_mask, cpus_allowed);
6206                         goto again;
6207                 }
6208         }
6209 
6210         trace_android_rvh_sched_setaffinity(p, in_mask, &retval);
6211 
6212 out_free_new_mask:
6213         free_cpumask_var(new_mask);
6214 out_free_cpus_allowed:
6215         free_cpumask_var(cpus_allowed);
6216 out_put_task:
6217         put_task_struct(p);
6218         return retval;
6219 }
6220 
6221 static int get_user_cpu_mask(unsigned long __user *user_mask_ptr, unsigned len,
6222                              struct cpumask *new_mask)
6223 {
6224         if (len < cpumask_size())
6225                 cpumask_clear(new_mask);
6226         else if (len > cpumask_size())
6227                 len = cpumask_size();
6228 
6229         return copy_from_user(new_mask, user_mask_ptr, len) ? -EFAULT : 0;
6230 }
6231 
6232 /**
6233  * sys_sched_setaffinity - set the CPU affinity of a process
6234  * @pid: pid of the process
6235  * @len: length in bytes of the bitmask pointed to by user_mask_ptr
6236  * @user_mask_ptr: user-space pointer to the new CPU mask
6237  *
6238  * Return: 0 on success. An error code otherwise.
6239  */
6240 SYSCALL_DEFINE3(sched_setaffinity, pid_t, pid, unsigned int, len,
6241                 unsigned long __user *, user_mask_ptr)
6242 {
6243         cpumask_var_t new_mask;
6244         int retval;
6245 
6246         if (!alloc_cpumask_var(&new_mask, GFP_KERNEL))
6247                 return -ENOMEM;
6248 
6249         retval = get_user_cpu_mask(user_mask_ptr, len, new_mask);
6250         if (retval == 0)
6251                 retval = sched_setaffinity(pid, new_mask);
6252         free_cpumask_var(new_mask);
6253         return retval;
6254 }
6255 
6256 long sched_getaffinity(pid_t pid, struct cpumask *mask)
6257 {
6258         struct task_struct *p;
6259         unsigned long flags;
6260         int retval;
6261 
6262         rcu_read_lock();
6263 
6264         retval = -ESRCH;
6265         p = find_process_by_pid(pid);
6266         if (!p)
6267                 goto out_unlock;
6268 
6269         retval = security_task_getscheduler(p);
6270         if (retval)
6271                 goto out_unlock;
6272 
6273         raw_spin_lock_irqsave(&p->pi_lock, flags);
6274         cpumask_and(mask, &p->cpus_mask, cpu_active_mask);
6275         raw_spin_unlock_irqrestore(&p->pi_lock, flags);
6276 
6277 out_unlock:
6278         rcu_read_unlock();
6279 
6280         return retval;
6281 }
6282 
6283 /**
6284  * sys_sched_getaffinity - get the CPU affinity of a process
6285  * @pid: pid of the process
6286  * @len: length in bytes of the bitmask pointed to by user_mask_ptr
6287  * @user_mask_ptr: user-space pointer to hold the current CPU mask
6288  *
6289  * Return: size of CPU mask copied to user_mask_ptr on success. An
6290  * error code otherwise.
6291  */
6292 SYSCALL_DEFINE3(sched_getaffinity, pid_t, pid, unsigned int, len,
6293                 unsigned long __user *, user_mask_ptr)
6294 {
6295         int ret;
6296         cpumask_var_t mask;
6297 
6298         if ((len * BITS_PER_BYTE) < nr_cpu_ids)
6299                 return -EINVAL;
6300         if (len & (sizeof(unsigned long)-1))
6301                 return -EINVAL;
6302 
6303         if (!alloc_cpumask_var(&mask, GFP_KERNEL))
6304                 return -ENOMEM;
6305 
6306         ret = sched_getaffinity(pid, mask);
6307         if (ret == 0) {
6308                 unsigned int retlen = min(len, cpumask_size());
6309 
6310                 if (copy_to_user(user_mask_ptr, mask, retlen))
6311                         ret = -EFAULT;
6312                 else
6313                         ret = retlen;
6314         }
6315         free_cpumask_var(mask);
6316 
6317         return ret;
6318 }
6319 
6320 /**
6321  * sys_sched_yield - yield the current processor to other threads.
6322  *
6323  * This function yields the current CPU to other tasks. If there are no
6324  * other threads running on this CPU then this function will return.
6325  *
6326  * Return: 0.
6327  */
6328 static void do_sched_yield(void)
6329 {
6330         struct rq_flags rf;
6331         struct rq *rq;
6332 
6333         rq = this_rq_lock_irq(&rf);
6334 
6335         schedstat_inc(rq->yld_count);
6336         current->sched_class->yield_task(rq);
6337 
6338         preempt_disable();
6339         rq_unlock_irq(rq, &rf);
6340         sched_preempt_enable_no_resched();
6341 
6342         schedule();
6343 }
6344 
6345 SYSCALL_DEFINE0(sched_yield)
6346 {
6347         do_sched_yield();
6348         return 0;
6349 }
6350 
6351 #ifndef CONFIG_PREEMPTION
6352 int __sched _cond_resched(void)
6353 {
6354         if (should_resched(0)) {
6355                 preempt_schedule_common();
6356                 return 1;
6357         }
6358         rcu_all_qs();
6359         return 0;
6360 }
6361 EXPORT_SYMBOL(_cond_resched);
6362 #endif
6363 
6364 /*
6365  * __cond_resched_lock() - if a reschedule is pending, drop the given lock,
6366  * call schedule, and on return reacquire the lock.
6367  *
6368  * This works OK both with and without CONFIG_PREEMPTION. We do strange low-level
6369  * operations here to prevent schedule() from being called twice (once via
6370  * spin_unlock(), once by hand).
6371  */
6372 int __cond_resched_lock(spinlock_t *lock)
6373 {
6374         int resched = should_resched(PREEMPT_LOCK_OFFSET);
6375         int ret = 0;
6376 
6377         lockdep_assert_held(lock);
6378 
6379         if (spin_needbreak(lock) || resched) {
6380                 spin_unlock(lock);
6381                 if (resched)
6382                         preempt_schedule_common();
6383                 else
6384                         cpu_relax();
6385                 ret = 1;
6386                 spin_lock(lock);
6387         }
6388         return ret;
6389 }
6390 EXPORT_SYMBOL(__cond_resched_lock);
6391 
6392 /**
6393  * yield - yield the current processor to other threads.
6394  *
6395  * Do not ever use this function, there's a 99% chance you're doing it wrong.
6396  *
6397  * The scheduler is at all times free to pick the calling task as the most
6398  * eligible task to run, if removing the yield() call from your code breaks
6399  * it, its already broken.
6400  *
6401  * Typical broken usage is:
6402  *
6403  * while (!event)
6404  *      yield();
6405  *
6406  * where one assumes that yield() will let 'the other' process run that will
6407  * make event true. If the current task is a SCHED_FIFO task that will never
6408  * happen. Never use yield() as a progress guarantee!!
6409  *
6410  * If you want to use yield() to wait for something, use wait_event().
6411  * If you want to use yield() to be 'nice' for others, use cond_resched().
6412  * If you still want to use yield(), do not!
6413  */
6414 void __sched yield(void)
6415 {
6416         set_current_state(TASK_RUNNING);
6417         do_sched_yield();
6418 }
6419 EXPORT_SYMBOL(yield);
6420 
6421 /**
6422  * yield_to - yield the current processor to another thread in
6423  * your thread group, or accelerate that thread toward the
6424  * processor it's on.
6425  * @p: target task
6426  * @preempt: whether task preemption is allowed or not
6427  *
6428  * It's the caller's job to ensure that the target task struct
6429  * can't go away on us before we can do any checks.
6430  *
6431  * Return:
6432  *      true (>0) if we indeed boosted the target task.
6433  *      false (0) if we failed to boost the target.
6434  *      -ESRCH if there's no task to yield to.
6435  */
6436 int __sched yield_to(struct task_struct *p, bool preempt)
6437 {
6438         struct task_struct *curr = current;
6439         struct rq *rq, *p_rq;
6440         unsigned long flags;
6441         int yielded = 0;
6442 
6443         local_irq_save(flags);
6444         rq = this_rq();
6445 
6446 again:
6447         p_rq = task_rq(p);
6448         /*
6449          * If we're the only runnable task on the rq and target rq also
6450          * has only one task, there's absolutely no point in yielding.
6451          */
6452         if (rq->nr_running == 1 && p_rq->nr_running == 1) {
6453                 yielded = -ESRCH;
6454                 goto out_irq;
6455         }
6456 
6457         double_rq_lock(rq, p_rq);
6458         if (task_rq(p) != p_rq) {
6459                 double_rq_unlock(rq, p_rq);
6460                 goto again;
6461         }
6462 
6463         if (!curr->sched_class->yield_to_task)
6464                 goto out_unlock;
6465 
6466         if (curr->sched_class != p->sched_class)
6467                 goto out_unlock;
6468 
6469         if (task_running(p_rq, p) || p->state)
6470                 goto out_unlock;
6471 
6472         yielded = curr->sched_class->yield_to_task(rq, p);
6473         if (yielded) {
6474                 schedstat_inc(rq->yld_count);
6475                 /*
6476                  * Make p's CPU reschedule; pick_next_entity takes care of
6477                  * fairness.
6478                  */
6479                 if (preempt && rq != p_rq)
6480                         resched_curr(p_rq);
6481         }
6482 
6483 out_unlock:
6484         double_rq_unlock(rq, p_rq);
6485 out_irq:
6486         local_irq_restore(flags);
6487 
6488         if (yielded > 0)
6489                 schedule();
6490 
6491         return yielded;
6492 }
6493 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(yield_to);
6494 
6495 int io_schedule_prepare(void)
6496 {
6497         int old_iowait = current->in_iowait;
6498 
6499         current->in_iowait = 1;
6500         blk_schedule_flush_plug(current);
6501 
6502         return old_iowait;
6503 }
6504 
6505 void io_schedule_finish(int token)
6506 {
6507         current->in_iowait = token;
6508 }
6509 
6510 /*
6511  * This task is about to go to sleep on IO. Increment rq->nr_iowait so
6512  * that process accounting knows that this is a task in IO wait state.
6513  */
6514 long __sched io_schedule_timeout(long timeout)
6515 {
6516         int token;
6517         long ret;
6518 
6519         token = io_schedule_prepare();
6520         ret = schedule_timeout(timeout);
6521         io_schedule_finish(token);
6522 
6523         return ret;
6524 }
6525 EXPORT_SYMBOL(io_schedule_timeout);
6526 
6527 void __sched io_schedule(void)
6528 {
6529         int token;
6530 
6531         token = io_schedule_prepare();
6532         schedule();
6533         io_schedule_finish(token);
6534 }
6535 EXPORT_SYMBOL(io_schedule);
6536 
6537 /**
6538  * sys_sched_get_priority_max - return maximum RT priority.
6539  * @policy: scheduling class.
6540  *
6541  * Return: On success, this syscall returns the maximum
6542  * rt_priority that can be used by a given scheduling class.
6543  * On failure, a negative error code is returned.
6544  */
6545 SYSCALL_DEFINE1(sched_get_priority_max, int, policy)
6546 {
6547         int ret = -EINVAL;
6548 
6549         switch (policy) {
6550         case SCHED_FIFO:
6551         case SCHED_RR:
6552                 ret = MAX_USER_RT_PRIO-1;
6553                 break;
6554         case SCHED_DEADLINE:
6555         case SCHED_NORMAL:
6556         case SCHED_BATCH:
6557         case SCHED_IDLE:
6558                 ret = 0;
6559                 break;
6560         }
6561         return ret;
6562 }
6563
